IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Influenza infection is a deadly disease that is often complicated by a secondary bacterial pneumonia, which is a significant contributor to the morbidity and mortality. Antibiotics do not help the viral illness, and our work demonstrates it causes harm by altering the commensal organisms in the gastrointestinal tract to increase the susceptibility to bacterial pathogens. This study will understand how antibiotics altered the fungal colonies in the gut that affect the lungs immunity to pathogens and aim to lead to novel therapeutics that can target the mediators of this effect.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We have identified a novel mechanism of oncogene activation where double PIK3CA mutations in cis increase cell signaling and sensitivity to drugs that target PIK3CA, compared to single mutations. The proposed research will investigate the mechanisms of activation and regulation of double mutations, their crosstalk with the estrogen receptor in breast cancer, and modulation of new substrates in the cell. This work will unveil new mechanisms of PIK3CA function and inhibition in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Infections with the enteric bacterial pathogen Shigella are the second leading cause of diarrheal deaths globally and the emergence of antibiotic resistant Shigella strains increasingly limits our ability to treat infections. Our studies will define novel anti-Shigella human immune programs that are inhibited by virulence factors produced by Shigella. Therefore, our studies will determine whether pharmacological targeting of these Shigella virulence factors has the potential to be used as as a novel treatment option for Shigellosis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Nearly 360,000 individuals suffer an episode of sudden cardiac arrest every year in the United States. Many are Veterans given their high prevalence of risk factors for sudden cardiac arrest. Because current resuscitation techniques promote survival with good neurological function in less than 10%, there is a pressing need for new interventions. We plan to examine in a clinically relevant swine model whether drugs known as gliflozins given during cardiac arrest could reduce damage to the heart and brain leading to improved survival with good neuro- logical function. Gliflozins were initially developed for type 2 diabetes mellitus but recently shown effective for heart failure. We found in our research laboratory that administration of empagliflozin attenuates cardiac injury leading to better post-resuscitation cardiac function. We herein propose to comprehensively assess in a swine model the effects of empagliflozin on initial resuscitation and survival with good neurological function. Because gliflozins are clinically available, our findings could lead to rapid clinical translation through the repurposing path.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammatory bowel disease, comprised of Crohn’s disease and Ulcerative colitis, impacts an estimated 600 per 100,000 veterans causing significant morbidity (malabsorption, bloody diarrhea, strictures, fistulas, infection, and surgical resection) as well as mortality (increased rates of colorectal cancer with decreased survival). Medical therapy has improved but relapse remains common and is not well understood. The luminal surface of the intestinal epithelium is covered with a densely-packed array of microvilli that function in nutrient absorption and host defense. Crohn’s patients have decreased levels of proteins that maintain the structural integrity of the intestinal microvilli in areas of the gut without significant inflammation. In this proposal we will perform experiments using Crohn’s patient biopsy tissue, patient-derived enteroid culture, and in vivo mouse experiments to understand how defects in microvilli contribute to Crohn’s relapse and infection.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Diabetes is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in Veterans; it remains the main cause of lower limb amputations, blindness, and kidney failure. The proposed research is relevant to Veterans health because it represents a novel approach to understanding the relationship between the gut microbiome, bile acid signaling, and type 2 diabetes. The investigators will determine whether microbial bile acid biotransformations affect blood sugars. Moreover, they will determine if the gut microbiome can be manipulated to treat type 2 diabetes. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of Veteran Affairs Office of Research and Development mission to better understand how the gut microbiome affects health and to find new treatments for type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: NARRATIVE A link between dementia and bone loss, often occurring with aging, has been suggested, although never con- clusively demonstrated. Using TREM2 mutant mice as a model of increased risk for Alzheimer's disease (AD), we will investigate the cellular and molecular mechanisms responsible for the deterioration of the skeletal system in this condition. Successful completion of these studies will widen our understanding of the cellular and molec- ular basis of the skeletal defects in mice with increased susceptibility to develop AD, and may set the basis for treatments that will improve both the cognitive and skeletal deficits in patients with AD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans, particularly the elderly, have a higher incidence of heart diseases than the general population including hardening of the valves of the heart which is a debilitating condition with no effective non-surgical treatment options. This disease involves the aortic valves becoming “bone like” and rigid which prevents the valve from opening properly and stresses the heart as it tries to pump blood out the valve. This research will study the processes underlying these changes in the heart valve and evaluate the potential efficacy of drugs as inhibitors of hardening of the valves. These drugs might have benefit to protect Veterans from developing this condition or potentially reverse the condition in Veterans with established aortic valve disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Inherited DNA mutations in the SDHA or SDHB genes can cause defects in the essential metabolic enzyme, succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) and are common in the general population (greater than 1.5% of individuals). Some of these mutations have no medical consequence, but others increase the risk of developing cancer and this risk can also be passed on to children. Individuals who have inherited harmful SDH mutations should undergo screening tests to detect any cancer at an early, curable stage. Genetic counseling and DNA testing should be done for family members of individuals who inherited a harmful mutation. Of the many thousand SDH mutations already discovered from DNA testing, less than 50 have been definitively categorized as harmful or having no medical consequences. We will test SDHA or SDHB mutations to determine which increase the risk of cancer. These results will inform the counseling and medical care of the more than 300,000 US Veterans estimated to have inherited an SDHA or SDHB gene mutation.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Obesity is prevalent among US military veterans and linked to an increased incidence of cardiovascular disease, diabetes, pulmonary disorders and certain forms of cancer. As the veteran population ages, diminished produc- tion of the primary sex hormone, estrogen, promote fat accumulation in menopausal women. We discovered a subpopulation of adipocytes in humans and mice termed bone marrow-derived adipocytes (BMDAs) that exhibit an inflammatory character. These unique adipocytes are more abundant in female than male mice, and are increased by loss of estrogen in female mice. These observations led us to hypothesize that BMDAs provide a link between sex hormone-related changes in adiposity and body-wide inflammation. This project will test this hypothesis in mice in which estrogen signaling is suppressed, and in which BMDAs and their progenitors are specifically ablated. Understanding the mechanisms by which sex hormones regulate BMDA and progenitor production holds the potential for therapies to prevent menopausal diseases in aging female veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA NORTH TEXAS HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myocardial infarction is the major cause of heart failure that is projected to increase 46% by the year of 2030. My proposed studies aim to understand how macrophages, the key immune cells recruited to carry out tissue repair after ischemic injury, control this crucial process through sensing and responding to DNA presented in the cytosol. My studies will also delineate if two immune modulators that have the potential to disrupt the DNA sensing and responding and are readily available clinically, modulate the behavior of macrophages and promote repair. This research will have the potential to reveal novel therapeutic targets to limit remodeling and heart failure after myocardial infarction.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: G V SONNY MONTGOMERY VA MEDCIAL CENTER
PHR: With aging along with prevalent risk factors such as diabetes, COPD, obesity, hypertension, and heart failure. While we have made great advances in the drugs and devices available to treat heart failure in adults, they do not work in elderly patients with this condition. The research proposed in this application will attempt to fill this critical gap by studying age-related impairment in the adaptive response that occurs during heart failure. The proposed research will highlight new therapeutic targets and further our understanding about how alterations in glucose and fatty acid metabolism occurred with aging in a preclinical model of heart failure. The outcome of the studies could provide a basis for improving contractile function and have a major impact on symptoms, disability, and survival of Veterans with heart failure.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: As Veterans age, they can lose the ability to perform activities of daily living because they are susceptible to poor or inadequate repair of musculoskeletal tissues such as muscle, ligaments, and bone. A major contributor to this poor repair is a severe, traumatic injury that affects multiple limbs. Despite known consequences of compromised healing of musculoskeletal tissues, a pre-clinical model of polytrauma has not been validated to recapitulate the multiple factors limiting activities of daily living, namely delayed fracture healing, soft tissue fibrosis and calcification, bone weakness, metabolic dysfunction, and cognitive impairment. If successful, this project will validate such a murine model that combines skin burn injury, soft tissue injury of the lower hindlimb, and a fracture of one femur midshaft to produce a hyper-inflammatory response. All injuries are well controlled favoring reproducibility. If validated, the mouse model can be used to study mechanisms by which severe injury causes common clinical complications among Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: L-type calcium channel (Cav1.3) contributes to cardiac function and contractility. Cav1.3 is normally absent in the healthy adult ventricles but recently our group demonstrated that Cav1.3 gene is re-expressed in the ventricles of patients with heart failure. Preliminary studies from our laboratory demonstrated that Cav1.3 is truncated at its C-terminus portion which moves to the nucleus and causes an increase in its own gene expression thereby allowing more calcium entry into the heart. In this research, we aim at leveraging this C-terminus mobile property to enhance cardiac function and improve heart contractility in heart failure. The findings from this work will have important therapeutic implications for Veterans suffering from heart failure.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This work will benefit both Veterans and civilians who have osteoarthritis (OA), by identifying novel approaches to target the control of inflammation and pain. The number of patients in the US estimated to have symptomatic osteoarthritis approaches 27 million. Incidence rate is 26% higher than the general population in active duty service members 20-24 years old, and >100% higher for those >40 years old, largely due to increased incidence of acute and chronic joint injury in the military. This project will identify a novel method of treatment to inhibit inflammation and chronic pain that results from arthritis development after joint injury. Expanding medical approaches for OA will improve quality of life, enhance rehabilitative efforts, and diminish the need for joint replacement in Veterans.

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health as triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is very progressive and lacks molecular targets for therapeutic intervention. By demonstrating the role of p38 in TNBC oncogenesis and the therapeutic target activity of the p38-activated metabolic pathways, the proposed research will contribute significantly to improve health care of TNBC patients and female Veterans.

PHR: Project Narrative Fatty liver disease (FLD) is a burgeoning health problem with few therapeutic options. We have used human genetics to identify genetic variants in a gene called PNPLA3. One variant confers increased susceptibility and the other increased resistance to FLD. In this application we will build on these discoveries to glean new insights into the pathogenesis of FLD with a goal of developing new strategies and targets for the treatment of chronic liver disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiac fibrosis is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, affecting almost all forms of cardiovascular disease, but no effective therapies are currently available. This study will investigate the molecular mechanisms that regulate the long-term fate and persistence of myofibroblasts, the key driver and mediator of fibrosis. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Neural stem cells (NSCs) hold promise for the treatment of neurological disorders common to our Veteran population such as traumatic brain injury and Parkinson’s disease. Understanding the molecular mechanisms by which NSCs differentiate into specific types of neurons and glia is key to unlocking their therapeutic potential. Our overall goal is to determine the molecular mechanisms that regulate NSC biology. For NSCs to make neurons, daughter cells need to express certain sets of genes while repressing others. Such lineage- specific gene expression is in part regulated by chromatin structure – the “packaged” state of DNA. We plan to use cell biology and molecular approaches to investigate how a specific chromatin regulator called MLL1 coordinates the production of specific types of neurons from NSCs.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Diarrhea in IBD is the result of impaired fluid and electroneutral NaCl absorption and remains a major health challenge to our veteran patient population. Dysregulation of DRA, the predominant protein involved in Cl- absorption, has been implicated in the pathophysiology of IBD-associated diarrhea. Therefore, increase in DRA expression and function is essential for enhancing Cl- absorption and exerting antidiarrheal effects. Of note, DRA also plays a key role in maintenance of epithelial barrier integrity. In this regard, glucocorticoids (GC), the first line therapeutics in IBD, are known to exert anti-inflammatory, barrier protective and proabsorptive effects. Our proposed studies are aimed at elucidating the molecular mechanisms involved in a novel finding of GC-mediated upregulation of DRA function and expression in physiological and inflammatory states. Outcome of these studies should establish that GC-mediated increase in DRA expression can alleviate the IBD associated diarrhea and barrier dysfunction.

PHR: Project Narrative  Our knowledge about the mechanisms controlling the progression from benign lymphatic malformation (LM) to the highly malignant lymphangiosarcoma (LAS) is very limited, and LAS remains as a deadly disease with no effective treatment at present. The characterization of both positive and negative signaling pathways and cellular processes that regulate LM progression to LAS will significantly advance our fundamental knowledge of the disease process and contribute to novel therapies for the prevention and treatment of LAS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Engineered nanoparticles, including multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs), have numerous applications in industry and consumer products, yet pose potential human health risks upon inhalation exposure; of particular relevance to public health are our recent studies in rodents that show severe exacerbation of allergen-induced lung inflammation and fibrosis by MWCNTs. The goal of our proposed research project is to explore basic mechanisms through which MWCNTs interact with common allergens to produce chronic airway disease in mice and further elucidate mechanisms using cultured human and mouse pulmonary cells. The results of these studies will benefit public heath by identifying basic mechanisms through which nanoparticles cause human respiratory disease and discovering molecular targets that could be exploited for therapeutic treatment of chronic airway disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: The application will fill a critical knowledge gap in our understanding of RAS family GTPases which play a central role in many aspects of biology including growth, differentiation, and development. The medical importance of RAS is highlighted by its frequent mutational activation in ~30% of human cancers with pancreatic cancers harboring RAS mutations in >90% of tumors. We have discovered a paradigm shifting approach to therapeutically inhibit RAS signaling and oncogenic transformation through targeting nucleotide- free RAS (apoRAS). Completion of these studies will provide fundamental support for development of therapeutics targeting apoRAS. Thus, this work has tremendous translational significance and relevance for Veterans who are disproportionately impacted by RAS-mutant cancers. We anticipate that these studies will lead to the future development of small molecules RAS inhibitors that specifically target apoRAS.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Six million people in the US have heart failure and 550,000 new cases are diagnosed annually. Despite current optimal therapy, there are 300,000 deaths every year in the US due to heart failure. Among these 6 million patients, 3 million have heart failure with normal ejection fraction, a measure of the heart’s ability to pump blood. However, conventional therapies, which have been shown to reduce mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, fail to reduce mortality in patients with heart failure with normal ejection fraction. Because the prevalence of heart failure with normal ejection fraction is increasing, and outlook is dismal, we need new treatments. We propose, based on studies performed in the previous tenure of our VA Merit award, that intravenous delivery of a virus vector encoding the protein urocortin 2 is a promising approach for these patients. The proposed work will test this in rat and mouse models of heart failure with normal ejectionfraction, determine mechanisms, and test related proteins such as urocortin 3.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans have a high incidence of progression of heart failure requiring heart transplantation. Unfortunately, this life-saving treatment is not offered to all patients with end-stage heart failure due to limited heart donors. Up to 20% of veterans with end-stage heart failure die awaiting transplantation. An alternative source of organs already used for liver and kidney transplants are hearts from donors who have suffered circulatory death. These organs are currently used in experimental setup only due to the ischemic damage caused by the circulatory death process. We learned that mitochondrial permeability transition pore opening, and protease activation are principle mechanisms responsible for damage to the circulatory death heart. Our proposal will explore and harness novel pharmacologic mechanisms targeted at preventing mitochondrial permeability transition pore opening and proteases activation to rehabilitate circulatory death hearts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: As conventional tissue-based biomarkers are limited by availability, safety, and patient considerations, and most current blood-based biomarkers do not accurately assess tumor or immune microenvironment status, there is an urgent need to develop new biomarkers that not only aid in the choice, but also predict response to immunotherapy and other anti-cancer treatments. Recent studies suggest that cytotoxic T and natural killer cells isolated from peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs), may, if processed appropriately, provide a blood- based biomarker that could substitute for a routine biopsy and more closely reflect both the systemic and tumor immune response. The purpose of this proposal is to optimize the processing of these easily attainable blood samples and demonstrate that under these optimal conditions, they can be utilized as biomarkers and improve patient-specific treatment choices by predicting outcomes as a surrogate to, as well as complement, the standard tissue biopsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) is the most prevalent psychiatric disorder, and a novel gene associated with ADHD is Latrophilin-3, however if environmental factors, such as pyrethroid exposure, interact with genetic factors to exacerbate this disorder is unknown. We developed a knock-out rat of Lphn3 that has abnormalities similar to ADHD (hyperactivity). We will test the combined effects of pyrethroids and Lphn3 knock-outs or heterozygous rats at different ages to elucidate whether this class of insecticides triggers or exacerbates ADHD-like effects in this model system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Design of genetically encoded sensors for detecting endogenous opioid peptides Endogenous opioid signaling is highly complex and plays a role in pain reduction, euphoria, respiration, alcohol abuse, depression and stress response. It is critical to study when and where the endogenous opioid peptides are released at high spatiotemporal resolution to understand the endogenous opioid sig- naling. We propose to design two classes of opioid sensors for mapping and monitoring endogenous opioid peptide release, which will significantly advance the field and facilitate the design of pain medications with minimum side effects.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Potential Impact on Veterans Health Care: Obesity and aging are a major drivers of progressive diseases, including type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, cancers, and degenerative disorders. The adult obesity rate in the USA is 39%, and an additional 32% are overweight, with an annual cost of $147 billion in the USA. In comparison, in veterans, the prevalence of obesity and overweight is 41% and 37%, respectively. At the same time, the median age of the veteran population (65 years) was higher than nonveterans (42 years), and the percentage of veterans aged 65 or older is projected to reach 50% of the total veteran population over the next 25 years. Both ageing and obesity are associated with dysfunction of the fat tissue, promoting increasing risk of developing diabetes. These studies will seek to understand how the hormone relaxin controls fat tissue health, and how it can be used to treat dysfunction caused by obesity and aging. Successful completion of the proposed research is expected to have a positive impact for veteran health care, a major part of the VA Mission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than 80% of patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) are obese and obesity is considered a primary comorbidity in HFpEF, yet, the role of obesity in provoking symptoms of dyspnea on exertion (DOE) and exercise intolerance in HFpEF patients has, thus far, been neglected. Obesity-related mechanical ventilatory constraints ultimately 1) increase the oxygen (O2) cost of breathing and 2) impose a mechanical ceiling on ventilation (V̇E) during exercise, which could provoke DOE and reduce exercise capacity. The overall aim of this K99/R00 proposal is to 1) investigate the O2 cost of breathing and examine how this impacts DOE and peak exercise capacity in patients with HFpEF, and 2) reduce obesity-related mechanical ventilatory constraints to potentially reduce DOE and increase exercise capacity in patients with HFpEF.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hospitalization and the associated muscle loss with bedrest accelerate progression to disability in older Veterans. This proposal uses the rat hindlimb unloading model to determine if chronic mTOR activity impairs the recovery of muscle after disuse. It is expected that completion of this study will identify mechanisms and a new approach to minimize the loss of muscle mass/function in older Veterans during critical periods of disuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Today, persons living with HIV (PLWH) are faced with an increased burden of chronic respiratory disease, out of proportion to what would be expected by traditional risk factors. There remains a critical need to understand the drivers of the accelerated lung function decline and disease development in PLWH, including the potential role of the environment. This proposal examines the contribution of long-term air pollution exposure to accelerated lung aging and disease development among PLWH and whether HIV increases susceptibility to pollution exposure, in hopes of identifying a modifiable risk factor that can be targeted to improve lung health in this vulnerable population.

PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this training program is to train science and engineering students in the fundamental principles underlying molecular machines, the enzymes, motors, switches, and pumps that power cell function. Students will be trained in structural biology, single-molecule biophysics, and computation, and additionally will learn how to create 3D molecular simulations. Trainees will be prepared for careers in interdisciplinary molecular biophysics research, industries such as pharmaceuticals or biomedical devices, teaching, or science policy positions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pulmonary vascular disease commonly occurs in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and despite the increased morbidity associated with severe pulmonary vascular disease, there is limited understanding of the clinical implications of less severe pulmonary vascular disease. Understanding the contribution of early pulmonary vascular disease to COPD morbidity will define opportunities for targeted interventions of the pulmonary vasculature that could improve outcomes in COPD patients. As a necessary first step, this proposal will address key limitations in characterizing less severe PVD with multi-modal noninvasive approaches and apply these approaches to evaluate the contribution of pulmonary vascular disease to COPD morbidity across its observed spectrum of severity.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative One of the leading causes of death and disability within the VA health care system is when the heart cannot properly fill and eject blood; heart failure. One common cause of heart failure is that associated with high blood pressure, even when the blood pressure is controlled by medicine. This project will identify how we can better predict and understand this form of heart failure and most importantly identify new strategies for treating and potentially reversing this disease process. These results will set the stage for an entirely new treatment approach for VA patients suffering from this form of heart failure.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The global focus on women and key populations has curbed HIV related adverse outcomes for these groups, but men in high disease burden locations continue to remain at high risk of HIV acquisition and onward transmission. Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) research and interventions have prioritized women and key populations, with notable reductions in HIV acquisition in PrEP users. This study addresses a key gap in HIV prevention for men by assessing 1) factors associated with PrEP uptake, 2) factors associated with sustained PrEP use and attrition, 3) and using behavioral economics to design and prototype an HIV prevention intervention for South African males 15-49 years old in high disease burden communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The ability to smell is necessary for long-term physical and behavioral health in humans. Epidemiological studies suggest that older adults with impaired olfactory perception have a 4-fold increase in mortality within 5 years, and an increasing number of studies detect significant correlation between olfactory deficits and the future onset of neurodegenerative disorders, including Alzheimer’s. The proposed research is motivated not only by the desire to solve a fascinating molecular mystery that constitutes the keystone of olfaction, but also by the need to obtain insight to a sensory modality critical for human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Surgically created arteriovenous fistulas (AVF) are the preferred approach to create a vascular access for hemodialysis in chronic kidney disease patients. However, AVFs fail at a high rate, thus imposing a huge burden on both the healthcare system and patients. This proposal investigates the cellular and molecular basis for AVF failure thereby providing knowledge that can be used to design future, rationally targeted therapies to enhance the success rate of this life-saving procedure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Caregiver Oncology Needs Evaluation Tool (CONNECT) empowers and educates caregivers about the benefits of supportive care services and systematically identifies unmet needs to connect lung cancer caregivers with a tailored list of supportive care resources. The intervention offers a scalable approach to reach a large number of lung caregivers, including vulnerable caregivers with barriers to in-person participation. Use of the NCI Community Oncology Research Program (NCORP) to plan for and pilot test this intervention will support future trial efficiency and yield findings generalizable to diverse caregivers, patients, and community oncology settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The initiation of DNA replication is central to cell proliferation and survival. Initiation pathways should be  susceptible to therapeutic intervention against bacterial infections and cancers; however, limitations in our  understanding of basic initiation mechanisms impede this goal. The proposed work will provide key  molecular models for understanding initiation proteins and activities and will establish new assays and  approaches for accelerating antibacterial discovery through efforts that target these factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have identified the first protective maternal genetic effect in palatogenesis. The proposed studies will determine whether the protective effect is due to changes in the maternal uterine environment and identify the underlying epigenetic or proteomic differences. Our long-term goal is to build upon these findings and identify therapeutic strategies to monitor or even improve the maternal environment to reduce the incidence of birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) Cell invasion through basement membrane barriers is crucial for tissue formation during development and immune cell trafficking to reach sites of infection. Cell invasion is also inappropriately co-opted in many human diseases including immune disorders and cancer. The proposed work will reveal how invasive cells acquire and use energy, build invasive structures, and withstand the stress of breaching basement membranes, which will advance our understanding of the mechanisms underlying cell invasion and generate new therapeutic strategies to modulate this behavior in developmental disorders and other human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Approximately 15% of patients with ulcerative colitis (UC) develop medically refractory disease or colorectal neoplasia requiring special surgery called IPAA to remove the diseased large intestine and to restore partial bowel function. An inflammatory disease, termed pouchitis, is a common and inadequately treated complication of IPAA. The proposed project is poised to provide novel insights into the role of intestinal mucin-type O-glycans in intestinal mucus barrier function and in pathogenesis of the common human disease, which may lead to a novel therapy for patients with UC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Legionella are facultative, intracellular bacteria residing in aquatic environments from which contaminated inhaled aerosols cause accidental infections leading to an increasing incidence of Legionnaires’ disease in the United States. Here, we hypothesize a critical role of the immune-modulatory cytokine, IL-27, signaling via its IL-27RA receptor for the immune pathogenesis of Legionellosis. The proposed studies aim for new insights into the molecular pathways of IL-27 production in infected macrophages and the lymphocyte-type specific activities of IL27RA to establish a solid knowledge basis for targeted therapies in future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a fatal blood cancer with heterogeneous underlying genetics that can be treated, albeit with variable success, using either intensive chemotherapy, for those patients able to tolerate it, or less intensive regimens in combination with oral agents that trigger cell death in leukemic cells. We have adopted a functional test capable of measuring the intrinsic potential for a particular AML cell to undergo cell death, which we hypothesize will predict treatment response to cell death-inducing agents and thus identify patients most likely to benefit from a specific treatment. The proposed research will also seek to distinguish mutations present in poor-risk TP53-mutant AML as bystander mutations or drivers of AML disease progression which mediate resistance to standard therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite outbreaks of COVID-19 among Black and/or Latinx migrant and seasonal farmworkers (MSFWs), few studies have comprehensively evaluated these disparities through the lens of structural racism (SR) which is defined as the macro level systems, social forces, institutions, ideologies, and processes that interact with one another to generate and reinforce inequities among racial/ethnic groups. Our study will be the first to combine environmental health science, community-based system dynamics (CBSD) theory, statistical analysis and public health approaches with legal analysis to unpack the mechanisms through which SR shapes COVID-19 trends among Black and/or Latinx MSFWs. Our proposed study will inform the design of policies and best practices to counter long-standing mechanisms of SR impacting MSFWs, optimize living and working conditions for better health protections and to control future outbreaks of infectious disease among these invisible and vulnerable workers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In patients with non-small cell lung cancer, combination treatment with chemotherapy and T cell checkpoint inhibition is more efficacious than chemotherapy alone, so it has recently become the standard of care. Despite increasing enthusiasm for this combination treatment, the reasons for its combinatorial efficacy remain unclear. We seek to understand these reasons by investigating treatment-induced mediators of inflammation which, if identified, would allow for rationally designed combinations and inform further drug discovery efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Diseases of the endocrine system constitute major public health problems in the US and worldwide. The objective of this Training Program is to prepare physician scientists to pursue research careers addressing mechanisms and treatment of human disease with focus on the endocrine system. Trainees from this Program will identify disease mechanisms, and develop and implement new effective treatments, whose applications will improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Tooth loss is one of the most common organ failures. However, our current understanding of the initiation stages of tooth development is limited. The overall objective of this proposal is to dissect the molecular and cellular mechanisms of tooth initiation, particularly the core transcriptional regulatory networks that drive specification of dental lamina, versus other epithelial fates, within the maxillary and mandibular ectoderm. The long-term goal is to apply the mechanisms uncovered for regenerative therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Replacement flame retardants are under consideration for regulation by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA). They are ubiquitous in the indoor environment which is a major determinant for respiratory conditions ranging from respiratory infections to asthma, the most common chronic disease in children. Therefore, it is of public health importance to determine the association of these chemicals with adverse respiratory outcomes in order to inform preventive measures aimed at reducing respiratory disease burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: A common feature of heart failure is fatty acid (FA) oxidation inhibition and boosting FA oxidation is beneficial in animal models of heart failure; however, the mechanisms that suppress FA oxidation remain unclear. In this proposal, I uncover an unappreciated role for peroxisomes, an essential organelle for FA oxidation, in ischemic heart failure and define the mechanism by which ischemia promotes peroxisome loss. These studies provide important insight into metabolic remodeling in heart failure and will help develop a novel therapeutic strategy in this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Trypanosomatid parasites infect 18-20 million people world-wide and are responsible for devastating diseases, yet drug therapies remain inadequate. Polyamine biosynthesis is a proven drug target for the treatment of Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT), and the finding of both novel polyamine metabolites and regulatory mechanisms suggest that additional therapeutic targets may be found that could be effective against all three pathogenic trypanosomatids. We propose to continue our long-standing efforts to understand the metabolism and regulation of this pathway using the causative agent of HAT, Trypanosoma brucei, as a model to uncover novel trypanosomatid biology that might be exploited for drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autophagy, literally meaning self-eating, is a cell renewal process that is implicated in many human diseases. Autophagy is recognized to recycle cellular components in the cytoplasm, but my study suggests that it also recycles constituents from the nucleus. I aim to study this new perspective of autophagy, and hypothesize that this nuclear role of autophagy helps cells to resolve adverse conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Our proposed study will obtain empirical evidence to demonstrate synergistic involvement of HIV-1 and morphine in altered pre-mRNA splicing of OPRM1 (the -opioid receptor) leading to preferential expression of MOR-1X isoform with implications for enhanced opioid dependence observed in people with HIV (PWH). In addition, it will provide essential understanding of the mechanisms underlying alternative splicing of OPRM1 and unique cellular pathways associated with MOR-1X -mediated intracellular signaling. Our proposed studies will also develop strategies to reverse morphine and HIV-1 -induced missplicing of OPRM1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is usually characterized by inactivation of the von Hippel Lindau (vHL) tumor suppressor protein, promoting accumulation of Hypoxia Inducible Factor (HIF) and consequent development of extensive vasculature, which is typically immature, lacks pericyte support, and exhibits increased permeability providing a selective therapeutic target. Vascular disrupting agents (VDAs) promise unique cancer therapy by selectively targeting these tumor-associated blood vessels, leading to rapid destruction and necrosis, and we have identified a promising new molecule, OXi8007, structurally inspired by lead VDAs (currently in clinical trials), which provides superior vessel destruction and prolonged efficacy. In combination with a new chemotherapy strategy targeting HIF-2, the recently approved thymidine kinase inhibitor cabozantinib, and potent immune checkpoint inhibitors, our studies will demonstrate enhanced therapeutic efficacy against kidney cancer to generate a translational foundation towards human applications in cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Children requiring inpatient rehabilitation treatment following acquired brain injury (ABI) are at risk for poor engagement in rehabilitative therapies. We will use a within subject, crossover design to determine whether involving dogs in physical and occupational therapies while receiving inpatient rehabilitation improves patient engagement, how involving dogs improves engagement, and identify who is most likely to benefit. This project addresses the critical need to establish an evidence base for animal-assisted therapies in pediatric rehabilitation, incorporates innovative methods, and has the potential to lead to improved clinical care for children and adolescents receiving intensive rehabilitation following ABI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Recent findings suggest that air pollution exposure during prenatal and childhood development may be a neurotoxicant; yet questions remain as to when and how the timing of exposure impacts changes in brain structure and function across diverse populations of children. The proposed study aims to determine whether long-term and/or specific periods of exposure to air pollution, with a primary focus on fine particle matter (PM2.5), alters neurocognitive abilities of executive functions, emotional behaviors, and brain development in a large, representative nationwide cohort of youth between the ages of 9 to 12 years-old. This study has the potential to improve prevention and intervention programs to reduce cognitive and emotional problems that may otherwise persist into adult life, and its findings of how air pollution impacts brain-behavior development is important to policy markers charged with regulating air quality in urban cities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Pediatric cancer is the second leading cause of death in children, and genetic studies to inform new drug therapies have been challenging. The proposal will utilize deep learning bioinformatics methods to transfer well-established pharmacogenomics knowledge for adult cancers to the study of pediatric cancers. The findings will facilitate the optimal usage of existing drugs and the development of novel therapies for pediatric cancer, and will facilitate the candidate’s transition to an independent research career as an expert in this area.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The proposed summer undergraduate research fellowship in the molecular biology and genomics of human cancer will offer students the opportunity to contribute to real research progress in understanding the origin, background, and treatment of gliomas, glioblastomas, leukemia, breast, bone, and ovarian cancers in the highly collaborative environment of The Jackson Laboratory for Genomic Medicine (JAX-GM). The 10-week experience will actively recruit students underrepresented in science and help plant the seeds for future diversity in the scientific, medical, and education workforces. Program alumni will be science ambassadors with a solid grounding in ethics, an appreciation for the challenges and promises of human disease research, and a zeal to share their love of science for the benefit of society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Cryo-electron tomography (cryo-ET) is an emerging imaging technique capable of elucidating the structure of proteins and protein-complexes of broad biomedical interest within the context of the cell. The development of computational methods to improve the resolution of structures determined by cryo-ET and sub-volume averaging will turn this technology into a powerful tool for studying important biomolecules in-situ. Our methods will contribute to broadening adoption of cryo-ET by adjacent disciplines in modern biology, accelerating biomedical research and providing more opportunities for the development of new medical treatments to combat disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narratives  This project aims to investigate the impact of early life antibody response to a broad array of pathogenic and commensal microbes and early life exposure to multiple environmental pollutants on future risk of allergic diseases. This longitudinal birth cohort study allows us to examine the temporal, dose-response, and synergistic effects of these early life factors on the development and prognosis of allergic diseases, including food allergy and asthma, from birth up to age 18 years. New knowledge gained will inform the development of novel strategies for early prediction and prevention of allergic diseases and will provide needed evidence to inform environmental standards and regulations as well as interventions to protect mothers and children from harmful environmental pollutants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Tobacco-derived carcinogens can cause gain-in-function mutations in RAS genes encoding for RAS proteins that constitutively activate cellular processes responsible for multiple aspects of tumorigenesis. Because RAS is mutated during early stages of lung cancer and a well-validated, high-value, yet elusive, cancer target, we seek to further study and develop a novel class of RAS inhibitors for lung cancer chemoprevention or early treatment that has ultra-high potency and selectivity for killing lung cancer cells with mutant RAS. The proposed research will precisely define the mechanism of action, optimize oral delivery by further synthetic chemistry of analogs and prodrugs, and evaluate antitumor efficacy in mouse models of lung cancer in a comprehensive manner; all with the goals of identifying a drug development candidate for IND-enabling safety assessment and to gain insight into potential biomarkers needed to conduct clinical chemoprevention trials of individuals at risk of developing lung cancer or malignant progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome) is an acute, inflammatory lung disease which afflicts 190,000 Americans annually, but has no drug therapy after dozens of failed trials. To overcome these failures, we will develop a new nanotechnology, in which we package multiple drugs into 100-nanometer drug carriers that are targeted to the key cells of the alveoli (air sacs) of the lungs: endothelial cells and neutrophils. Using these targeted nanocarriers (NCs), we will answer fundamental questions in pharmacology and ARDS biology, while at the same time finding the optimal combination of cargo drugs in our NCs to create a novel therapy for ARDS.

PHR: Project Narrative Cross-sectional methods for identifying new infections and targeting interventions is critical, as the traditional longitudinal studies are costly. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Sepsis is commonly encountered and a leading cause of in-hospital mortality. Yet, there are no specific approved therapeutic agents for sepsis. The goal of this project is to identify biologically discrete subgroups in sepsis that may differentially respond to therapies. Through a deeper understanding of these subgroups, we hope to improve patient outcomes by matching appropriate therapies to individual patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A class of drugs called the `anti-cancer sulfonamides' were recently discovered to work by targeting and destroying a key cellular protein called RBM39. We have recently shown that a form of blood cancer known as acute myeloid leukemia (AML), which have mutations of genes involved in RNA splicing, are particularly sensitive to these drugs; we now seek to understand more about the function of RBM39 in the normal body (including normal blood production) as well as its function in the development of blood cancers. We hope that this research will both help us understand more about how blood cancers develop, and to more intelligently optimize the anti-cancer sulfonamides to minimize side-effects from destroying RBM39 in non-cancerous cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Environmental exposure to inorganic arsenic (iAs) is associated with risk of cancer and other deadly diseases. Laboratory mice detoxify iAs more efficiently than humans, which makes it difficult to study iAs associated diseases in laboratory settings. The goals of this project are (a) to characterize adverse effects of iAs exposure in a recently established humanized mouse strain and (b) to generate and characterize a new mouse strain, in which the role of genetic polymorphisms linked to risk of iAs-associated diseases can be studied.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative This project will use state-of-the-art neuroimaging tools and behavioral assessments to understand the neural signatures of attention in young children with and without prenatal alcohol exposure. The long-term goal of the project is to identify a neurophysiological marker of attention deficits to facilitate early intervention for children with prenatal alcohol exposure (PAE) as well as children with attention deficits from other causes. This study addresses the needs of children with attention deficits and their families and the NIAAA Strategic Plan calling for early identification of PAE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anti-cancer therapeutics targeting the adaptive immune response, including checkpoint blockade, have been a boon for a subset of patients and are being combined with chemotherapy to further improve outcomes. We have identified an innate immune checkpoint utilized by tumor cells to suppress the anti-tumor response during chemotherapy and, based on our mechanistic understanding, have discovered a combination therapy (PTP1b inhibition/chemotherapy) that improves survival in multiple preclinical models. We propose to 1) determine whether this immune suppressive mechanism is predictive of patient response to chemotherapy, 2) identify which chemotherapies yield the most robust response in conjunction with PTP1b inhibition and 3) understand how our therapeutic affects the adaptive immune response and responsiveness to checkpoint blockade.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suboptimal linkage to and retention in HIV prevention and care is prevalent among high risk women who use or inject drugs in both the US and globally, including high HIV incidence contexts like Kazakhstan; addressing HIV and intersectional stigma, especially from health care providers (HCP) within clinics, is necessary to increase engagement in the HIV care and prevention continuum. To address this challenge and increase HIV prevention and care, the proposed study will involve the design and assessment of the acceptability, feasibility, and usability of a three component, multi-level participatory intervention to promote stigma resistance/coping and reduce anticipated/internalized stigma among high risk women who use drugs as well as to reduce enacted stigma among HCP in Kazakhstan, Central Asia. Results of this study will generate information in order to power a future preliminary effectiveness trial and will be unique in utilizing multilevel anti-stigma approaches for both high risk women who use drugs and HCP, all of which will have important implications for advancing HIV prevention and care engagement among highly stigmatized populations in diverse settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative One in three youth in the United States are overweight, and nearly 85% of overweight youth have at least one  Metabolic Syndrome (MetS) risk factor that is affected by their school physical activity and food environments,  as well as their engagement in physical activity and healthy eating behaviors. Strong Teens for Healthy Schools  Change Club (STHS-CC) is a multi-level, theory-based civic engagement program that equips and supports  middle school students in racially/ethnically diverse, Title 1 middle schools to make a positive food and  physical activity environmental change and personally engage in physical activity and healthy eating behaviors  to reduce their MetS risk. Working in partnership with Cooperative Extension and 4-H staff, school educators,  and middle school students, we will refine the STHS-CC curriculum for delivery and use a cluster randomized  controlled trial to evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention for improving individual (i.e., MetS risk,  positive youth development), social (i.e. peer support and engagement in health behaviors), and environmental  (i.e., school physical activity and nutrition environments) outcomes, as compared to students in the control  condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Since the introduction of sepsis bundles, there have been multiple published trials that have demonstrated a consistent, strong association between implementation of sepsis “bundles” (3- hour bundle) and improved survival. The current proposal is a Hybrid 2, pragmatic, cluster randomized clinical effectiveness/implementation trial evaluating mortality and respiratory failure-based outcomes, in patients admitted to the emergency department with sepsis, comparing the effectiveness of implementation of the hour-1 bundle to 3-hour bundle, while facilitatingadherence to both bundles. In addition, 4 distinct sepsis phenotypes will be derived from routine clinical data to identify specific patient phenotypes that allow for a more precision-based application of sepsis bundles in future studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure (HF) afflicts 6.5 million US adults and is associated with significant morbidity, mortality (50% at five years of diagnosis), and expense for healthcare systems worldwide. Recovery of cardiac function has been reported in ~15% of patients with end-stage HF. Understanding the factors and mechanisms associated with cardiac recovery could lead to the development of novel personalized therapies to improve outcomes in the broad HF population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  Access to social interaction has protective and restorative effects in animal models of opioid craving. By using a novel rat model of choice between social interaction and heroin in combination with cutting-edge molecular approaches, this proposal will determine the genomic network mediating the protective effect of social interaction on heroin craving. We anticipate our results to have a translational impact by identifying distinct genetical markers that may inspire clinical studies to determine whether social-based behavioral treatments would restore physiological circuitry function, resulting in reduced long-term relapse risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bronchopulmonary dysplasia, a devastating chronic lung disease with debilitating long-term consequences, affects approximately half of all infants born extremely preterm. The objectives of this proposal are relevant to public health because they aim to establish that bacterial communities in the gut influence development of bronchopulmonary dysplasia by altering the immune responses of the developing lung. Successful completion of this proposal will provide insight into extra-pulmonary contributions to lung development and characterize new targets for therapy, which addresses goals of the NIH to seek mechanistic understanding of the microbiome in the pathobiology of lung diseases and reduce the incidence of chronic lung disease during early life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will pair the NIH-funded AAV BRAIN Safe and Effective Neuromodulator and Sensor Utilization across Species (SENSUS, led by Caltech) with California State Polytechnic University, Pomona (CPP) to build a new Armamentarium Vector Core (ArmVC), broadening the Armamentarium project’s ability to validate and disseminate the next generation of modern gene delivery tools to understand and, eventually, treat the brain. In addition, ArmVC will help to build a new, more diverse brain gene therapy workforce through the AAV BRAIN SENSUS Program for Integrated Research Experiences (ASPIRE). As ASPIRE Scientists, undergraduates from CPP—a designated Hispanic-Serving Institution that also serves a large number of Pell-eligible, first-generation, and African American students—will receive extensive training and mentoring both at Caltech and CPP while broadening novel AAV validation, production, and dissemination through ArmVC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This proposal will determine how changing mechanical load, such as occurs when the heart has to pump against a high pressure, influences structures of the heart muscle membrane called transverse tubules. These (t)-tubules are disrupted in diseases such as heart failure, but how changing the load of the heart affects them is not known. Understanding this process, and the molecules responsible, might help in discovering new treatments for heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Project Narrative A large proportion of the world’s population will experience hearing loss at some point in their lifetime, often as a result of external causes. The sensory cells of the inner ear, called hair cells, are very sensitive to damage, and in mammals, once these cells are lost, they will not regrow. In this proposal, we will use zebrafish as a model organism to define the genetic pathways that regulate sensory hair cell regeneration, with the long-term goal of providing a mechanism to regrow sensory hair cells in the human inner ear.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Racism continues to plague minority sub-groups in the United States, and race-related stress (RRS) contributes to health disparities among African Americans (AA) with alcohol use disorder (AUD); however racial identity (RI) may buffer this effect. It is crucial to understand how RRS influences alcohol use and risk for developing AUD in order to identify targets for interventions that are culturally salient for AA. Serving toward Dr. Brown’s ultimate career goal of becoming an independent investigator in the alcohol field focused on health disparities, she will address this gap in the literature by using a human laboratory paradigm and ecological momentary assessment (EMA) methods to examine the effects of RRS on reactivity to cue- induced stress and craving and the role of RI among AA with current AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Comprehensive analysis of the genomes of cancer cells is transforming our approach to the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of cancer. To date, however, the cancer genomics revolution has largely ignored tumors from patients in Africa and has not involved many African scientists. The training program in this application aims to provide graduate level training in cancer genomics and genomic data science to students in Uganda and East Africa to prepare them to bring the benefit of the cancer genomics revolution to Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Pre-analytical processing of biological samples profoundly impacts data output in research and clinical settings. And yet, the relative effects of variables associated with tissue collection, preservation, transport, storage, sampling and analytic processing on the reliability of epigenetic biomarkers in cancer studies – including the uniformly lethal brain tumor glioblastoma – have not been rigorously examined. This proposal addresses the need to define pre-analytical variables in the clinically used glioblastoma MGMT promoter methylation biomarker assay.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Men with metastatic castration sensitive prostate cancer (mCSPC) are at high risk of disease progression and while the treatments used can delay progression, they can increase the risk of metabolic side effects (diabetes and heart disease). Data from our team has shown that intermittent fasting using a fasting mimicking diet (FMD) can improve metabolic health in people and delay cancer progression in mice, including in prostate cancer models. We propose a phase 2 multisite randomized trial of intermittent fasting with a FMD vs. standard of care in men with mCSPC designed to improve cancer control and reduce risk of diabetes, while gaining insight into how insulin and IGF1 signaling are associated with the benefit of FMD in delaying prostate cancer progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will provide a strong scientific justification to develop screening and to test preventive treatment strategies for subclinical hereditary transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis (hATTR-CA) in V122I TTR carriers. Key findings from this proposal will change how we think about this disease and will justify future research towards reducing HF morbidity and mortality by way of earlier hATTR- CA recognition and earlier treatment. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to part of the NHLBI's mission to promote the prevention and treatment of heart disease.

PHR: We are proposing the development of an orally available small molecule drug that targets inflammatory cell trafficking to the gut as a safe alternative to current treatments strategies in inflammatory bowel disease that either are associated with significant safety concerns, like the development of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, or are associated with high numbers of primary and secondary non-responders to therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cell-cell interactions are crucial components of many biological processes including tumor-immune cells interactions. Although impressive progress has been made in developing single-cell analysis technology, existing techniques suffer from drawbacks in speed, resolution, biocompatibility, and automation; moreover, they cannot pair and separate cells reversibly. This project aims to develop and validate a harmonic acoustics-based microphysiological analysis platform that can perform high-throughput, high-resolution cell manipulation and perform quantitative phenotypic analyses of reversible cell-cell interactions at the single-cell level for a broad range of biomedical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE There are an estimated 2.8 million rural cancer survivors today, and they experience lower survival rates than cancer patients living in urban areas. We propose to conduct a study of rural prostate, rural breast, rural colorectal cancer patients and comparison groups of urban cancer patients in Utah and in elderly patients across the US, to investigate whether rural cancer survivors experience higher rates of adverse outcomes such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes, opioid use disorders and mental illness than urban cancer survivors. We will also assess why rural cancer survivors may experience higher adverse outcome rates, with possible reasons including differences in the cancer treatment they receive or the distance to care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ovarian cancer is responsible for more than 150,000 deaths per year and so it remains a high priority to develop effective prevention approaches and to identify new disease specific therapies to reduce disease mortality. The research proposed here has two components: (1) To characterize the genetic component in ovarian cancer development through epigenomic landscape; (2) to establish the functional relevance of genetic findings for clinical translation. This is a highly integrated multi-disciplinary research proposal, and these approaches to novel discovery and mechanistic understanding are desperately needed to advance our basic knowledge of this disease to develop clinical interventions that reduce mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a deadly disease caused by uncontrolled tissue fibrosis in the lungs. There are no FDA-approved drugs that cure or prevent disease progression. We propose to combine computational modeling with experiments study how fibroblasts and microvessel remodeling in the lung contribute to disease and to identify novel drugs and drug combinations that target these processes in order to effectively treat IPF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Increasing genetic evidence suggests that susceptibility to type 2 diabetes is linked to defects in the ability to make and store insulin. Several of the risk loci are linked to genes involved in the process generally described as “Endoplasmic Reticulum (ER) Quality Control”. This group of leading investigators are among the world’s experts in the ER quality control in insulin-producing cells, and this proposal directly relates such quality control to the pathogenesis of diabetes (as well as therapeutic approaches to ameliorate the disease).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Loss of integrity of the kidney filtration barrier results in urinary protein loss, which accounts for approximately 80% of end stage kidney disease where nearly 700,000 patients in the United States require dialysis or await kidney transplantation. Understanding the biological mechanisms are necessary to prevent the progression of chronic kidney disease. In this grant proposal, we plan to elucidate the underlying components required to maintain a normally functioning filtration barrier so that potential novel treatments can be discovered in the near future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Cancer is treated with DNA damaging chemotherapy and radiation therapy (XRT). Cancer cells are sensitive to DNA damage as they divide rapidly and have often acquired mutations in mechanisms that safeguard genome stability. Immune cells are also sensitive to DNA damage as they divide extremely rapidly (<6 h). Since cancer is treated with combinations of DNA damaging chemotherapy, XRT and immunotherapy, we investigate new approaches to separate the impact of DNA damage on cancer and anti-tumor immune cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately half of all drugs in use today come from organisms in the environment such as bacteria. However, because of issues including increasing levels of antibiotic resistance, we need new bacterial sources of these compounds to replenish the drug pipeline. This research will discover new therapeutically relevant compounds and associated biochemistry using bacteria that were missed during past drug discovery efforts due to their growth requirements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Translational dysregulation that enhances protein synthesis and oncogenic gene expression has emerged as a key process contributing to cancer evolution, including in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), the most common primary liver malignancy and a leading cause of cancer death worldwide. We have recently biochemically characterized the function of a key HCC-related gene, METTL5, as the 18S rRNA N6-methyladenosine (m6A) methyltransferase, and have shown that its loss markedly reduces cellular proliferation. Defining the role of METTL5 in regulating ribosome function and investigating the mechanism by which it supports proliferation and tumorigenesis will clarify our understanding of the link between METTL5 and HCC, providing a potential new drug target and contributing to our understanding of how rRNA modifications can dynamically regulate translational processes in relation to disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative My laboratory is built on a thorough understanding of the BCL-2 family of proteins, which regulates apoptosis, a program of cellular suicide. We have had important success in guiding small molecule inhibitors of BCL-2, an anti-apoptotic protein, into the clinic, spurring successful clinical trial programs particularly in chronic lymphocytic leukemia and acute myelogenous leukemia. We are building on this success by using dynamic BH3 profiling to identify novel drugs that selectively induce pro-apoptotic signaling in a wide range of cancer types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Esophageal adenocarcinoma is a cancer with poor outcomes when diagnosed after the onset of symptoms. It arises in a precancerous condition called Barrett’s esophagus. In this proposal, we aim to validate a non- endoscopic approach to the diagnosis of Barrett’s esophagus, dysplasia and adenocarcinoma, using a capsule sponge combined with DNA markers, to enable early diagnosis, prevention and treatment of this lethal cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Inspiratory training (IT) has demonstrated clinical benefits in numerous chronic cardiopulmonary conditions, and consistently improves breathlessness and exercise capacity. Recently studies suggest IT reduces dyspnea and respiratory symptoms in pediatric asthma. Obesity is an increasingly prevalent factor complicating pediatric asthma management. The mechanism(s) driving the clinical benefits of IT remain wholly unknown. This project leverages our group's expertise with IT and pediatrics to study the mechanisms underlying pediatric obese asthma in general and IT in particular.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Strategies to prevent opioid overdose which impact large groups of opioid users at multiple levels of influence are acutely needed. The broad objective of this K01 proposal is to investigate modifiable neighborhood factors which impact opioid misuse and mental health and which may contribute to opioid overdose using a mix of both quantitative and qualitative methods. The proposed research and training will lead to a subsequent R01 proposal that formally tests implementation strategies and effectiveness of neighborhood-level interventions for overdose prevention.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE HIV, cervical cancer and human papillomavirus (HPV) are interrelated health conditions with intersecting stigmas that may influence women’s uptake of prevention services. We will evaluate the effectiveness of a novel stigma-responsive service delivery model for HPV-based cervical cancer screening called “Elimisha HPV” among women in a high HIV-prevalence area of Kenya. If effective, this may serve as a new model for cervical cancer screening as well as a new paradigm for comprehensive, stigma-responsive service delivery packages for people living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: The research performed by students in the CMB program addresses fundamental questions about the nation’s pressing public health concerns, including prevalent chronic disorders (e.g., cancer, diabetes, heart disease), neurological conditions (e.g., Alzheimer’s, epilepsy, addiction), and infectious diseases (e.g., COVID, MRSA). Training a diverse pool of students, using evidence-based approaches that combine broad exposure and focused training of students in cellular and molecular approaches, effective mentor training, and program evaluation at multiple levels, fills a critical need for producing well-trained scientists in the biomedical workforce who work to advance fundamental knowledge in areas relevant to advancing health, reducing illness and improving the quality of human life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Alternative pre-mRNA splicing is a crucial component of establishing appropriate gene expression programs that are unique to tissues and differentiated cell types. Defects in alternative splicing are known to associate with many human diseases. In this project we will analyze the mechanisms of regulated alternative splicing using a combination of experimental and computational approaches to provide detailed molecular insights into the control of gene expression and to identify novel disease targets.

PHR: Narrative Injuries to tendons and ligaments make up almost half of all musculoskeletal injuries yet the signaling pathways that regulate tissue formation during development and following injury remain poorly understood. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: There are more than 700,000 annual acute ischemic stroke (AIS) events in the US which result in nearly 150,000 deaths, making AIS the fifth leading cause of death and the leading cause of neurological disability. Although thrombectomy is the standard of care for those diagnosed with a treatable large vessel occlusion in the anterior circulation, improvements in thrombolysis are needed given that most AIS events are not amenable to thrombectomy. UNandUP (short for “Unmet Needs and Underserved Populations”) has invented a safe and effective nanoparticle-based magnetic thrombolysis platform which can be applied to nearly all AIS victims.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The loss of skeletal muscle mass can occur through genetic or external factors such as disease, hospitalization or aging; and affects the quality of life for millions of people. In this proposal, I will be studying a novel and potentially important protein (F-box and leucine-rich repeat protein 22) involved in the development of skeletal muscle atrophy. The approach taken in this proposal has great potential for understanding the role of E3 ubiquitin ligases in the regulation of skeletal muscle mass and function and the findings may provide a basis for new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of muscle atrophy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Liver plays important roles in maintaining normal pregnancy. Pregnant women with liver diseases have increased risk for developing pregnant complications including preterm birth and stillbirth. However, our current understanding on the underlying mechanisms and treatment option are limited. This proposal is aiming at filling in those gaps to investigate the underlying mechanisms of increased pregnancy complications in pregnant women with liver diseases and develop novel mechanism-based interventions to reduce or prevent pregnancy complications in those affected populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide exacts a heavy toll among adolescents living with HIV (ALWH) in Malawi where suicide prevention efforts are lagging. This proposed study will 1) enhance the Friendship Bench (FB) depression model with a culturally-adapted Safety Planning (SP) intervention to reduce suicidal ideation and behaviors among ALWH in Malawi; 2) evaluate the implementation and preliminary effectiveness of the FB+SP model through a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT); and 3) build the capacity of researchers and policy makers to use evidence to advance decriminalization efforts. This proposal will critically advance suicide prevention in Malawi, build capacity, and generate the preliminary evidence needed to test the FB+SP model in a large-scale R01 RCT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/LAY SUMMARY This proposal examines the mechanisms of liver injury and inflammation in nonalcoholic fatty liver disease by employing models related to obesity. We propose that liver endothelial cells exposed to excess circulating toxic lipids such as saturated free fatty acids undergo structural and functional alterations that we refer to as endotheliopathy, which increases vascular resistance and enhances white blood cell infiltration into the liver, promoting portal hypertention and liver inflammation. The results of the proposal have the potential to identify new mechanisms of liver inflammation and portal hypertention in nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (the most common liver disease in children and adults), and discover new therapeutic targets for this disease.
