IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative For children with severe cerebral palsy, a powered wheelchair (PWC) may provide their only option for functional mobility and independence. PWC use is often restricted to a small percentage of children who can quickly demonstrate proficient PWC skills within a single 30- minute PWC trial. This 2-arm, parallel group, single blinded, pre-test-post-test randomized controlled trial will test our hypothesis that an 8-week PWC skills training intervention will produce greater improvements in children’s PWC skills capacity immediately after the intervention and at an 8-week follow-up assessment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Through this project, we aim to increase awareness of the importance of evidence-based decision making and enable biomedical science administrators and other stakeholders with the tools and skill sets to make program evaluation an on-going, integral component of research training programs from the beginning rather than a one-time event. Our proposed solution highlights the strength of decision-making based on systematically collected evidence that improves the quality of biomedical research training programs and therefore contributes to the development of biomedical research and global health. Our long-term goal, therefore, is to make program evaluation a seamless component of biomedical research training programs by equipping the stakeholders with skills and knowledge required for planning and conducting program evaluation through online educational modules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heavy menstrual bleeding is a frequent and life-altering problem for adolescents and young adults with heritable bleeding disorders, but this population has previously been excluded from research on treatments. In this multicenter prospective clinical trial of U.S. adolescents and young adults with heritable bleeding disorders, we aim to compare two commonly used treatments that are successful for menstrual suppression in those without heritable bleeding disorders – 52 mg levonorgestrel intrauterine device (LNG-IUD) and norethindrone acetate (NETA). Under this application we will compare the bleeding outcomes, satisfaction, hemostatic parameter changes, and patient reported quality of life measures at baseline and through 6 months of treatment and compare LNG-IUD treatment results to a control group without a bleeding disorder, with the goal of determining the benefits and expected outcomes of these treatment options for this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Summary: We have identified a discrete stage of heart valve development that is critical for aortic valve morphogenesis and have also discovered a unique cascade of endocardial signaling proteins that are essential for normal valve formation prior to birth. Our goal is to understand how these signaling cascades within the endocardium direct normal aortic valve development. As most congenital heart defects involve abnormalities of heart valve formation, these studies will lay the foundation for understanding the etiology many congenital heart diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Bipolar disorder, an often-debilitating condition associated with a high risk for suicide, is characterized by dramatic and recurrent shifts in mood, energy levels and behavior ranging from the lows of depression (lasting weeks or months) to the highs of mania (lasting at least a week). There is an urgent need for more effective treatments of the depressive phase of bipolar disorder; accordingly, this study will test whether deep brain stimulation (DBS), a neurosurgical procedure widely using in movement disorders, is effective and safe in 10 patients with bipolar depression. To reduce the risk of inducing mania, emerging signs such as decreased need for sleep, increased activity, rapid speech, and elevated mood, will be monitored using a variety of mobile monitoring methods (e.g., wearables, smart phone readouts, audio diaries, etc.) together with recording of brain activity by the DBS device.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE African Americans experience among the highest levels of tobacco-related disease and socioeconomic disadvantage; approximately 85% of African Americans who smoke use menthol, which contributes to persistent tobacco use. This study will characterize unmet social needs of African American menthol users by assessing community- and individual-level disadvantage, and will subsequently examine these key factors in relation to smoking treatment outcomes, with the goal of identifying opportunities to address needs and enhance treatment. Improving treatment for African Americans, including menthol users, is central to reducing disease burden and enhancing health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Up to 80% of the 8.5 million people diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease (PD) worldwide will develop dementia within a decade of diagnosis, yet we know little about what processes are occurring in the brain in those who develop PDD versus those who do not, and what clinical and neuroimaging measures best predict PDD. Overcoming the small samples and low power of prior studies, we launch a global initiative with unprecedented power to understand what leads to dementia in PD - what are the primary risk factors, and which kinds of neuroimaging data are most valuable to collect, and for which patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE: OVERALL CENTER AgFF industries have the highest rates of occupational fatality in the country and AgFF workers suffer from disproportionately high rates of work-related illness and injury, as well as chronic health conditions, suicide and stress. This application seeks to improve the health and welfare of AgFF populations in the Northeast by working collaboratively with AgFF partners, industries and workers to develop solutions that are effective and can be easily adopted by the workforce.

PROJECT_TITLE: Northeast Center for Occupational Health and Safety: Agriculture, Forestry and Fishing

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biliary tract inflammation contributes to the development and progression of many common human biliary and liver pathologies, but our understanding of immune processes within the biliary tract is exceedingly limited. I have characterized resident immune cell populations in the extrahepatic biliary tree at high resolution, and found that the make-up of this biliary immune niche is impacted by biliary epithelial cells and the microbiome-status of the host. This project will test how the microbiome, microbial metabolites, and biliary epithelial cells impact the biliary immune niche, and will test whether alterations in the biliary immune niche at homeostasis, specifically the presence or absence of neutrophils, impacts the progression of cholesterol gallstone disease.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a rare, rapidly progressive, and invariably fatal neurological condition characterized by autonomic failure, parkinsonism, and/or ataxia. There is no available treatment to slow or halt disease progression. Based on strong efficacy signals from a recently completed early phase study, we propose a randomized double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase II trial to assess optimal dosing frequency, efficacy and safety of adipose-derived autologous mesenchymal stem cells delivered into the spinal fluid of patients with MSA.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Randomized Double-Blind Placebo-Controlled Adaptive Design Trial of Intrathecally Administered Autologous Mesenchymal Stem Cells in Multiple System Atrophy

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biostatisticians are key contributors to cardiovascular disease research, and demand continues to escalate for PhD biostatisticians with the required training, particularly in this era of biomedical big data. This program will provide predoctoral students at North Carolina State University and Duke University with unique training that integrates rigorous study of statistical theory and methods with a collaborative apprenticeship working on cutting edge cardiovascular disease research studies in multidisciplinary teams at the Duke Clinical Research Institute to prepare them to make immediate contributions to the cardiovascular disease research enterprise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to train the next generation of clinical and translational researchers to meet the nation's health care challenges of the coming decades. We will provide training in the core knowledge expectations of clinical and translational science (CTS) to clinical and biomedical research postdoctoral fellows in the Tufts CTS Graduate Program and prepare them to be effective leaders, team members, communicators, and innovators in CTS. In addition to a general CTS track, we offer three specialized tracks: Predictive Analytics and Comparative Effectiveness Research (PACER), One Health, and Health Policy and Health Disparities (HPHD).

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will generate the most robust evidence to guide administrators about whether and how to prioritize continuity of care in ICUs to improve quality and minimize costs. We will use econometric methods (causal statistical methods), qualitative methods and optimization and simulation modeling to determine the quality and economic case for improving continuity of ICU interprofessional teams. The results will have direct impact on informing organizational approaches to human resource allocation in intensive care units in Michigan, Massachusetts and ultimately, nationally.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: A quality and cost analysis of interprofessional team continuity in ICUs

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This program trains students to address challenges in human health by applying the foundations of biology to life at a chemical and molecular level. The program brings together chemists, biologists, engineers, and physician-scientists to foster creative thinking across disciplinary lines, leading to the discovery and engineering of molecules, materials and measurement tools that advance human health. Students trained in this program will be primed to revolutionize the way medicines and medical treatments are conceived, created, and implemented.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Child maltreatment is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in the U.S. Better understanding of proximate mental and physical health predictors after childhood traumatic stressful events (TSEs), including genetic susceptibility and early biologic embedding by epigenetic age acceleration (EAA) and increased inflammation, may facilitate targeted interventions to ameliorate the long-term health burden. Using the Philadelphia Neurodevelopmental Cohort (PNC) and Center for Applied Genomics (CAG) pediatric biorepositories at The Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia, this project will test the hypothesis that childhood TSEs are associated with a spectrum of mental and physical health consequences that are influenced by genetic susceptibility and biologic embedding.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE We propose to establish a Collaborative Program involving the basic research and development of the discorhabdin class of marine iminoquinone alkaloids as highly potent and selective controls for a diversity of diseases. Due to the lack of availability of the natural products through isolation from the Arctic sponges, studies have been designed to develop innovative natural product synthesis methodologies as well as assess and develop these highly unique alkaloid natural products as potential therapeutics. Aleutianamine possesses ideal features for the development of innovative synthesis methodologies and because the molecule is small, strained and may effectively penetrate unique tissue types and serve broadly as a model for effective disease management for a variety of diseases for which viable treatment options do not currently exist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Life-threatening trauma exposures, including traumatic injuries requiring presentation to acute care medical settings, occur frequently in the US in the era of the COVID-19 pandemic, firearm proliferation, and extreme weather events, and are both a substantial source of individual suffering and a significant public health burden. The study team is proposing a randomized pragmatic trial of a brief stepped care intervention delivered from an acute care medical trauma center that may both reduce the symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder and diminish emergency department health service utilization. The study team has established a track record of using evidence derived from pragmatic trials to influence American College of Surgeons Committee on Trauma regulatory policy through end-of-study policy summits, thus enhancing the public health impact of the investigative results for US trauma care systems nationwide.

PHR: Narrative: Consumer reporting patient safety events (PSE) during transitions of care is expected to reduce the risks for poor outcomes and adverse events. We propose to address facilitators and barriers to consumer PSE reporting during care transitions, and develop a patient-oriented PSE reporting system for cancer patients to engage in medication event reporting, promoting safety and quality of care. Built upon the established feasibility of consumer reporting, this project is expected to be generalizable to all chronic conditions through enhanced self-management and engagement during transitions of care.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Patient Engagement in Reporting Medication Events during Transitions of Care

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A key goal of this project is to detect the disease module of the chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) to improve our understanding of its pathogenesis and inform therapeutic treatment. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it enables us to systematically identify disease genes associated with COPD. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission towards developing fundamental knowledge about the nature and behavior of living systems and the application of that knowledge to enhance human health and reduce illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal seeks support to develop novel data integration methods using electronic health records (EHR) from multiple CTSA hubs to create predictive models of multi-system diseases. We propose to develop the Predictive Analytics via Networked Distributed Algorithms (PANDA) framework, which will enable accurate risk prediction to help healthcare providers reach accurate diagnoses earlier.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance: Mammalian cells use biological zip codes to transport mRNAs, which encode the information for the synthesis of proteins, to specific locations in the cell, so that proteins are made in their appropriate location. This RNA localization process is critical to early development, learning and memory, and at the level of the individual cell, to the secretion of hormones and neurotransmitters as well the cell surface localization of proteins functioning in signaling and cell-cell communication. The findings from this study are expected to reveal new mechanisms of RNA localization and identify conserved pathways that may be dysregulated in diseases of development, metabolism, and ageing.

PROJECT_TITLE: Mechanisms of RNA localization and translational regulation on the endoplasmic reticulum

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common and also the most lethal type of the malignant urological tumors and has been increasing continuously for unknown reasons during the past decades in the U.S. This proposed study represents the first large, prospective, racially diverse population-based study to investigate the association between PFAS exposure and kidney cancer risk in the US general population. The findings of this study will inform the medical and public communities about the health effects of PFAS exposure and help regulators make sound, science-based decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative T cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia patients that fail to respond to glucocorticoid (GC) therapy often relapse and succumb to disease. We identified new GC-resistance genes and a subpopulation of slow-cycling leukemia cells that is present in patients who fail therapy and relapse. We will use this information to reverse GC resistance and interfere with dormancy to prevent relapse in children with leukemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because it focusses on elucidating the molecular mechanisms underlying glutamatergic synapse function in inhibitory interneurons, a synapse that is implicated in many mental health disorders. This research could yield innovative strategies to boost glutamatergic synapse function in inhibitory interneurons, providing new therapeutic approaches to tackle psychiatric disease and neurological disorders. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH's mission that pertains to protecting and improving health.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE High blood pressure can lead to heart attacks, strokes, and kidney failure, amongst other outcomes. Controlling high blood pressure can be achieved through changes in behavior combined with medications. The public health component of this study will be to understand how engaging people through an application on their phones and computers can help them to control their blood pressure and decrease these poor health outcomes.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Collaboration Oriented Approach to Controlling High blood pressure (COACH)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Housing policies enacted during the COVID-19 pandemic—including eviction moratoriums, emergency rental assistance, and legal representation to tenants facing eviction—impacted millions of households experiencing and at risk for housing insecurity. This study assesses to what extent these policies affected the receipt of substance use treatment and overdose risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Neurodevelopmental disorders, including microcephaly and autism, as well as neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer’s, and cancer result in significant human suffering and impose significant annual costs on the US health care system and society as a whole. This proposal seeks to understand how diet influences neural stem cell proliferation decisions during development. Neural stem cells are the cells that make all the neurons in the brain. Results garnered from this research will stimulate new discoveries in translational stem cell research in the context of normal development and disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will map the parts of the African and Amerindian genomes that regulate the functions of the genes and contribute to disease. This has not been done before for these ancestries and needed to understand how genes cause Alzheimer Disease in African American and Hispanic populations. Identifying genes will lead to high quality genetic targets for the treatment of Alzheimer Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fear of cancer recurrence (FCR) is a highly prevalent, disruptive, and under-treated problem for breast cancer survivors. This randomized controlled trial will test the efficacy of group-based Acceptance and Commitment Therapy compared to Cognitive Behavioral Therapy and enhanced usual care for breast cancer survivors suffering from FCR while examining its cost-effectiveness and the mechanisms by which the intervention may work. Study findings will guide the future care of breast cancer survivors with FCR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT) As the leading cause of cancer death, lung cancer represents the most significant cancer-related public health challenge in the United States. Despite significantly greater risk, Hispanics patients experience a robust survival advantage relative to non-Hispanic Whites. This project seeks to test hypothesized sociocultural resilience factors to inform targeted intervention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: There are major gaps of knowledge in the understanding of how cell fate decisions are controlled to form airways or alveoli during development, and how the adult injured lung proceeds to undergo normal regeneration or abnormal dysfunctional repair. This proposal investigates these issues, examining mechanisms of cell plasticity and their implications in human diseases using mouse models, organoid technology and epidemiological data. Results from these studies will provide relevant insights into lung development and disease-repair processes for therapeutic interventions. PHS 398/2590 (Rev. 06/09) Page Continuation Format Page

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research seeks to understand the functioning and regulation of the photoreceptor phosphodiesterase enzyme (PDE6) and the proteins with which it interacts during visual signaling in retinal rod and cone photoreceptors. The work is relevant to the mission of the Retinal Diseases Program of the National Eye Institute because it will enhance our ability to predict whether genetic mutations of photoreceptor genes will result in visual disorders or blindness (e.g., retinitis pigmentosa, congenital stationary night blindness), as well as accelerate development of personalized therapeutic treatments for retinal diseases arising from defects in the proteins responsible for regulating the visual signaling pathway in the retina.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project will combine in vitro and in vivo approaches to elucidate the molecular mechanism(s) required by cancer and immune cells for migration in confining environments. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Individual aging is the outcome of biological configuration and socioeconomic conditions and experiences. Aggregate population aging alters individual aging as it generates conditions that affect social organization, health services, and macro-economic change. CDHA helps to investigate these issues as an innovative and flexible provider of research products, training, and infrastructure for sharing scientific insights.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genomic DNA is packaged into a compact form around chromatin, which is a highly organized complex of DNA and proteins that needs to be reorganized by chromatin remodelers to enable biological processes such as gene expression, DNA replication, and DNA damage repair. Recent human genetic findings have indicated that mutations in genes encoding chromatin remodelers are an important contribution to disorders of brain development, including autism spectrum disorder and intellectual disability. In this study, we seek to understand the distinct functions of chromatin remodeling in gene expression and DNA damage and repair, and the consequences of their disruption on the development of the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative: Glioblastoma (GB), the most common primary CNS tumor in adults, is surrounded by an immunosuppressive microenvironment through the recruitment of myeloid cells. This proposal seeks to harness the anti-cancer po- tential of myeloid cells by targeting Neuropilin-1 (NRP1) in an effort to curb the growth of this intractable tumor type. The studies will contribute to the fundamental knowledge of how the innate immune system modulates GB growth, and how tumor-associated myeloid cells could be targeted to create new GB therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Formaldehyde is a naturally occurring metabolite found in all cell types as well as a potent universal toxin. Our work will characterize the first known bacterial mechanisms of formaldehyde homeostasis with a model bacterium that by necessity, has been adapted to navigate formaldehyde stress. This work will provide insights into mechanisms of formaldehyde sensing, formaldehyde-mediated regulation, and mitigation of formaldehyde-induced protein damage.

The investigators will use this innovative strategy to engineer microorganisms that help us understand how the gut microbiome affects host physiology. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As ultrasound imaging becomes more ubiquitous and useful in diagnosis and treatment of many diseases, the need increases for improved processing of the data in smaller and lower power systems while not degrading the image quality. This project will explore the cutting-edge techniques in data reduction for ultrasound imaging and their implementation at semiconductor chip level for next generation portable and wearable ultrasound systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Borderline personality disorder (BPD) is associated with alarmingly high rates of morbidity and mortality, including suicide attempt (up to 75%), and death by suicide (10%), yet few medications are capable of reducing overall BPD symptom severity or suicide risk. Based on our novel and promising pilot findings, we propose a critical in vivo investigation of a potential pharmacological target for the treatment of symptoms of BPD (including impulsivity, affective lability, and suicidal behavior) - the kappa opioid receptor (KOR). This innovative project will advance understanding of BPD pathophysiology and has the potential to inform treatment development and risk prevention efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative: Vocal fold (VF) inflammatory lesions are common voice disorders related to disrupted epithelial homeostasis accompanied by inflammatory infiltrates and changes in the lamina propria. These lesions cause notable changes in voicing thereby impacting the quality of life. In this application, we seek to provide comprehensive characterization of VF Lrig1+ cells as a population of epithelial stem cells that are responsible for hyperplastic epithelial changes associated with disease condition and generate organoids as a reliable culture system to understand VF epithelium health and disease.

PHR: Project Narrative Our proposed T32 training program, “ACCELERATE: Accelerating HSR at OSU,” will prepare the next generation of researchers for careers in health services research. ACCELERATE will match experienced mentors with exceptional postdoctoral trainees in a collaborative, multidisciplinary environment at one of the most diverse colleges of medicine in the country. With a foundational emphasis on health equity, our trainees will be equipped to address the most pressing issues in the delivery of healthcare, using data and innovative processes to help people increase their well-being and access to affordable, safe, and effective care throughout their lives.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The learning healthcare system is designed to “generate and apply the best evidence to optimize the collaborative healthcare choices of each patient and provider, drive the process of discovery as a natural outgrowth of patient care, and ensure innovation, quality, safety, and value in healthcare.” Vanderbilt is developing investigators in multiple disciplines, who are formally trained and well versed in best methods for engaging and improving the learning healthcare system. We propose to continue training future investigators in the Vanderbilt Patient, pRactice Outcomes and Research in Effectiveness and Systems Science (PROgRESS) Training Program in three distinct methodologic areas: 1) Patient Centered Outcomes Research -To determine which strategies are most effective for patients; 2) Implementation Science-To implement those effective strategies into practice; and, 3) Health Policy/ Community Health-To influence policy to benefit all patients and improve the health of the community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE An unsupervised deep learning approach will be developed to enable high-quality photon-counting CT image reconstruction from less data by synergistically combining deep learning, compressive sensing, and iterative reconstruction techniques. It will significantly enhance the imaging performance of photon-counting CT at increased scanning speed, increased spatial resolution, and reduced radiation dose, with initial applications in clinical human extremity imaging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infective Endocarditis is a life-threatening disease and a significant economic burden due to prolonged intensive treatment. Early identification of the microbial infection is crucial to improving outcomes, but current standards relying on blood cultures are slow and often yield false-negative results. This prevents the administration of evidence-based antimicrobials precisely when they are maximally beneficial. The efforts described in this Commercialization Readiness Pilot program proposal will advance the maturity of a novel, fully automated test capable of identifying and characterizing these infections directly from patient blood in only a few hours. Success in this effort will result in a critically needed diagnostic, ready for manufacturing scale up as required for FDA trials and market launch.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Human iPSCs can provide unlimited sources of human neurons to study disease mechanisms; but in vitro neuronal cultures lack many important brain components that play crucial roles in neuronal functions. Thus, we will generate brain-region-specific humanized cortical interneuron mice to allow for the study of the role of grafted human neurons in brain circuit and behavioral functions. Such physiological humanized models will facilitate the understanding of cell-type-specific and brain-region-specific disease mechanisms, and the development of novel therapeutics.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research goal of this proposal is to understand the neurobiological mechanisms of three features of fatigue (feeling of weariness, sense of effort, and willingness to exert effort) in healthy individuals and individuals with post-acute sequelae of SARS-CoV-2 infection (PASC). These studies will significantly advance our understanding of fatigue, one of the most common and debilitating symptoms in the health care system, and contribute to the NIH's RECOVER initiative, which seeks to understand, treat, and prevent PASC. In addition, the proposed training plan will allow me to acquire expertise in neuroimaging, psychophysiology, and computational and translational neuroscience for an independent research career that will aim to understand how fatigue manifests in PASC and other illnesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  All neurons are remarkably different and existing approaches do not allow visualization of living cells in intact brains without making transgenic animals. Here, the multidisciplinary team will develop and validate novel technology for neuronal selection (Neuro-SELEX) to label specific neurons within highly heterogeneous cell populations and characterize membrane molecules associated with unique neuronal phenotypes. As a result, this research will generate advanced nanoprobes for single-cell deciphering of neural circuits and single-cell biomarker discovery in neuropathologies and diagnostics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hemophilia A is an inherited bleeding disorder caused by the lack of coagulation factor VIII (FVIII) and resulting in debilitating joint disease due to chronic bleeding. The immune response to replacement FVIII therapy is a significant concern that could be alleviated by better characterization of the factors that predispose to or regulate anti-FVIII antibody development. This proposal seeks to understand the pathogenesis of FVIII antibodies and investigates the mechanism of a potential novel regulator, B cell activating factor (BAFF), in FVIII immunogenicity with the goal of developing targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) primarily die from heart failure, and any therapies that could prevent or treat this cardiomyopathy could extend their lives significantly. Our preliminary studies suggest that thromboxane/prostanoid receptor activation helps drive DMD cardiomyopathy, and our goals here are to determine the role this receptor plays in DMD fibrosis and heart failure, to investigate effects of antagonism or deletion of the thromboxane/prostanoid receptor when combined with standard-of-care therapeutics, and to compare the molecular and clinical response to thromboxane/prostanoid receptor antagonism in DMD patients. Completion of this project could improve the chance of clinical success for a cardiac-specific muscular dystrophy treatment, and would help us understand how heart failure develops in DMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Signal transduction in development and disease PI: Rohatgi The Hedgehog and WNT pathways are two of the central systems for cell-cell communication, controlling both the formation and the maintenance of most tissues in our bodies. We are working to understand how these systems receive signals from outside the cell to eventually change the activation of genes in the nucleus. Our results will influence strategies to monitor and repair this pathway in developmental disorders, degenerative conditions and cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Circadian rhythms are used by organisms to align physiology and behavior with the 24-hr day/night cycle generated by our earth’s rotation. The goal of this project is to develop an understanding of the cellular mechanisms by which microbial signals integrate into vertebrate circadian rhythms. Circadian rhythms have been found in all domains of life, where they help organisms anticipate environmental change and optimize physiology to promote health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria control and eradication efforts are hindered by resistance to frontline anti-malarial drugs and new therapeutic options that target novel parasite biology are urgently needed. Host cell remodeling by exported effector proteins is central to parasite survival and Malaria disease and the PTEX translocon that drives this process has emerged as an important new drug target. This project will determine the mechanism of PTEX cargo selection and regulation as well as its function across vertebrate infection to reveal how PTEX and other export pathway components can be targeted for development of novel anti-malarials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) affects 30% of individuals over the age of 65 years and is the leading cause of vision loss in the Western World. Though the fundamental abnormalities causing AMD development are not known, several pathogenic pathways altered in AMD have been identified including inflammation, RPE and choroidal degeneration, and RPE barrier dysfunction, among others. The objective of this grant is to perform the first characterization of the roles of the different isoforms of the matricellular protein, osteopontin (OPN), in RPE cells a function of age, and asks the question would targeting OPN be a therapeutic option for dry AMD, using mouse models that present with AMD – like features.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the wealth of biological knowledge about how teeth are formed, the underlying molecular mechanisms of tooth development remain poorly understood. This research will identify the gene regulation programs of tooth enamel development and address the question of why certain genetic mutations result in congenital dental enamel anomalies. Understanding the gene regulation programs of tooth enamel development is important for the development of better strategies for the diagnosis, prevention, and treatment of congenital and acquired dental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This project is to investigate the molecular processes that control the association of protein tyrosine kinases with other cellular proteins. Dysregulation of these associations can lead to aberrant function in immunological response, cell proliferation or cell survival, and lead to disease including autoimmune disorders and cancer. The value of the research is to provide knowledge that can be used to either fuel future efforts to understand disease through biosensors or develop effective drugs against autoimmune disease or metastatic cancer.

PHR: Project Narrative Obesity induces chronic inflammation that triggers cellular damage involving multiple organs, possibly by damaging reparative cells that reside in tissues. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is great enthusiasm about the regenerative potential of grafting dopamine neurons derived from stem cells into the brains of patients with Parkinson's disease (PD). But there are concerns about the negative impact of the abnormal proteins and inflammation in the Parkinson brain on graft survival. Here we analyze inflammation in brain cells and in human grafts injected into the brain of α-synuclein mouse models of PD; we also develop gene editing methods to enhance the resistance of graft cells to neurotoxicity due to inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The adenosine (ADO) pathway is a key mechanism by which the body regulates inflammation. Our preliminary results in different nonhuman primate species in which SIV infection has an opposite outcome have shown that, in the nonprogressive SIV infections, in which the gut damage and chronic inflammation are well controlled, there are higher levels of ADO in the gut tissues compared the progressive infections, which associate loss of gut integrity and dramatic increases in inflammatory biomarkers upon SIV infection. These findings strongly support a significant involvement of the ADO pathway in the pathogenesis of SIV/HIV related gut dysfunction. We will probe this hypothesis in nonhuman primates, in which we will therapeutically increase ADO production with Roxadustat. If successful, our experiments may be directly translated as a new therapeutic strategy to alleviate SIV/HIV-related gut damage and residual inflammation that are responsible for multiple comorbidities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The recent and rapid advancement of genome-wide technologies has enabled major breakthroughs in heart, lung, and blood (HLB) research. Yet, we continue to face a deficit in interdisciplinary and collaborative HLB genetic epidemiologists who can address the challenges and opportunities characterizing today's wide and expanding genomics knowledge base and threats to HLB health. Our internationally known mentors with established research collaborations, unique and multidisciplinary training environment, and innumerable research opportunities make us exceptionally well-positioned to continue to develop the next generation of genetic epidemiology leaders who are well-equipped to investigate the genetic underpinnings and public health challenges of HLB traits and associated diseases.

PROJECT_TITLE: The Genetic Epidemiology of Heart, Lung, and Blood Traits Training Grant (GenHLB)
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: NHLBI Institutional Training Mechanism Study Section[NITM(JA)]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of this project is to implement a series of engineered liver culture platforms for analyzing the microenvironmental regulation of human liver cell functions and epigenetic changes within the context of non- alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). This approach will enable unique studies focused on the synergistic effects of extracellular matrix composition and stiffness, multicellular interactions, and soluble triggers of NAFLD in cellular phenotypic alterations, which could aid the development of novel drug therapies for this disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to test a novel hypothesis to explain how excess exposure to folic acid can exacerbate vitamin B12 deficiency. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Structural racism is embedded in societal structures that limit opportunities and resources for racialized groups; this manifest as social determinants of health (SDOH)—the social circumstances in which people are born, live, and age—and as racial/ethnic health inequities. While healthcare systems that serve low-income patients are implementing SDOH screening, critical knowledge gaps remain regarding the equitable implementation and impact of SDOH screening/referral systems. We will apply an antiracism lens to an evidence-based SDOH screening/referral system and develop an antiracist-informed implementation toolkit aimed at mitigating unequal treatment for patients of color in both the healthcare and social service systems as well as evaluate the impact of the SDOH screening/referral system on mitigating deleterious chronic disease outcomes across the lifespan; this proposal will allow us to create novel community- and patient-engaged strategies for implementing SDOH screening/referral systems that can be disseminated across the country with the potential to reduce racial/ethnic health inequities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Bone disorders resulting from bacterial infection are associated with severe inflammation and bone loss and/or abnormal bone formation but the mechanisms underlying such damage are poorly understood. While the neuropeptide substance P is recognized to exacerbate inflammation in a range of tissues, its role in the damage associated with bacterial infections of bone tissues has not been examined. In these studies, we will determine whether inhibiting the substance P receptor can attenuate bacteria-induced bone damage, providing an essential step in evaluating the therapeutic potential of repurposing clinically approved substance P receptor antagonists as an adjunctive therapy to limit inflammatory bone loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abnormal neural synchrony between the medial prefrontal cortex and hippocampus is a key feature of several pathophysiological and cognitive brain disorders including but not limited to schizophrenia, Alzheimer's disease, and epilepsy, thus understanding how prefrontal-hippocampal interactions are supported at the circuit level can have a significant impact on public health. Nucleus reuniens (RE) of the midline thalamus is thought to drive coherent neural states between the medial prefrontal and the hippocampus during wake and sleep states, however, this idea remains experimentally untested. The proposed research will explore the excitatory actions of RE pathway-specific neurons on the coherent activity of the prefrontal-hippocampal circuit during an episodic-like sequence memory task, and during theta and delta driven rhythms in sleep (REM/NREM) to determine how RE influences those interactions in support of memory and behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it aims to identify early diagnostic markers of glaucoma in myopic eyes with the goal to accelerate the development of new prevention, diagnostic and treatment strategies and prevent glaucomatous visual impairment in myopic eyes. The project is relevant to the NEI's mission because, by addressing the unknown nature of the relationship between myopia and glaucoma, the results will have the potential to reduce vision loss and improve the quality of life of the rising numbers of myopic patients with associated glaucomatous degeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Ovarian cancer recurrence is a leading cause of cancer deaths among women due to tumor resistance to therapy. The tumor microenvironment is highly immunosuppressive, and this constitutes a major treatment barrier. Utilizing our newly-developed and highly characterized murine models of ovarian cancer and patient- derived tumors, we will systematically examine the molecular mechanisms and targets associated with FAK- dependent oncogenic signals reprogramming the tumor microenvironment promoting tumor immune evasion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Impairment in attention is associated with many neuropsychological conditions, such as neglect due to stroke, attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder, autism, and Alzheimer’s disease, as well as certain visual problems such as strabismic amblyopia. By elucidating the basic brain mechanisms of attention, the proposed research will inform our understanding of the nature of attentional deficits in these disorders and contribute to the basic research foundation that will ultimately guide the diagnosis and treatment of these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This application proposes to establish a new NIA P30 Center on the Demography and Economics of Aging at The University of Texas at Austin (UT Austin)—The Center on Aging and Population Sciences (CAPS). CAPS will promote and support research key to the mission of the NIA P30 program, particularly novel research that illuminates how biosocial and environmental factors intersect, compound, and cascade throughout the life course to shape health and well-being at older ages. CAPS research will offer new insights critical to furthering the health and well-being of a diverse aging US population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative:  Mechanisms underlying the initiation and persistence of lethal cardiac rhythms are of significant clinical interest. Changes in connexin distribution, density, and/or properties are characteristic of arrhythmic heart disease; therefore, understanding what causes alterations in gap junction properties in heart disease is essential for defining the pathological substrate and devising effective therapies. The rationale for the proposed basic science research is that understanding the mechanistic basis of Cx43 and Cx45 regulation will lead to possible points of therapeutic intervention to restore proper gap junction intercellular communication that has been altered due to heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative:  T cells and immune suppressive regulatory T (Treg) cells are pivotal in immune homeostasis and diseases. It is critical to understand the functional protein networks underlying T and Treg cell function. Our recent study revealed an unexpected critical role for innate senor AIM2 (Absent In Melanoma 2) in controlling Treg cell function to mitigate autoimmune EAE, by modulating Akt-mTOR signaling. Based on these exciting findings, we propose to study how the expression and function of AIM2 in Treg cells are controlled through mechanisms both distinct from and shared with those found in the innate cells, to uphold tolerance and restrain autoimmunity. This study will highlight a previously unappreciated critical role for AIM2, shed new lights on the molecular networks underlying Treg cell function, and reveal potential novel molecular targets and therapies for autoimmune diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Midcareer Investigator K24 Award in Patient-Oriented Research will provide the candidate, Sung Won Choi MD MS, protected time to act as a research mentor for early stage investigators conducting patient-oriented research. Dr. Choi has devoted her career to improving the clinical and health-related quality of life outcomes (HRQOL) of family caregivers and patients undergoing hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) by: i) designing and executing rigorous clinical trials; ii) incorporating innovative correlative studies; and iii) leveraging mobile health technologies to enhance care delivery. Thus, her research program offers a rich training environment for early stage investigators to pursue patient-oriented research in HCT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research program seeks to understand how genomic information is organized and accessed by direct observation across scales—from single molecules to mesoscale reactions toward behaviors in living nuclei. The organization and structure of chromatin in the cell of often dictates when and how DNA sequences are processed and perturbing chromatin architecture can lead to misregulation of genes, errors in differentiation and development, and genome instability, all of which lead to a host of maladies in living organisms. By connecting newly accessible in vivo measurements into mechanistic frameworks of individual protein actions, many long-standing problems in chromatin biology are likely to be resolved.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Project Narrative Pressure injuries, local areas of damage to the skin and underlying soft tissue that are costly and painful, are often preventable if repeated instances of mechanical forces can be lessened with timely implementation of prevention strategies. Identification of early pressure induced tissue damage among nursing home residents by nursing staff during routine skin assessment is critical because detection cues initiation of prevention actions and may allow viable tissue rescue, lessening morbidity and mortality. We propose use of sub-epidermal moisture (SEM) measures as the cue for initiating pressure injury prevention because it offers significant promise by: 1) providing early detection of PrI damage by as much as 5 to 10 days prior to any visual skin discoloration, which can trigger prompt, effective, individualized prevention, 2) eliminating the inherent structural bias in visual skin assessment for residents with dark skin tones, 3) demonstrating a model of care using technology innovation in poorly-resourced healthcare settings, and 4) providing bedside, real-time, point- of-care feedback that is immediately actionable by nursing staff, the daily care providers for frail, vulnerable elders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Neurosteroids are rapidly acting anti-depressant agents with an undefined mechanism of action. The proposed research will identify specific neurosteroid binding sites on putative target proteins as well as novel neurosteroid binding proteins, enabling assessment of the functional role of these target proteins in anti-depressant physiology and behavior. The work will provide the basis for synthesizing compounds that target the specific proteins and sites that mediate neurosteroid anti-depressant effects, leading to novel therapeutics and insights into the biology of naturally occurring neurosteroids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This is an application for renewal of a training grant for postdoctoral and clinical fellows in the area of Neurobiology of Aging and Alzheimer's Disease. The 29 faculty acting as Preceptors in the training program are chosen from the Arizona Alzheimer's Consortium and have complementary research interests that span basic and clinical science, including brain imaging, computer science, genomics, systems, cognitive and molecular neuroscience, experimental therapeutics and neuropathological approaches to the study of the aging brain and early detection and treatment of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and AD-related dementias (ADRD). The program offers a unique collaborative and interdisciplinary research experience designed individually for each Fellow to provide the next generation of independent investigators the tools needed to enable them to contribute in significant ways to an understanding of cognitive decline in aging, AD and ADRD, so that preventions and treatments can be effectively developed.
PROJECT_TERMS: Aging;Alzheimer's Disease;Neurobiology;post-doctoral training
PROJECT_TITLE: Postdoctoral Training, Neurobiology of Aging and Alzheimer's Disease

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We discovered that endorepellin, a soluble fragment of the heparan sulfate proteoglycan perlecan, evokes excessive autophagy or self-eating in the endothelial cells lining breast cancer vessels with no direct effects on the cancer cells. This novel bioactivity of endorepellin, via selective and specific targeting of the endothelia, will be investigated utilizing state-of-the-art molecular methodologies combined with highly-innovative mouse models of mammary carcinomas. Our research, by focusing on the tumor microenvironment and tumor secretome, will unravel unique avenues of study using endorepellin as a valuable treatment modality to combat this devastating disease in both primary and secondary malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The episodic nature of affective disorders suggests that switching between healthy and unhealthy brain and behavioral states is an inherent feature of some psychiatric illnesses. Neuroactive steroids (NAS) have been implicated in affective switching and have demonstrated persistent antidepressant effects, suggesting the ability to influence behavioral states. The current project will investigate the mechanisms through which NAS can alter network and behavioral states, which will potentially provide insight into the episodic nature of psychiatric illnesses as well as the antidepressant effects of NAS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public health statement The death receptor Fas can kill cancer cells through induction of apoptosis, however in most cancers including breast cancer it is expressed by the cancer cells to drive and maintain tumor growth and facilitate metastases formation. Based on recent preliminary data by the PI this proposal will explore a novel immune suppressive activity of the Fas receptor and to overcome it when expressed on triple negative breast cancer, the breast cancer subtype with the poorest prognosis. Results from this proposed could result in an improved way to use immune therapy for the treatment of triple negative breast cancer where it has not yet been successful.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative The neurosteroid brexanolone has recently been approved for the treatment of postpartum depression and other neurosteroids are being evaluated for the treatment of major depressive disorder. The mechanism of action whereby neurosteroids ameliorate depression is currently unknown. This core will provide a panel of neurosteroid analogues with different mechanisms of action that will be used in Projects 1 – 3 to determine physiologic molecular targets and pathways that underlie the antidepressant actions of neurosteroids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative The human brain’s cerebellar connectome plays an important role in neurodevelopment and aging and has been implicated in a large number of diseases. However, a complete map of the human cerebellar structural connectome is still lacking due to multiple challenges that have thus far prevented comprehensive mapping of its complex intrinsic and extrinsic pathways. We propose to address these challenges to create the most comprehensive, anatomically curated maps of the intrinsic and extrinsic cerebellar connectome to date, which will enable the study of the cerebellar connectome in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We will interrogate how the innate immune NLR family member NLRC4 in macrophages and dendritic cells affects T cell responses through the modulation of expression of the apoptosis-inducing ligand FasL. We will further determine mechanisms pathogens and tumors exploit to downregulate NLRC4 expression and evade immune responses. These findings will provide critical insights into the non-canonical NLRC4 signaling pathway and identify novel therapeutic targets that can augment or inhibit specific immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Boys’ and men’s ice hockey is a collision sport, and women’s and girl’s hockey a contact sport with a high rate of injury and exposure to repetitive head impacts. Recent studies have shown that repetitive head impacts sustained in collision and contact sports may be related to brain changes, even in the absence of clinically diagnosed concussion. The proposed F31 award will evaluate youth athlete performance metrics as a potential determinant of head impact exposure, and will use a postural control assessment to measure clinical outcomes of cumulative exposure to head impacts; the didactic, mentor-guided fellowship proposed will prepare the applicant towards a career as an independent investigator utilizing a joint background in neuroscience and injury biomechanics towards improving athlete safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The rise of antibiotic resistance threatens to negate many advances of modern medicine which rely on antibiotics, in part because a common form of resistance, heteroresistance, is undetectable. We propose to develop a new approach to susceptibility testing, built on interferometric measurement of topography, which is able to detect heteroresistance, and is rapid, robust, and inexpensive. This new technology will help clinicians avoid treatment failure, suggest new combination therapies, and in the long term may be applied to other biomedical problems that involve unrestrained cellular reproduction, such as cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Diseases involving brain overexcitability, such as epilepsy, schizophrenia, post-traumatic stress disorder, and autism spectrum disorder, are often debilitating. My recent work has revealed, for the first time, that certain cells in the brain, during states of strong activation, put "the brakes" on in a way that has never been described before; this mechanism of firing, called 'ectopic spiking,' may serve as a check the brain uses to prevent overexcitation, yet we do not understand how ectopics are generated. I propose here to determine the mechanism underlying ectopics, and to elucidate when they occur in awake, behaving animals in the hope that I can use the results of these experiments to identify novel mechanisms that may be implicated in disorders involving brain overexcitability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disruption of normal sleep and headaches frequently occur after mild traumatic brain injury (concussion) and can persist in some sufferers for months to years following injury. In this proposal, we will be testing whether post traumatic sleep disruption actually contributes to the development of posttraumatic headaches, and whether impairment of the brain’s waste clearing system, the glymphatic system, contributes to these changes. These studies may lead to new approaches to prevent or treat post-traumatic headache by targeting sleep or the function of this cleaning system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Autism spectrum disorders (ASD) are highly prevalent neurodevelopmental disorders, and surprisingly, the majority of individuals with ASD also exhibit altered sensitivity to light touch. Our prior findings reveal that dysfunction of peripheral somatosensory neurons, not neurons in the brain, causes tactile over-reactivity in ASD models, and this tactile over-reactivity contributes to aberrant social behaviors in mice, yet it is not known how peripheral sensory neuron dysfunction leads to social impairments. The goal of this proposal is to uncover the mechanisms through which peripheral somatosensory neuron dysfunction leads to changes in S1 interneuron development, S1 microcircuit function and S1 long-range connectivity that is critical for social behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative In our daily lives, we make decisions as to how best to achieve desired positive outcomes and to avoid feared negative outcomes; this is complicated by various forms of uncertainty that impact the probability that any given action will result in a particular outcome. Our understanding of the computations and brain circuitry involved in probabilistic decision-making, and disruption of these mechanisms in anxiety and depression, has been limited by lack of parallel studies using positive (rewarding) and negative (aversive) outcomes. The work proposed here examines commonalities and differences in the computations and brain mechanisms supporting human probabilistic decision-making when potential outcomes are aversive versus rewarding, investigates alterations to these computations and their neural implementation as a function of anxiety and depressive symptomatology, and provides tasks and models that can be used in future clinical studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating, fatal neurodegenerative disorder with no known cure. A recently discovered mutation in C9ORF72, now recognized as the most common cause of ALS, is providing new insights into fundamental cellular pathways that are disrupted in ALS. This proposal aims to pinpoint the mechanisms underlying impaired axonal transport of autophagic vesicles and lysosomes in C9ORF72 ALS, and test therapeutic strategies for reversing these defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will disclose a new mechanism and signaling cascade that have critical impact on stroke outcome: CYP46A1 → 24S-HC → NMDAR → ischemic brain injury. This is expected to be a significant contribution because it will expand our knowledge of the mechanism of ischemic brain injury. Additionally, it validates and identifies new targets for stoke intervention, e.g., CYP46A1 and those allosteric modulatory sites on NMDAR that are critical for the binding of 24S-HC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Postpartum depression (PPD) affects 28 million mothers worldwide annually and there are no effective preventative therapies. These investigations will identify a patient-informed acceptable dose and pharmacokinetics of ketamine infusion after cesarean delivery, a common mode of birth, and will provide novel data on trajectories of PPD symptoms after CD. The results of these investigations will inform optimal dosing strategies for postpartum ketamine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Obesity causes multiple complications including hypertension, diabetes and sleep apnea, which contribute to high cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. We have discovered a novel mechanism of these diseases related to signaling of fat-tissue-produced hormone leptin, which excites an ion channel TRPM7 in the carotid body, a peripheral sensor of insufficient blood oxygen. Moreover, we developed a novel treatment for hypertension, diabetes and sleep apnea in obese individuals by blocking this channel.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To identify new treatment targets, the genomics of Alzheimerʹs disease (AD) has been examined primarily in non-Hispanic White populations. We propose here a genomics study of AD in multiplex families of African ancestry both from the US and Africa. We will use whole-genome sequencing as well as collect biomarker and cardiovascular disease phenotypic data in these populations together with information about ancestry and to identify genetic variation influencing AD thereby extending AD genetic discoveries to these underrepresented groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT (Narrative) Pediatric stroke has the highest incidence in neonates or infants, and may cause severe neurological sequalae, including motor and cognitive deficits. Infection and immune responses are a major risk factor for pediatric stroke, but no immune-directed therapies are available. The goal of this project is to test the pathological functions of blood-borne neutrophils and monocytes in experimental pediatric stroke to develop immunomodulation therapies of this condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hepatotoxicity caused by overdose of the analgesic drug acetaminophen is a leading cause of acute liver failure (ALF), a serious condition with poor prognosis and few therapeutic options beyond intensive care. High levels of the platelet adhesive protein von Willebrand Factor (VWF) have been linked to an increased risk of liver transplant and death in ALF patients, and experimental evidence suggests that VWF inhibits repair of the acetaminophen-injured liver. The primary goals of this research program are to uncover the mechanisms whereby VWF inhibits resolution of acetaminophen-induced liver injury and to provide proof-of-concept that VWF is a viable target to accelerate recovery after acute liver injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Parkinson’s disease (PD), late PD dementia (PDD), and PD-related amyloid angiopathy are looming disasters for public health. The combined direct and indirect cost of PD, including treatment, social security payments, and lost income, is estimated to be nearly $52 billion per year in the United States alone. Nearly 1 million Americans are living with PD (2020), and the numbers are growing, as there is no definitive cure. This proposed research is highly relevant, as the control of systemic β-amyloid peptide production and transport, involving platelets and blood, could slow the advance of late-stage dementia and open up a new approach to therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Untreated peripheral nerve damage results in a tangled mass of disorganized nerve fibers and blocks functional recovery following nerve injury. While significant advances in understanding the molecular mechanisms governing the repair process have been made in recent years, the clinical results of peripheral nerve repair remain disappointing. This proposal seeks to improve nerve repair by mimicking endogenous cues using topographical guidance and concentration gradients of ECM-peptides and growth factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative: The results from this work will reveal new signaling mechanisms important for the development of synaptic contacts between cochlear hair cells and spiral ganglion neurons (SGNs). Synaptic loss in the cochlea that results from noise exposure, age, or other factors could be restored through molecular therapies aimed at these mechanisms. Even if auditory input is eventually restored, either through prosthetic or biological means, maintaining SGNs and/or re-establishing their connectivity with hair cells will be critical for normal auditory function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Many neuropsychiatric disorders including depression, schizophrenia, autism, and attention disorders  involve networks of heterogeneous neurons. We will test mechanistic hypotheses about how populations  of neurons guide behavior in different cognitive conditions. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: We recently identified structural and dynamic features of membrane proteins that we hypothesize contribute to their native functions and aberrant aggregation, which is a feature of neurodegenerative disease. We will combine approaches from biophysics and cell biology to probe the role of these features in exocytosis, membrane-binding dynamics, and membrane-induced aggregation, which will provide a molecular mechanism for the activities of these proteins. This work will also prepare the PI to launch an independent scientific career by providing essential training in biophysical spectroscopy and cellular imaging, as well as disciplinary expertise in membrane protein structure and molecular neuroscience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative:    Advanced cutaneous T cell lymphoma (CTCL) and peripheral T cell lymphoma (PTCL) have very poor survival  due to limited effective treatments and lack of predictive markers for selecting the optimal therapy for each  patient. Here, we propose the use of an innovative “lab- in- a- patient” device, smaller than a grain of rice, that  can be inserted directly into a patient’s tumor for rapid drug screening.  Our study is the critical first step toward  determining if the implantable microdevice may help select what experimental drugs should be tested in  patients and ultimately help chose which approved cancer drug is most effective to treat a patient’s cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative To expand our knowledge about the cues that promote directed cell migration, we propose a new experimental platform that combines aligned collagen fiber landscapes with soluble biochemical gradients to study directed migration within a complex 3D environment. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE I developed new technologies that enable exploration of the understudied process of bacterial biofilm dispersal. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will support the re-establishment of a well-characterized cohort of Mexican American and non- Hispanic White older adults. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: OTHER PROJECT INFORMATION – Project Narrative Health insurance plans may impact beneficiary health outcomes by steering them to higher- or lower-quality providers. We will measure the impact of different providers on health outcomes and then use detailed data on plan networks to aggregate provider-level quality scores into plan-level measures. We will analyze the degree to which these measures explain differences in plan-level mortality rates and effects. We will further measure the possible benefits of wide dissemination of these quality scores for policymaking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE About 40% of epilepsy patients fail to control seizures after treatment, and there is currently no treatment that can prevent epilepsy. The goal of this study is to perform multi-scale electrophysiological investigations combined with advanced computational algorithm development to understand the characteristics of the pathological brain networks during the latent period of epilepsy. The findings of this project will lead to a better understanding of the network mechanisms of epileptogenesis and suggest novel approaches to prevent the process of epileptogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Recent clinical trials for Alzheimer’s disease have faced high failure rates in part due to a poor translation of preclinical findings from studies completed in transgenic mice, and immunotherapeutic trials in particular have been impeded by significant complications linked to the clearance of cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA). This proposal will utilize TLR9 agonist CpG ODN 1018 to stimulate innate immunity, and represents the first comprehensive evaluation of CpG ODN 1018 efficacy and safety in squirrel monkeys, a non-human primate model with a predilection for age-associated CAA, by integrating biofluid biomarker data with imaging markers and cognitive measures, in addition to post-mortem neuropathology correlates. The study will also feature advanced multi-shell diffusion MRI models to follow whole brain and white matter microstructural changes in response to treatment, and will conclude with an in-depth characterization of the CAA and choroid plexus proteomes using our group’s innovative localized proteomic strategy, which altogether will provide essential data advancing CpG ODN 1018’s feasibility for clinical application, as well as promote further discoveries of CAA diagnostic biomarkers.

PHR: Glioblastoma (GBM) is a highly lethal malignant brain tumor due to its diffuse invasion. Here, we investigate the functions of Plexin guidance receptors in governing biomechanical properties of migrating GBM cells during GBM invasion along preferred migratory paths.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  Sexual minority women (e.g., lesbian, bisexual, queer women) and gender diverse (e.g., non-binary) sexual minorities assigned female at birth are at elevated risk for cannabis use disorder (CUD) compared to heterosexual women, with this disparity growing in recent years, but little is known about how cannabis use (CU) risk processes unfold on a daily basis among sexual minority women and gender diverse individuals (SMWGD). Existing studies of event-level risk processes among heterosexual women and SMWGD have provided mixed evidence for two risk processes for CU: positive reinforcement (e.g., using to increase positive emotions) and negative reinforcement (e.g., using to decrease negative emotions); however, our preliminary results and the multistage model of substance use provide a potential explanation for these mixed findings by suggesting that these two sets of risk factors may be relevant at different stages of CUD, with positive reinforcement most relevant when CUD symptoms are absent to mild and negative reinforcement becoming dominant when CUD symptoms become more severe. To address existing mixed evidence for event-level risk processes contributing to CU among SMWGD and heterosexual women and advance our understanding of risk factors for CU and CUD in these two populations, we aim to accomplish three specific aims using a measurement burst design (i.e., 5 semi-annual bursts of 14-days with 2 surveys per day) with a sample of SMWGD and heterosexual women: 1) identify changes in the effects of event-level risk factors on CU as CUD develops, 2) test for differences in effects of shared event-level risk factors on CU for SMWGD and heterosexual women, and 3) determine if differences in CU trajectories for SMWGD and heterosexual women contribute to disparities in the development of CUD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Speech production is disrupted in a number of neurological diseases that involve the basal ganglia, including Parkinson’s disease (PD) and dystonia. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Although almost half of the over 1.5 million Medicare beneficiaries who enroll in hospice each year have Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD), hospice is poorly suited to the needs of people with dementia. Hospice care for people with dementia is both more expensive and lower quality than for other populations, such as those with cancer. The proposed study will evaluate how recent changes in the way Medicare pays for hospice impacts the quality and costs of care for hospice enrollees with dementia compared to those with cancer, which will help determine how to provide the highest-value hospice care for the hundreds of thousands of people with dementia enrolled in hospice every year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative: For women who use drugs (WWUD) in the US, the months they are pregnant and postpartum are among the most hazardous of their lives: the US has the highest maternal mortality rate of all industrialized nations, 13%-26% of maternal deaths are attributed to drug use in states where this topic has been analyzed. Disparities are complex and dynamic. To support the development of interventions to help WWUD survive while pregnant and postpartum, the proposed 4-year longitudinal study will use qualitative methods to “walk alongside” Black, White, urban, and rural pregnant/postpartum WWUD to learn about (a) their evolving drug- related and sexual/ reproductive health concerns and practices; (b) the dynamic risk environments in which these concerns and practices occur; and (c) WWUDs’ perceptions of pathways linking these environments to these concerns and practices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ionizing radiation is used to treat a large fraction of cancer patients with variable success rates. Radiation can cause immune cell-mediated cancer cell killing but mechanisms are not fully understood. This study will reveal a new mechanism that will improve radiation therapy efficacy and durability through generation of a special kind of memory T cells that are capable of killing cancer cells. It will also test and optimize the use of a novel drug to improve efficacy and durability of radiation therapy. If successful, this study may lead to clinical trials using the drug that has successfully undergone a Phase 1 clinical trial to demonstrate safety for patient use.
