IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The long-range goal of the “Communicating Data” project is to create a replicable model of STEM education that engages teachers and students as citizen scientists in collecting data on drinking water in collaboration with community partners; this will lead to improved public health and increased student competency and interest in science. The proposed project is focused on local issues of heavy metal contamination of drinking water in Maine and New Hampshire, including arsenic, uranium, and lead, and will have broad applicability to other water contamination issues across the nation. Teachers and students will partner with local scientists to analyze and communicate their data to the public in order to translate their findings into local action; students will engage in planned activities with their families at home to increase the likelihood of action at the household level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disruptions in the nuclear pore complex and nucleocytoplasmic transport have been identified as a prominent pathomechanism underlying Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) and related neurodegenerative diseases. While alterations to the expression and/or localization of nuclear pore proteins has been observed in multiple models of neurodegeneration, the molecular mechanisms leading to this phenomenon remain poorly understood. This proposal will test the hypothesis that aberrant activation of CHMP7 and ESCRT-III mediated degradation leads to the reduction of nuclear pore proteins from neuronal nuclei as an early event in the pathogenesis of sporadic ALS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the most common type of liver cancer and the third leading cause of cancer mortality world-wide. In the US, HCC rates have tripled over the last 30 years and a further increase is expected due to the increase in obesity and fatty liver disease. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because revealing if cellular senescence is a general mechanism in dopamine neurons leading to parkinsonism is critical for the understanding of Parkinson’s disease and age- related neurodegeneration. This study aims to identify factors and pathways that cause cellular senescence in dopamine neurons and other cell types of the midbrain, to ultimately unravel how senescence spreads between cell types and how it would be possible to interfere and prevent neurodegeneration. Thus, this proposal is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to fostering fundamental creative discoveries and innovative research strategies as a basis for ultimately protecting health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative This study examines mechanisms that are responsible for the assembly of nodes of Ranvier, and other domains of myelinated axons, in the PNS and CNS. We will investigate two complementary mechanisms: the roles of contractile myosin II in promoting node assembly and that of glial induced endocytic clearance in removing nodal components elsewhere, i.e. at extranodal sites. In the future, this research may aid the development of therapies directed at promoting recovery of function in demyelinating neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative High grade glioma is the leading cause of cancer-related death in children. Our preliminary data suggest hematopoietic stem cells and PD-1/PD-L1 inhibiting therapies may promote anti-glioma T cell responses in a thymus-dependent manner. This proposal will characterize the impact of PD-1 blockade on thymocyte development and determine how the thymus promotes anti-tumor responses in the context of hematopoietic stem cell and anti-PD-1 combination therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to understand mechanisms regulating the Cullin-RING ubiquitin ligases (CRLs), a large family of enzymes that control the activity and degradation of numerous critical regulatory proteins in human cells. Dysfunction and misregulation of CRLs can lead to various diseases such as cancers and muscle dystrophies, and a member of CRLs, Crbn, is responsible for the anticancer activity of the drug thalidomide. Our research findings will provide a foundation for understanding the pathogenesis of CRL-related diseases and inform novel strategies for the prevention and treatment of these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE AND RELEVANCE The proposed R34 and future R61-R33 research are relevant to public health because they focus on repurposing a safe, inexpensive, anti-inflammatory medicine (oral montelukast) to decrease hospitalizations of children with acute asthma exacerbations. This research may lead to more effective and personalized treatment for these children by selectively augmenting or replacing systemic corticosteroid, the only anti- inflammatory medicine currently available and one with concerning side effects. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NHLBI mission to promote treatment of lung disease and enhance the health of individuals to live longer and more fulfilling lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: HENRY M. JACKSON FDN FOR THE ADV MIL/MED
PHR: Project Narrative We previously demonstrated that HIV neutralization breadth can be shaped during early HIV infection and develops more frequently following infection with multiple founder variants (MFV). Preliminary data indicate that a multivalent HIV Env vaccine composed of a cocktail of minimally distant, stabilized Env trimer proteins formulated with ALFQ elicited broader neutralizing antibody responses than a more traditional single Env trimer immunization. Our goal is to develop a multivalent clinical HIV vaccine candidate that consists of multiple minimally distant HIV Env trimers corresponding to multiple founder variants and elicits robust protective neutralizing responses against HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative River blindness is a major neglected chronic tropical disease caused by a parasitic filarial nematode, Onchocerca volvulus, that affects an estimated 25 million people worldwide. Approximately 270,000 are blind and 1.2 million people are visually impaired by river blindness. The World Health Organization's goal is to eliminate this disease by 2030, however, this is unlikely achievable using the existing drug ivermectin that only targets transmission of infection. The long-term goal of this project is to overcome this barrier by rationally identify, optimize and develop new drug candidates to complement the present control interventions, and consequently facilitate the likelihood of eliminating this filarial disease that affects populations in mostly poor, developing countries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A failure to properly segregate replicated chromosomes has been directly linked to human cancers and severe developmental disorders. Defining the molecular mechanisms that underlie this essential process will inform new ways to combat these diseases. Bacterial cell wall biogenesis is the target of some of the most highly effective and widely used antibiotics; a deeper understanding of how cell wall synthesis pathways are coordinated and maintained has the potential to uncover novel targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prostate cancer (PCa) is the most diagnosed cancer among men in developed countries including the United States. Despite advances in PCa screening, more than a quarter of a million men die globally from the disease every year due to lack of effective treatment and emergence of castration resistant prostate cancer (CRPC). The overall goal of this proposal is to develop small molecules to treat CRPC, by directly targeting both androgen receptor (AR) and AR-splice variants (AR-SV).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Coronary artery disease (CAD) is the leading cause of death for both men and women in the US. It has become increasingly evident that coronary microvascular dysfunction plays a pivotal role in myocardial ischemia and predicts outcomes of patients with CAD. Our application addresses a change of vasodilation mechanism as an underlying cause of coronary microvascular dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Loss of function progranulin (GRN) mutations, which typically cause progranulin haploinsufficiency, are a major cause of frontotemporal dementia (FTD). Progranulin-boosting therapies are a promising treatment strategy for FTD-GRN, but the most effective strategy for boosting progranulin remains unclear due to progranulin’s complex cellular trafficking and diverse effects in a variety of cell types. We propose to investigate the cellular and molecular mechanisms by which progranulin insufficiency causes FTD, with the goal of identifying the cellular site of action for progranulin-boosting therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: The prepubertal hormonal surge that primes the rapid social and emotional development of adolescence may accelerate risk for disordered eating and the development of binge eating, particularly among girls. This project will test a model of sex differences in risk for binge eating that positions differential gonadal hormone influences on the development of functional brain networks in girls relative to boys as a key determinant of accelerated risk for disordered eating during this vulnerable period. Validation of this model would constitute important progress in delineating the neuroendocrine basis of sex differences in eating disorder risk and could have wide applicability to other behavioral and psychosocial problems characterized by altered responses to natural environmental cues (food, substances of abuse, etc.).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative mPATH-Cloud is an innovative digital health platform that delivers evidence-based and culturally responsive communication and navigation to help patients receive colorectal cancer screening, a widely recommended test that decreases mortality. However, while this type of technology has proven effective for routine, face-to- face primary care appointments, there is increasing interest and demand for reaching more diverse and marginalized patients beyond the confines of the traditional clinical visit. This project will determine the effectiveness and optimal way to implement mPATH-Cloud as fully remote and culturally responsive strategy for increasing CRC screening among low-income, rural and racially diverse patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Inside the living cell, the cytoplasm is a crowded place occupied by a diverse collection of dynamic molecular constituents. How this environment supports life processes is still not well understood. These studies will show how this crowded environment influences cellular processes such as cytoskeletal and chromosomal dynamics, control of nuclear size control and cell growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES

PHR: NARRATIVE The Center for Brain Recovery and Repair will strengthen its interdisciplinary team of basic science and clinical investigators, with the goal of discovery of new and effective treatments to accelerate recovery of function for stroke and traumatic brain injury survivors. The Center will continue to develop innovative new research programs, supported by intensive mentoring and state-of-the-art resources. These efforts provide a hub for brain injury research in New Mexico, and aim to ultimately benefit the large number of New Mexicans and their families living with the consequences of debilitating brain injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed research is to develop antimicrobial nanomaterials for the treatment of wound biofilm infections. These challenging infections occur across the population, and, in particular, in the elderly and those with underlying diseases. This proposed study will impact the rapidly emerging threat of multidrug resistant bacterial infections, providing an alternative to surgical methods currently in use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Spontaneous speech patterns and time-pressured picture naming ability have been shown to predict who may eventually develop Alzheimer’s Disease, but to date, these patterns have only been identified in monolinguals. As the country diversifies, the aging population will include many more people who speak two or more languages which makes the assessment of dementia inherently more complex. The proposed research will investigate linguistic markers of future cognitive decline and cognitive ability in older Spanish-English bilinguals to determine which aspects of bilingual speech might be useful in early diagnosis of AD in a more diverse demographic than previously studied.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative A specialized CNS macrophage, the perivascular macrophage is the target of HIV and SIV early following infection in the periphery and throughout infection even with non-detectable ART. SPION labels injection into the CSF label the PV macrophages and show they can leave the CNS, via draining lymphatics potentially reseeding the periphery with CNS derived virus. Studies in this application propose to use an FDA approved reagent to target PV macrophages, that ablates these cells, and study ask whether such ablation with ART and ART cessation, clears this CNS reservoir and its ability to traffic to the periphery with CNS derived viral sequences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE: The K24 proposal will support Dr. Margaret McNairy to train clinical investigators in the conduct of patient-oriented cardiovascular disease research in Haiti and Tanzania, and to conduct a new study on environmental lead exposure and cardiovascular disease risk factors in Haiti. United States trainees will spend ~60% of their time at international research sites in Haiti or Tanzania, which have onsite Weill Cornell faculty, long-standing international collaborators, and outstanding environments for research training. All the projects have patient-oriented research on cardiovascular disease as their focus and offer trainees a broad experience in the conduct of mentored research in the topics of cardiovascular epidemiology, clinical trials and implementation science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Ischemic stroke is a devastating neurological disease affecting millions of Americans. There is now an urgent need to understand the underlying mechanisms of stroke brain injury and to develop therapeutics against stroke brain injury. This proposal will use state-of-the-art animal models to study the role of the endolysosomal system in stroke brain injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Exosomes are now fully realized as being integral elements in many biological processes, first and foremost as conduits for inter-cellular communication. Key to their study and utilization across fundamental biochemistry, potential uses in clinical diagnostics, and realizing their promise as therapeutic drug delivery vehicles is the development of technologies that allow their rigorous, robust, efficient and inexpensive isolation and purification across many size scales and source matrices. Capillary-channeled polymer (C-CP) fiber and film platforms address these challenges in a unified way that provides continuity and simplicity across these fields of endeavor, holding the promise of advancing the knowledge base and applications of these important extracellular vesicles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Radiotherapy remains a frontline treatment for childhood medulloblastoma (MB) where long-term survival in  the majority of patients (> 80%) is accompanied by debilitating cognitive and cerebrovascular side effects. The  proposed R01 seeks to evaluate the benefit of FLASH for the treatment of MB, a new ultra-high dose rate  radiation modality that greatly minimizes normal tissue toxicities without compromising the eradication of brain  tumors when compared to conventional dose rate radiation protocols currently used in the clinic. This project  involves studies approximating clinical treatments of MB using a relevant grade 3 MB tumor orthotopically  implanted in the brain of mice as well as tumor free animals. Mice subjected to each radiation modality will be  evaluated at short (1-month) and long-term (4-6 month) post-irradiation times for tumor control,  neurocognitive, cerebrovascular and molecular outcomes to provide clinical and mechanistic insight into the  neuroprotective effects of FLASH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project investigates the perception and neural coding of pitch in infants, as well as in adults throughout the lifespan with normal and impaired hearing. Pitch plays a crucial role in music and speech perception, and in enabling us to hear out one voice in the presence of other competing sounds. An improved understanding of how pitch is coded should lead to better hearing aids and auditory implants, which will help people with hearing disabilities communicate more effectively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The tumor microenvironment plays a critical role in melanoma proliferation and invasion. Keratinocytes are the most abundant cells in the microenvironment of early-stage melanomas, but their role is poorly characterized in vivo. This study aims to elucidate the role of microenvironmental keratinocytes in melanoma progression in vivo by examining the effect of keratinocyte adhesion and paracrine signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Lung cancer is the global leader in cancer related deaths, and responsible for an estimated 1.4 million deaths worldwide and ~160,000 deaths in the United States annually. Treatment outcomes have improved in recent years with our recent understanding that patients can be divided into subsets based on the presence of specific genetic mutations occurring in their tumors that can be targeted with certain specific therapeutics. This application proposes the analysis of mechanisms that drive lethal lung cancer progression, using genetic mouse experimental models of lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative Muscle contraction is reliant upon excitation-contraction coupling (ECC) process that leads to an increase in cytosolic Ca2+ concentration and its subsequent binding to contractile proteins. Several neuromuscular disorders including Central Core Disease, Multiminicore Disease, Malignant Hyperthermia, Hypokalemic Periodic Paralysis are related to defects in the ECC process resulting in abnormal Ca2+ levels. Our studies will provide pivotal structural insights into the molecular mechanisms of ECC, that is ultimately required for finding new cures for neuromuscular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The activities of this grant represent a major upgrade in the technology to precisely analyze protein molecules from cells and the human body. From model systems and humans, proteins are measured from cell culture, cells, fluids, and solid tissue to better understand and detect mechanisms and markers of human disease. Technological improvements assist the collaborating clinical and research labs directly, but also the field of protein measurement science in general through robust programs for training, dissemination and community engagement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The COVID-19 pandemic resulted in environmental conditions that may have consequences for obesity and related cardio-metabolic behaviors. The study will (1) measure pre-pandemic to pandemic changes in cardio-metabolic health in adults >1 year after the acute lockdown period, and (2) report the size of these changes for different groups of people, (3) study mechanisms leading to changes in health. The findings will help prioritize public health priorities in the pandemic recovery period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma is an aggressive, fast-growing brain cancer that represents 48% of all malignant brain tumors. Due to the high rate of recurrence, current treatment options only extend survival following initial diagnosis to one year. Building on significant basic research into the biology of glioblastoma identifying myosin 10 as a potential therapeutic target, an interdisciplinary team has been brought together with the necessary expertise in glioblastoma and myosin biology, drug discovery and development, and the clinical treatment of glioblastoma to identify and optimize a myosin 10-based therapeutic agent for glioblastoma therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: EZH2 is a well-known histone lysine methyltransferase and an oncogene upregulated in many types of cancer, including prostate cancer. In this project, we will investigate the novel noncanonical, Polycomb-repressive complex-independent role for EZH2 in rRNA 2’-O-ribose methylation, ribosomal functions and protein synthesis via FBL. Successful completion of this project will provide novel mechanistic insights EZH2’s novel functions beyond its lysine methyltransferase and transcription repressor activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The directed movement of cargos inside cells by the molecular machines dynein and kinesin is essential for cell survival. This research will provide fundamental insight into the workings of the molecular machines involved in these two processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent studies of familial hypercholesterolemia suggest that the broad phenotypic definition encompasses four distinct subtypes: 1) monogenic FH caused by a pathogenic variant in an FH gene, 2) polygenic hypercholesterolemia caused by the cumulative inheritance of many common alleles associated with incremental increases in LDL-C, 3) LPA gene variants that increase levels of serum lipoprotein (a) and mimic the FH phenotype, and 4) severe hypercholesterolemia and a positive family history in the absence of a genetic cause. Distinguishing among these subtypes may have clinical importance. We propose a multi-disciplinary project to examine risk among FH subtypes and use implementation science to develop strategies for the communication of this complex information between clinicians and patients for improved cardiovascular disease prevention in FH. We propose a multi-disciplinary project to examine risk among FH subtypes and use implementation science to develop strategies for the communication of this complex information between clinicians and patients to improve cardiovascular disease prevention in FH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This R01 grant proposal addresses a critical unmet need, exploring LPC 18:2 as a novel small molecule therapeutic for immune related adverse events (irAEs) in cancer patients undergoing immune checkpoint blockade (ICB) therapy for cancer. We are leveraging a powerful, discovery-based metabolomics platform in human cancer patients combined with mechanistic studies in humans and preclinical models to understand molecular mechanisms by which LPC 18:2 protects against ICB-driven irAEs. This study will directly enable LPC 18:2 therapy to alleviate irAEs and minimize risk, maximize benefit, and personalize cancer immunotherapy for those patients who stand to benefit from these powerful treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This Phase II SBIR will complete the development of the Opioid Rapid Response System (ORRS), test its efficacy for opioid overdose response, and prepare it for widespread dissemination. Overdose events require a rapid response, which is often not available through standard emergency procedures. ORRS is a system for recruiting and training citizen responders to reverse overdoses through naloxone administration that capitalizes on widely disseminated medical apps linking responders to these events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Organ transplantation is the preferred therapy for end stage organ failure of the heart, intestine, kidney, liver, lung, and endocrine pancreas, as well as an emerging option for patients with limb, face, and other composite tissue loss and the number of patients awaiting (currently >120,000), receiving (>28,000/year) and living with (~420,000) organ transplants has approximately doubled in the past decade; however, even as the number of patients requiring innovative, scientifically sound solutions to transplant-related problems markedly increases, the number of scientists entering the field has decreased in recent years. Newly energized, transplant-focused training is required to perpetuate the pattern of discovery that has propelled the field of transplantation, and these training opportunities need to be developed cognizant of the unique clinical integration and multidisciplinary scientific and practice patterns characteristic of modern transplantation. Collaborative scientists and clinicians at the Emory Transplant Center are proposing an integrative, multi-disciplinary training program in transplantation biology (Advanced Research Training in Transplantation Sciences, ARTTS) to accomplish this goal.
PROJECT_TERMS: Research Training;Science;Transplantation
PROJECT_TITLE: Advanced Research Training in Transplantation Science
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Allergy, Immunology, and Transplantation Research Committee[AITC]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with psychotic disorders experience a high level of functional disability, and a major contributor to this disability is introspective inaccuracy, which is defined as inaccurate judgements of one’s abilities and performance. Yet, no intervention has directly targeted introspective accuracy in psychotic illnesses. In a sequence of clinical trials, we will evaluate a new intervention, called iTEST, that is delivered on mobile devices and trains people with psychotic disorders to improve their introspective accuracy with an ultimate goal of improving daily functioning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to design and pilot test a multi-modal sensor-based approach to automate functional health assessment and provide assistance with everyday activities for individuals with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRDs). This work will demonstrate that intelligent technologies can be used in real-world settings for functional health assessment and intervention. This research is relevant to public health because these technologies can extend the functional independence of our aging society through technology-assisted health self-management, reduce caregiver burden and improve quality of life.

PHR: Although astrocytes play critical functions in the brain, mechanisms controlling their diversity remain mostly elusive. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The National Institute on Aging (NIA) has funded the RAND Postdoctoral Training Program in the Study of Aging over five five-year cycles. We propose five more years of support for two postdoctoral fellows per year, beginning in 2021. RAND offers a rich and unique environment for advanced training in the study of aging—one characterized by a strong emphasis on interdisciplinary research, supported by 9 Centers dedicated to the study of myriad issues of relevance to aging, a diverse and distinguished group of scholars and mentors, excellent facilities and strong research support services, and the availability of formal instruction in research skills that postdoctoral fellows will need to productively advance in their careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE Oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) is a deadly cancer with high relapse rates and poor responses to immune checkpoint inhibitors, and current treatment results in reducing the patient’s quality of life. However, the generation of new compounds designed to target for degradation specific intracellular proteins opens previously inaccessible avenues to treat OSCC and particularly those that have inactivated the tumor suppressor p53, which makes them more aggressive and difficult to treat. We generated a novel degrader to target a newly uncovered vulnerability in OSCC and propose studies that should ultimately lead to improved therapeutic intervention for this deadly malignancy.

ORG_NAME: MAKERERE UNIVERSITY COLLEGE OF HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurological disorders are a burgeoning epidemic and Low middle-income countries (LMICs) like Uganda have limited capacity to address them. Research training in LMICs provides an avenue to address and build capacity for locally research aimed at preventing and controlling neurological disorders. Leveraging on a successful collaboration with Case Western Reserve University and through a Multiple Principal Investigator application, we propose a plan for a comprehensive multi-disciplinary research-training program for neurological disorders across the lifespan in Uganda. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epilepsy can be the harbinger of the aging brain and the third most common neurological disorder in the elderly with up to half of new onset cases with no identifiable cause. This work seeks to understand the causes and cognitive trajectory of late onset unexplained epilepsy (LOUE) by exploring the burden of Alzheimer’s disease and cerebrovascular markers and whether epilepsy related factors worsen these pathologies and cause accelerated cognitive decline. This area of research is especially relevant given the aging population and the importance of identifying treatment targets that can prevent and treat LOUE, and the work’s findings can be applied to diseases where seizures are a common comorbidity such as Alzheimer’s disease.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Advancement in child health is threatened by the decline and limited diversity of pediatrician-scientists in the biomedical workforce. The Pediatric Scientist Development Program (PSDP) has implemented a comprehensive strategy to expand the boundaries of child health research and develop the research careers of rigorously trained, diverse pediatric physician-scientists. The PSDP's primary goal is to produce the next generation of diverse investigative pediatricians who will discover the causes and cures of childhood illnesses, recognizing that a diverse group of pediatrician physician-scientists is better equipped to address health issues affecting all communities and achieve maximum health impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Injury is the most common cause of death in people under 46 years old with more than 200,000 Americans dying annually. Bleeding accounts for 30% of deaths after injury, most of which are preventable if patients receive timely bleeding treatments including procedures to stop the bleeding as well as medications and blood transfusions to prevent blood thinning. The proposed resarch will understand how bleeding after injury is managed in hospitals that do and do not specialize in injury care, identify the reasons patients do not get timely treatment, and then create an improved systematic process by engaging key stakeholders from across the spectrum of hospitals caring for injured people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This research explores the relationships between anemia and multi-dimensional functional recovery in survivors of critical illness, including recovery of physical function, cognition, mental health, and quality of life. Anemia is a common consequence of critical illness and may represent a modifiable risk factor for functional recovery, which is impaired in millions of annual survivors of critical illness. In this research, we test a multifaceted intervention to prevent and treat anemia during critical illness and examine the impact on post- hospitalization functional outcomes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will contribute to improved public health by helping understand how abnormalities in the Gs signaling pathway cause abnormal bone growth and affect fracture repair. The new knowledge will validate new tools for studying human bone formation and repair, and identify key mechanisms that could be targeted as future treatments for diseases of bone loss or for fracture repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Low physical activity after hospitalization mediates many harms associated with acute illness in older adults such as new disability, increased health care utilization, and higher costs of care. In this study we will use behaviorally designed gamification and social support through personalized coaching to implement scalable interventions to engage older adults in activity during recovery from acute illness and hospitalization. The study also aims to reduce disability and acute and post-acute care utilization as well as to promote long-term habits of healthy activity in aging adults with chronic medical conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s Disease, a neurodegenerative condition ultimately leading to cognitive decline and dementia, can present in a variety of time courses and symptoms in different individuals. We aim to explore the consequences on the function of brain cells of different variation in human DNA that contribute to Alzheimer, using a combination of work in cell culture, human tissue and analysis of large-scale information. Ultimately, this will allow us to characterize the mechanisms by which combinations of changes in DNA lead to different manifestations of the manifestations of Alzheimer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The primary neuropathological hallmarks of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) begin to accumulate in the brain decades before clinical symptoms emerge, making it difficult to properly model AD using short-lived animal models, such as mice. The overall goal of this project is to optimize, validate, and characterize seeding the brains of aging common marmosets with the tau protein to accelerate the onset of memory loss and cognitive impairment due to AD-related pathology. These marmosets will be invaluable in translational research aimed at elucidating the pathogenic mechanisms of AD and contribute to the development of new therapeutics for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Calcium-mediated signaling through inositol 1,4,5-triphosphate receptors (IP3Rs) is essential for the regulation of numerous physiological processes. Deregulation of IP3Rs leads to pathological changes in calcium signaling and is implicated in the pathogenesis of diverse diseases including cancer, neurodegenerative, autoimmune, and metabolic diseases. The goal of the proposed study is to elucidate the molecular mechanism of IP3R activity and regulation paving the road for development of novel therapeutic agents to control IP3R activity in the diseased state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mexican adolescents are at a greater risk of attempting and dying from suicide than ever before. We will culturally adapt, implement, and pilot test the Socio-Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy Protocol for Suicidal Behaviors (SCBT-SB), a culturally centered CBT protocol, among suicidal adolescents in Mexico City. This will be the first time that SCBT-SB, an evidence-based practice for suicidal ideation and behaviors, developed with the support of the NIMH, will be used with mental health providers in the public health sector in Mexico.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT) includes many forms of inherited peripheral neuropathy and affects 1:2500 people. There is no approved treatment for any of the one-hundred genetic subtypes of CMT, representing a large unmet clinical need. Here we are proposing to optimize a gene therapy approach for CMT type 2D that will apply to all patients with dominant mutations in the glycyl tRNA synthetase (GARS) gene.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Suicide is one of the leading causes of death worldwide with disproportionately higher rates in developing countries and far reaching impact on families, friends and communities. Uganda with a large rural based population, requires implementation of evidence-based interventions in order to address the burden of suicide and its prevention in rural Uganda. Thus, the proposed implementation strategy consisting of WHO LIVE LIFE guide with DHMT as Champions for Suicide Prevention in rural Uganda (WLLDC-SP), will pilot test a culturally appropriate innovative evidence-based interventions for suicide prevention to reduce the risk of suicide and SIB, and/or NSSI and promote resilience for people across the life span in rural Uganda and LMICs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Canavan disease (CD) is an autosomal recessive inherited leukodystrophy caused by the mutations in ASPA gene encoding the aspartoacylase enzyme, leading to loss of enzyme activity and increased concentrations of its substrate N-acetylaspartate (NAA) in the brain. Currently, there is no cure or disease-modifying treatment for CD. The main objective of this project is to identify a brain-penetrant N-acetyltransferase 8-like (NAT8L) inhibitor and establish the therapeutic utility of NAT8L inhibition for the treatment of CD using a murine model, aiming at bringing a novel treatment option that can potentially delay or slow the progression of CD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pre-release medication for opioid use disorder (MOUD) and peer navigation (PN) represent promising strategies for improving re-entry outcomes, but there is great need for better understanding of implementation, utilization, and outcomes of these interventions. Large-scale implementation of these programs across NJ's 11 state prisons, together with established state/university partnerships and innovative linkage across clinical and administrative datasets, creates a unique research opportunity to develop and disseminate knowledge on these interventions over time that can inform translation and adaptation across states. Among releasees with SUDs, the study will: 1.) examine patterns/predictors of pre-release and post-release MOUD and PN; 2.) examine recovery outcomes over the re-entry period and their relationship to peer navigation and MOUD, separately and jointly, utilizing innovative event history analyses incorporating propensity scoring and machine learning strategies; and 3.) analyze, document, and disseminate experiences of implementation and adaptation of PN and MOUD from the perspectives of multiple stakeholders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Social information processing is essential for social learning, memory and decision-making, which are social cognitive behaviors impaired in several neuropsychiatric disorders. Dissociating the neurmodulatory, circuit, and population coding mechanisms of two social characteristics will reveal general principles underlying social information processing. As no unified understanding of circuit and population coding of social information exist, results from this proposal have the potential to transform our current understanding of social cognition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysfunction in how the brain makes decisions underlies virtually all psychiatric disorders. Here, we seek to leverage innovative approaches in rodent neuroeconomics in combination with new in vivo imaging technologies to determine the neural basis of complex forms of cognition – including counterfactual thinking, or the ability to represent consequences of unselected actions. This work will uncover how neurons integrate hypothetical information and how such processes influence future behavior, providing translational insights into how novel treatments for mental illnesses could be tailored to circuit-specific computational processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite having an increased risk of developing new melanomas, melanoma survivors often do not engage in adequate sun protection, and the best set of interventions to help improve sun protection is not yet known. Given the promise of technology, in this project, we refine and test a mobile health intervention system that captures real-time sun exposure adjusted for self- reported sun protection use during outdoor activities and delivers up to 5 additional intervention components. This study will determine which intervention components are feasible, acceptable, and demonstrate preliminary efficacy in decreasing unprotected sun exposure..

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This study aligns with NIMH strategic priorities and will strengthen the public health impact of NIMH- supported research by leveraging low-cost technology to improve the accessibility, efficiency, and scalability of evidence-based suicide prevention interventions for youth in Colombia. Study aims will investigate the innovative use of technology-assisted methods to reduce suicide risk and promote mental health among youth within the education sector. Study results have the potential to galvanize political will and improve adoption and sustainability of evidence-based, suicide prevention interventions within the education sector as well as in other alternative delivery settings able to reach vulnerable youth in LMICs and other low resource regions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative We have discovered that the orphan nuclear receptor TLX can be targeted with small synthetic ligands. Such compounds may have the ability to enhance adult hippocampal neurogenesis, improve cognitive function and thus offer novel therapies for treatment of dementias including Alzheimer's disease among others. Here, we focus on developing, refining, and validation of TLX assays for the purposes of performing a screen for novel TLX ligands that can be used as points to initiate optimization efforts to develop TLX agonists towards potential clinical evaluation for treatment of diseases where cognitive function is impaired.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aeorobic organisms are highly susceptible to fluctuations in oxygen levels, which is manifested in many disease states. This project aims to investigate an endogenous signaling pathway that reduces metabolic rate and enable cells to withstand longer periods without oxygen. The ability to manipulate these pathways in human cells has significant therapeutic implications for the prevention of hypoxic injury that occurs in many disease states (e.g. pulmonary vascular disease, acute kidney injury, diabetes and neurodegenerative diseases).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondria serve as the powerhouses to sustain their continuous beating of heart muscle cells, and their dysfunction has been linked to various cardiac and systemic disorders. This investigation aims to elucidate the significance of Cullin 3-RING ubiquitin ligase in monitoring and maintaining mitochondrial health under normal and stressed conditions in the heart. Completion of the proposed studies not only offers potential therapeutic targets for heart failure but also provides valuable fundamental insights into biological processes with broad applicability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Despite an overall lower tobacco exposure, African-Americans have the highest burden of lung cancer in the U.S. of any racial/ethnic group. Findings from this project could contribute significantly to our understanding of the genetic susceptibility of lung cancer among African-Americans. This research will help explain why lung cancer affects African-Americans more often than European Americans and will potentially lead to new and improved modes of diagnosis and prevention for patients with lung cancer among African-Americans.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will develop a novel microfluidic approach to elucidate the effects of soluble factor gradients, individually and in controlled combinations, on zonated functions in primary liver cells from rodents and humans towards determining species-specific effects. Ultimately, our novel devices can be used to investigate the mechanisms underlying liver zonation, chemical-induced zonated hepatotoxicity, and how zonation is perturbed in liver diseases, such as non-alcoholic fatty liver disease and hepatocellular carcinoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Our proposed research is relevant to public health and addresses NIH PAR-23-058 “NCI Small Grants Program for Cancer Research for Years 2023, 2024, and 2025” since we aim to generate an improved understanding of the BRCA1-PALB2-BRCA2 axis. These core proteins are well documented to play a role in breast and other cancers and yet structural information remains sparse for the individual proteins and larger heterocomplex. We will combine advanced cell-free expression techniques to generate wild type and full-length proteins then perform cryo-Electron Microscopy and Native Mass Spectrometry to determine the structure of the assembled heterocomplex and resolve structures of BRCA1, PALB2 and BRCA2.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Group B Streptococcus is one of the most common causes of invasive bacterial infections during the newborn period, contributing to serious adverse outcomes such as sepsis with organ failure, meningitis and brain injury, and death. We propose studies that will help establish how group B Streptococcus is able to attach to the newborn intestinal surface, which sets the stage for later bloodstream invasion and serious illness. This work will add to our understanding of consequential newborn infections and may identify molecular targets that could be used in future efforts to develop new ways to prevent or treat illness from group B Streptococcus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of the proposed feasibility and acceptability pilot study is to capture lived experiences of breast cancer patients and characterize their knowledge types, levels, and gaps longitudinally. In a collaboration between human factors researcher, medical oncologist, and a patient partner, we will conduct semi-structured Cognitive Task Analysis interviews with 35 adult breast cancer patients to elicit experiences longitudinally (prior to first treatment, 6 months and 1 year after diagnosis). We will analyze interview data using thematic analysis and develop taxonomy of patient knowledge across the care continuum.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: DES MOINES UNIV OSTEOPATHIC MEDICAL CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reduced nitric oxide availability is a key factor in the pathophysiology of many cardiovascular diseases. While nitric oxide donors are used in practice, nitrate tolerance and development of endothelial dysfunction limit their clinical efficacy. In this project, we will develop a novel peptide that promotes endogenous production of nitric oxide through a unique mechanism of action leading to vasorelaxation and anti-inflammatory effects while protecting endothelial cell function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Radiation therapy is commonly used to cure prostate cancers, including cancers confined to the prostate gland itself as well as prostate cancer that has spread to surrounding lymph nodes or other tissues. However, many patients are not cured of prostate cancer after radiotherapy due to restrictions in dose required by the limited radiation tolerance of adjacent normal tissues. In this proposal, we will attempt to develop a novel therapeutic drug that could improve outcomes for these patients by sensitizing only prostate cancer cells to the effects of radiotherapy and spare other tissues, such as bowel.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite recent evidence that Black sexual and gender minority (SGM) adolescents and young adults (AYA) are at inequitable and increasing suicide risk, little research has examined forms of structural oppression as drivers of these trends. In this study, we will establish a large nationwide cohort of Black SGM AYA and follow them longitudinally to examine socio-structural predictors (e.g., state laws, policies, and social climate indicators of racism, anti-SGM stigma, mental health stigma, and their intersections) of suicide thoughts and behaviors (STBs) and proximal mediators of STBs. We will integrate Intersectionality frameworks and the social ecological model to identify modifiable socio-structural targets for future transformational public health policy and community-level intervention that reduce population-level suicide inequities for Black SGM AYA in line with the 2019 Congressional Black Caucus Taskforce “Ring the Alarm” report’s call to action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: Project Narrative Serotonin potently regulates brain activity and plasticity, and many medications for depression and anxiety act on serotonin. However, targeted treatments are limited because we have a poor understanding of how the serotoninergic system is organized throughout the brain. This project will address that problem by mapping the brain-wide architecture of the serotonergic system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Recent data from our team suggests that normal sinus rhythm emerges from a highly heterogenous electrical network along the sino-atrial node set by the intrinsic properties of the cells in specific regions and regional variation in vascular supply. The experimental and computational work proposed in this application will unveil the mechanisms underlying cardiac pacemaking and may lead to the development of rational strategies for the treatment of rhythm disturbances during heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The purpose of this project is to determine and validate the full operational parameters of a novel combustion generation system in the WVU Center for Inhalation Toxicology: a surrogate military burn pit generator. The conditions of combustion in burn pits varies tremendously and the resultant emissions generated also vary tremendously. Completion of this project will identify: proportions of combustion elements, parameters of operation, characterize emission aerosols in a whole-body rodent inhalation exposure chamber, and validate these parameters for subsequent animal models of burn pit exposures to study chronic multisymptom illness in U.S. Veterans.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endometriosis is a common and debilitating gynecologic disorder that affects approximately 10% of persons born with internal reproductive organs. To date, there has been almost no research on risk factors for or consequences of endometriosis among Black women and this is a significant gap as many established risk factors for endometriosis differ in their prevalence between Black and White women. This study will be the first ever study on risk factors and consequences of endometriosis among Black women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For Veterans living with dementia and their caregivers, one of the most critical choices during an ED visit is the decision to be admitted to the hospital or to be discharged home. There are significant risks associated with either choice, such as hospital-acquired infections when admitted, or return ED visits when discharged. This research project seeks to develop a shared decision making tool that will help Veterans living with dementia, their caregivers, and ED health care providers have conversations about risks, benefits and what matters most, in order to make a disposition decision that is aligned with patient and caregiver values and preferences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to elucidate the structural principles and channel properties of polycystic kidney disease proteins, which are the sites of mutations that cause autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, biliary atresia, and congenital heart defects. Treatment options for these genetic disorders are currently limited, in large part because the molecular mechanisms of the relevant proteins are only poorly understood. Successful outcome will inform the development of therapeutic strategies that counteract the molecular defects of relevant polycystic kidney disease proteins.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Avulsion of the pubovisceral muscle from the pubic bone at vaginal birth is one of the primary mechanisms leading to the development of pelvic organ prolapse later in life; yet, this injury is largely ignored since there are currently no strategies for repair. Here we propose to define the pathological changes that follow avulsion and physiologic recovery to inform the design of novel and effective therapeutic solutions to the benefit of women world-wide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a leading cause of death in the United States for which there is no cure. In this study, we will utilize high-throughput RNA sequencing technologies, proteomics, spatial profiling, and network analyses to understand how aberrant cells in COPD communicate with their local environment. We believe that this may identify new therapeutic targets for COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will develop novel deep learning models to improve performance equity in automated glaucoma detection, which will greatly benefit racial and ethnic minorities and socioeconomically disadvantaged groups with more equitable glaucoma screening. The novel deep learning models can be generalized to be used in other disease screening tasks to make a broader impact on various medical artificial intelligence applications. Equally important as our technical innovations, we will curate, clean, de-identify, and release a large dataset with 10,000 patients to the public including optical coherence tomography scans, fundus photos, glaucoma diagnostic data, and demographic identity information to facilitate a greater community of researchers to study medical artificial intelligence equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hemophilia A patients that are missing the protein factor VIII (FVIII) can be given FVIII as a medicine to control bleeding. Unfortunately, while some patients’ body react to the FVIII by creating an immune response that last even when the FVIII treatment is stopped, others make an immune response that disappears once the FVIII therapy is withdrawn. Because it is not known why and how patients’ bodies make different types of immune responses to FVIII, this grant will investigate a potential immune explanation for this and may contribute to finding strategies that can prevent this problem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Women and men differ in the development of cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors such as obesity. CVD mortality in the population has decreased in the past 40 years, but women of ages 35–54 have experienced greater rates of hospitalization, and the incidence of CVD in women aged >60 has outpaced that in men. We have identified a specific gene on the X chromosome that promotes fat storage in females and will characterize its effects in fat cells at different points in the lifespan when gonadal hormone levels change.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will employ the emerging novel, robust, cell-based 3D brain organoid model that closely mimics the complexity of the human brain microenvironment to investigate the acute and late effects induced by radiation therapy on normal brain structures and functions, and to enable the development of adequate countermeasures by leveraging the established UCLA portfolio of radiation mitigators which have been identified with the high-throughput screen performed by the UCLA Center for Medical Countermeasures Against Radiation. Considering that patient-derived iPSCs may be leveraged to develop personalized testing models, our novel biomimetic model holds significant promise in the screening of patient-specific radiation mitigators in the era of precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Oncogenic Ras signals through the poorly understood Ral oncogene, which in turn transduces signals via the exocyst complex while also regulating essential function of the exocyst complex in transporting proteins out of the cell. Using the simple model animal C. elegans, we successfully identified a separation-of-function missense mutation that disrupts Ral signaling but leaves protein export intact. We will define the biochemical defect in mutant Ral and translate the C. elegans mutation into human Ral proteins in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, in which activation of Ras and Ral are typically very high.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While breast cancer is one of the most common cancers in women in the U.S., ii is extremely rare in men, accounting for less than 1 % of all breast cancer cases. The proposed studies will investigate the mechanism of male breast cancer using a novel transgenic mouse model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) affects disproportionately older women, but very few effective treatments are currently available. The goal of this proposal is to evaluate the benefits of home-based heat therapy (HT) on physical capacity and quality of life in older women with HFpEF. Since this intervention is non-invasive, non-pharmacological and widely accessible, there is high potential for this work to rapidly translate into clinical practice and result in significant improvements in patients’ lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: THE TRUSTEES OF THE STEVENS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY
PHR: Project Narrative Deep learning-based diagnosis would provide a consistent diagnosis of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP), especially plus disease, and may improve clinical access to the underserved region via telemedicine. However, the performance of deep learning-based diagnosis is hindered by limited data availability in the training phase of the model and the image quality variations due to different acquisition systems. This study aims to develop a deep learning technology to augment the training dataset using animal-to-human translated images and standardize the image quality for images acquired cross-platforms using multi-task learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Tendinopathies are common musculoskeletal injuries that lead to tendon rupture and disuse. A major hurdle to progress in management of developing chronic tendinopathies is that the mechanism of tendon repair is unknown, largely because it does not naturally occur. The proposed studies will (A) identify biological and mechanical factors that should be considered prior to initiation of conservative treatment such as exercise, (B) determine the therapeutic potential of myofibroblasts and integrin α5, and (C) establish the foundation for new diagnostics and therapeutics to halt the progression of tendon damage and avoid ruptures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide has become the leading cause of death among adolescents in China, and adolescents in rural China experience particularly high rates of suicidal ideation and attempt while there is a lack of suicide prevention programs for adolescents, teachers, and caregivers in this low-resource, high stigma setting. Building on our team’s prior development and evaluation of a suicide prevention skills-training program for teachers in rural area (“Life Gatekeeper”) and leveraging our relationships with schools and communities in rural Guangdong, the proposed research project will develop and test a multi-level, universal suicide prevention program (“Together We Can”) that aims to address suicide risk, promote mental wellness, reduce stigma and facilitate adolescent help-seeking in this setting by engaging youth, teachers, and caregivers. This research will enhance research capacity for further suicide prevention and adolescent mental health research in rural China.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The objective of this application is to investigate anticancer effect and mechanism of promising cancer-preventive agents in an innovative model that resembles high-risk colorectal cancer. The success of our study will generate critical efficacy data that are needed for supporting future funding applications to further develop these promising anticancer agents. Our project will likely help develop new preventive agents that potentially decrease cancer mortality and is important for translation of basic research to the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neurodegenerative diseases are imposing an increasing health and financial burden given the rapid increase of the aging segment of the population. This grant will use a multidisciplinary approach to characterize PAS kinase as a new novel target for therapy of spinocerebellar ataxias, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD). Our approaches will likely have a broad impact on other neurodegenerative diseases as well.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As up to 15% couples are infertile, further examination of the intersection of reproductive and somatic health has implications for millions of individuals around the world. By examining two prospective preconception cohorts with populations in three countries, there is an opportunity to shed insight on future health risk for infertile males and females, which could be modified by early recognition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Friend and family caregivers of recently deceased cancer patients experience acute bereavement following the death. Post death bereavement is an intense period of mourning that includes an unfolding of the grief process and is characterized by strong emotions and demands on cognitive resources to those who have put aside their own needs to support the dying patient with cancer. This research will test the feasibility and acceptability of a nature-based healing meditation (NBHM) intervention to support cancer caregivers’ during the bereavement process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic low back pain is a leading cause of chronic pain and has a substantial economic impact in the United States. Treatments for disc-associated low back pain exhibit poor long-term efficacy highlighting an important unmet medical need. Our work will develop a novel model of chronic low back pain that sufficiently mimics human patients, to more accurately screen therapeutics for treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abnormal autoantibody-producing B-cell subsets, including plasma cells, are a major driver of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Specific eradication of pathogenic B cells in SLE poses significant clinical challenges. Our proposed experiments will solidify blocking the synthesis of the long isoform of the prolactin receptor (LFPRLR) as an effective approach to specifically eradicate abnormal plasma cells and their precursors without affecting their normal counterparts in patients with SLE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Insertion sequences are small, mobile DNA elements residing in many bacterial genomes whose activation leads to subpopulations with amplified segments of the chromosome. The increased gene copy number creates heterogeneous cells with distinct phenotypes which improves odds of surviving environmental challenges, including nutrient stress and exposure to antibiotics. This project aims to understand host bacterial factors and environmental conditions that regulate insertion sequence activation and the generation of cell individuality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Activating the compensatory signaling pathway for survival is expected in cancers, especially prostate cancer. We have learned that inhibition of AR can induce GR expression and activity to evade AR blockade. Currently, clinical trials are testing the therapeutic effects of AR-targeted therapies with GR modulators (NCT03674814) in CRPC. This proposal will study GR-driven lethal prostate cancers' complexities, mechanisms, and vulnerabilities across advanced disease stages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Narrative This proposal attempts to unravel a major challenge in understanding cancer progression i.e., how microenvironmental stress in the primary tumor select for distinct metabolic phenotypes. Specifically, we will study how switching to a lipogenic phenotype confers metabolic advantage to stress adapted cells. We propose to decipher the relationship between microenvironmental stress-induced evolution that results in hardwired phenotypic adaptation represented by a lipogenic phenotype as an initiator of cancer progression.

PHR: NARRATIVE  There are seven human genetic mutations of KCa2.3 linked to Zimmermann-Laband syndrome 3 (ZLS3) and one mutation associated with idiopathic noncirrhotic portal hypertension (INCPH). We hypothesize that ZLS3 is related to abnormally elevated Ca2+ sensitivity of the mutant KCa2.3 channels. We will explore FDA-approved drugs and compounds in clinical trials that inhibit KCa2.3 channels as candidates for off-label or compassionate use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Isolation and processing hematopoietic stem cells (HSC) in the hypoxia condition strikingly improve numbers and functionalities of HSCs. Here, we propose to study the functions of p38 MAPK/Nrf2/Bach1 pathway in the hypoxia condition in the context of Fanc-/- HSCs. We will also develop a Spacer-Nick gene correction system along with inhibition of p38 pathway to restore the functions of Fanc-/- HSCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Potential celiac disease occurs when an antibody blood test for celiac disease is positive, but the small intestinal biopsy is normal. Some of these patients will progress to biopsy-positive celiac disease, while others do not. We will determine the difference in immune system signals, active genes in the small intestine, and small intestinal and stool microbial communities in children with celiac disease, potential celiac disease, and non-celiac disease controls to understand the changes that occur which allow loss of gluten tolerance and tissue injury.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Radiation-induced vaginal toxicity is a common side effect of pelvic radiotherapy, and no clinical tools exist for objective, quantitative evaluation of vagina health. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Burnout is pervasive in oncology, imparting harm to both providers and patients, increasing healthcare and workforce disparities, and exacerbating projected physician and nursing shortages. To address the critical and unmet need for evidence-based, acceptable, and scalable interventions to improve burnout, this application will evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of a novel team-based intervention that includes mindfulness and compassion-based approaches and is delivered by hospital chaplains embedded within the interprofessional team. It will also develop and validate a low-burden, objective, and embedded ambulatory assessment “toolkit” to identify interpersonal and objective behavioral indices that can be used to improve research rigor and ultimately expand the evidence-base for effective approaches to improve provider well-being and address the needs of the 21st century healthcare workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative In Tajikistan, as well as in many other LMICs, especially in Asia, women have elevated rates of suicide. This project works collaboratively with diverse stakeholders to develop and pilot a scalable evidence-based nurse and peer-led suicide prevention program in primary care for women at moderate or high risk for suicide. It could help reduce the epidemic of suicide and it also augments an NIH supported research capacity building program to further advance the implementation science capacities of mental health researchers in Tajikistan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The alphavirus Mayaro is a mosquito borne pathogen that causes febrile illness in Latin America but has not produced widespread outbreaks like related chikungunya virus. Given that chikungunya epidemics are promoted by viral adaptation to increase infection and transmission in urban mosquito species, the goal of this project is to assess the potential for Mayaro virus to adapt to urban mosquito vectors using an experimental evolution approach. Understanding potential for Mayaro virus adaptation is important for defining risk of future outbreaks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE South Asia has the highest suicide rate in the world with important risk profile differences from high-income settings. We will conduct formative research to co-design a package of brief interventions and implementation strategies to prevent youth-suicide and then test the package in a pilot feasibility hybrid type 2 cluster randomized controlled trial in Nepal. Potential health impacts may be substantial as results can be applied not only in similar South Asian primary healthcare contexts, but also in low-resource settings in the US and abroad, where the suicide burden remains high.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Worldwide, the more than 52% of women living with HIV (WLWH) experience earlier onset of non-AIDS comorbidities (such as diabetes and heart disease) and increased mortality compared to men living with HIV (MLWH), despite viral suppression with antiretroviral therapy. The underlying cause for this difference is likely increased HIV-induced immune activation and inflammation in WLWH compared to MLWH. The goal of this proposal is to demonstrate that CD38, a T cell marker of immune activation in HIV infection, plays a role in chronic inflammation in WLWH and is a potential therapeutic target to decrease morbidity and mortality in WLWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: An unmet clinical need exists for new therapeutic concepts in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), a cancer associated with exceptionally high mortality. We hypothesize that intra-tumoral heterogeneity, progression, metastasis, and drug resistance is driven by hypoxia-mediated reprogramming of PDAC cells. In this study we interrogate the function of hypoxic cells and identify molecular mechanisms that drive adaptation to hypoxia in PDAC tumors in vivo, which may inform future therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE Older Hispanic/Latina women living with food insecurity are at very high risk for medical conditions; despite this, they have been understudied in medical research. Chronic binge eating disorder (BED) worsens risk for multimorbidity and may be particularly detrimental for older Hispanic/Latina women living with food insecurity. This study will provide critical information about the prospective impacts of BED in older Hispanic/Latina women living with food insecurity that can be used to inform future treatment efforts and policy changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative. Black school-age children report suicidal thoughts and behavior (STB) more frequently than their white peers and are twice as likely to die from suicide. The most common psychiatric disorder associated with STB and suicide deaths in school-age Black children is attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), and Black children may experience a disproportionate impact from ADHD-related risk for STB due to racism. There is a need for research examining how ADHD may intersect with racism to widen the racial disparity in STB and suicide deaths, and which factors could protect against STB, to inform suicide prevention strategies for Black school-age children with ADHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Genitourinary syndrome of menopause and the associated condition of vulvovaginal atrophy negatively impacts the quality of life of millions of perimenopausal and menopausal women world-wide. Despite its high prevalence and interference with healthy aging, current treatments for GSM are suboptimal, with many issues related to accessibility or long-term efficacy. The proposed research will determine if a minimally invasive, low-cost, acellular biomaterial with modular delivery mechanism can reverse pathological changes in all vaginal tissue layers and therefore restore a healthy vaginal phenotype.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Extensive changes occur due to menopause that can put women at greater risk for heart attacks, diabetes, and related diseases, but the reasons why are not well understood. Here we propose to use a chemical that is toxic to follicles in mouse ovaries to simulate menopause, compare to control female and male mice, look at how genes are turned off and on in various organs throughout the body, and investigate how estrogen treatment reverses these changes. Together with comparisons between samples from premenopausal versus postmenopausal women, these findings could identify genes that change with menopause, facilitating more precise prevention and intervention strategies for cardiovascular disease in midlife women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: NARRATIVE AD is characterized by the accumulation in the brain of misfolded protein aggregates in the form of amyloid-beta and hyperphosphorylated Tau. Toxic Tau aggregates are formed by a seeding/nucleation mechanism that enables them to spread throughout the brain during the course of the disease. In this project we will develop, validate and utilize a highly relevant screening assay based on the powerful PMCA technique invented and developed in our group to identify and develop novel drugs for AD treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application will investigate the role of MeCP2 Ser421 phosphorylation (p421) in the antidepressant action of ketamine. We observe a requirement of MeCP2 Ser421 in the sustained, but not acute, antidepressant action of ketamine suggesting distinct mechanisms for prolonged versus rapid drug action. We propose to test a mechanistic model that transitions the acute rapid antidepressant actions of ketamine with MeCP2 pSer421 dependent sustained effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Inhibition of remyelination and neurorepair is a hallmark of many neurological disorders including multiple sclerosis and neurodegenerative diseases. Overcoming the inhibitory effect of toxic factors in brain lesions on remyelination is essential to promote neurorepair for devastating neurological diseases. The proposed research will address this public health concern by identifying novel compounds that overcome extrinsic inhibition of remyelination with the potential to facilitate repair and slow disease progression in neuroinflammatory diseases like Multiple Sclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) provides a stable fluid cushion to the brain and carries components that can control brain development, maintenance, and aging. Building on our recent finding that concentrations of CSF electrolytes change as the brain matures, this proposal uses cutting-edge imaging, genetic, molecular, and gene-therapy techniques to test the hypothesis that these shifts in CSF electrolytes are necessary to facilitate brain generation and electrical activity. Outcomes of this innovative research program will have major implications for how we understand the fundamental processes that are critical to brain development, will clarify pathophysiology underlying CSF biomarkers, and will inform future efforts to harness CSF to mitigate developmental mental health disorders.
