IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Immune non-responder HIV-1 infected persons (INR), aged individuals, do not recover CD4 Tcell count after ART and remain at greater risk for morbidity and mortality. We found enrichedlevels of gut-derived bacterial toxins in the plasma of those patients. We will explore if these toxins have a role in lowering CD4 T cell count in INR and contribute to morbid outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will provide a detailed characterization of human behavioral and neural responses to real-world object images degraded by visual noise or blur, with the goal of developing deep neural network (DNN) recognition models that can better approximate the robust neural computations performed by the human visual system. The foundational knowledge gained from this research will inform our understanding of central visual disorders, including both acquired and neurodevelopmental disorders. The development of more robust, human-like DNN models is also of considerable relevance to AI applications in computer vision, including the analysis and evaluation of medical images.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE/NARRATIVE Aβ peptides and amyloid plaques play important roles in the early stages of Alzheimer's disease (AD), and the importance of amyloid pathology in AD is supported by several recent FDA approvals. But there is a lot about these pathological hallmarks that we do not understand. This project aims to address the urgent clinical need to better understand Aβ dynamics during progression of amyloid plaque pathology in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Here, we propose a Center without Walls, entitled Epilepsy Multiplatform Variant Prediction (EpiMVP), spanning five institutions and incorporating expertise from geneticists, clinicians, computational biologists, neuroscientists, stem cell biologists, pharmacologists and electrophysiologists who have a proven track record of collaborative publications and grants, as well as stature as leaders of national and international epilepsy organizations. EpiMVP will develop a modular, highly integrated platform approach to accelerate determination of the functional, pharmacological, neuronal network and whole animal consequences of genetic variants among a range of clinical epilepsy types. Our ultimate goal is to devise an effective platform for testing the pathogenicity of variants of uncertain significance in non-ion channel, non-receptor genes implicated in epilepsy and for identifying potential targets for future intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project is a novel study of psoriasis in individuals with Down syndrome (DS). Psoriasis is associated with increased cardiometabolic risk factors and cardiovascular disease in the general population; however, this association has never been explored in people with DS who are considered protected against cardiovascular disease. This study will use a population-level database to enhance our understanding of psoriasis in people with DS and explore if psoriasis could present an exception to their presumed cardiovascular disease resilience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE: We propose to conduct research that will determine the impact of relevant behaviors on HIV prevention among Young Black Sexual Minority Men (YBSMM), such as heavy cannabis use. We propose to explore mechanisms, specifically neurocognitive impacts of heavy cannabis use, linking heavy cannabis use to HIV prevention outcomes (and particularly PrEP use), and whether motivations for cannabis use, amidst a changing cannabis regulatory, social acceptance and legal landscape, modify its effects on HIV prevention. Identifying neurocognitive mechanisms through which cannabis use affects HIV prevention and the importance of motivations for cannabis use in understanding clinical outcomes will provide targets for future HIV prevention efforts.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Shared decision making is a key part of high-quality care for adolescents with chronic conditions and their families. Yet, because no measure of adolescent shared decision making exists, it is impossible to evaluate whether efforts to improve shared decision making and improve adolescents’ outcomes are successful. Thus, this project will develop and validate the first adolescent and parent reported measure of adolescent shared decision making.

PROJECT_TITLE: Developing and Validating an Adolescent and Parent Reported Measure of Pediatric Shared Decision Making

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will assess whether an intervention that shows a patient’s medication out-of-pocket cost to clinicians via the Electronic Health Record when the medication is being ordered improves access to medications and quality of care for Black, Hispanic or Latino, and rural patients with chronic conditions. High out-of-pocket costs and medication unaffordability are principal drivers of lower rates of use of effective medications and lower rates of guideline concordant care among these patient populations. This study will inform how, if at all, the intervention leads to increased receipt of treatment services consistent with national evidence-based recommendations and reductions in preventable outcomes for these patients, and whether the impact was different during the COVID-19 pandemic.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to identify the factors related to high resistance to substance use. Factors increasing resistance may have the highest impact in maintaining or leading to health, as opposed to disease. Identifying these factors requires novel methods developed for this study, and developmental data – from childhood to adulthood – already available and newly obtained in this project in a sample of twins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative / Relevance This study will develop a comprehensive risk prediction model based on genetic and environmental/lifestyle risk factors in a racially/ethnically diverse population which will correct the Euro-centric bias. To translate this transethnic risk prediction model into clinical practice, we will use microsimulation modeling to personalize screening recommendations based on genetic and environmental risk factor information and we will develop a web-based risk communication tool which we will evaluate in racially/ethnically diverse participants. Results from our study will ensure that targeted personalized interventions will confer equitable benefits for all Americans regardless of their ethnicity and race.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal, our interdisciplinary team proposes to develop and validate innovative methods to advance personalized risk prediction models in the presence of missing and biased EHR data We propose to develop: 1) effective sample-weighting method to correct biases in risk factor selection and estimation for population inferences (Aim 1), 2) flexible deep learning method for EHR personalized risk prediction with fairness criteria (Aim 2); and 3) innovative calibration method to improve reproducibility of EHR-based risk models between institutions (Aim 3). We will assess and validate the developed methods on the New York City Clinical Data Research Network (NYC-CDRN).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Type 1 diabetes occurs due to autoimmune destruction of insulin-secreting beta cells in the pancreas. Identifying target molecules (i.e. antigens) for T-immune cells is important to develop immunotherapy to halt autoimmune attack against beta cells and ultimately prevent and sure type 1 diabetes. In this project, we will characterize antigen specificity and phenotypes of T-immune cells that are involved in the pathogenesis of type 1 diabetes.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative  Diabetes is the most common metabolic disease in the world and the leading cause of end stage renal disease. The focus of this proposal is to examine the pathogenic role of dynamin-related protein 1 (Drp1), a key protein involved in mitochondrial fragmentation, in experimental models of diabetic kidney disease. The results of this study will provide important new insights into the role of mitochondrial morphology in the development of diabetic nephropathy, and may lead to novel therapeutic targets for the future treatment of diabetic kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hotspot mutations in the U2AF1 splicing factor gene (encoding U2AF1S34 and U2AF1Q157 mutants) are associated with different clinical features, outcomes, alternative splicing, and co-occurring gene mutations in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS). The proposed studies will test the hypotheses that different gene expression and alternative splicing programs are aberrantly induced by U2AF1S34F and U2AF1Q157R mutants, and that these distinct molecular perturbations contribute to the divergent hematopoietic phenotypes we observe in MDS patients, including cooperativity with other gene mutations (e.g., ASXL1). A better understanding of the mechanisms driving pathogenesis of U2AF1 mutant MDS could nominate vulnerabilities to therapeutically exploit in MDS patients harboring mutations in U2AF1 and other splicing factor genes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: An adverse prognosis subset of myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is characterized by increased expression of a set of homeodomain transcription factors, including HoxA9 and A10. In preliminary studies, we found such acute myeloid leukemias were also characterized by activation of pathways involved in the innate immune response. In murine models of Hox-overexpressing AML, we found emergency granulopoiesis was enhanced and failed to resolve during the innate immune response; associated with accelerated leukemogenesis and shortened survival. We also found increased expression of proteins involved in the integrated stress response (ISR) during leukemogenesis in Hox-overexpressing murine models of AML. These results suggest the ISR may sustain EG and enhance accumulation of mutations leading to AML in the context of increased Hox expression. Molecular mechanisms involved in this may provide markers of adverse prognosis in a subset of myeloid malignancies and potential therapeutic targets to delay disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have identified a novel mechanism by which co-activation of two neurotransmitter receptors, called mGlu5 and mGlu3, can enhance synaptic plasticity and cognitive function. Employing a combination of highly selective pharmacological tools, genetic mouse models, as well as state of the art cellular and in vivo studies, we will test the hypothesis that this mGlu3/mGlu5 communication occurs in a specific population of neurons in the prefrontal cortex, a brain region that is involved in cognitive deficits in schizophrenia patients. We will then test the hypothesis that mGlu3 activation improves cognitive performance in rodents via a mechanism that is dependent on co-activation of mGlu5 and determine the ability of mGlu3 and mGlu5 to interact after animals have been treated with phencyclidine to induce cognitive deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: The depression-executive dysfunction syndrome after stroke is common, chronic, and disabling. The proposed study will evaluate the efficacy and target engagement of a digital therapeutic that targets the executive control network by training rapid multitasking, combined with metacognitive coaching to improve awareness of deficits and transfer of training gains. In the short-term, the findings will inform the efficacy of the intervention and in the long-term, may support the use of the intervention to improve co-occurring cognitive and mood dysfunction after stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will identify the exact genomic locations of DNA lesions that occur endogenously during aging as well as those induced by common environmental carcinogens and anti-cancer compounds, and then characterize the factors that influence damage removal at these same sites. The data obtained through this work will provide genome-wide single-nucleotide resolution DNA damage- and repair-platforms that will be widely used by researchers in the fields of DNA damage, repair, and mutagenesis as such contributes to the efforts of a holistic approach to carcinogenesis and chemotherapy. Thus, this project is relevant to NIH’s mission to understand how DNA adducts contribute to human carcinogenesis and affect cancer treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Despite modern combination therapies, T-cell lymphoma (TCL) continues to have high rates of refractory disease and early relapse due to escape from immunosurveillance. Although TCL cells carry alterations that protects them from phagocytosis, their identification and relevance is poorly understood. This proposal utilizes integrative genomic and proteomic approaches to investigate mechanisms responsible for resistance to phagocytosis in TCL and develop strategies for their therapeutic targeting, thus providing significant impact for a wide variety of malignancies beyond TCL.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Fatigue is highly prevalent in individuals following severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS- CoV-2) infection which can persists for weeks to months. Veterans experiencing the chronic presence of fatigue following SARS-CoV-2 infection may be at risk for experiencing increased fatigability when engaging in physical activity. Skeletal muscle weakness, reduced oxygen extraction, and reduced affective responses to activity may contribute to increased fatigability following SARS-CoV-2 infection. Home-based exercise is a safe and accessible treatment option for addressing fatigability in Veterans recovering from SARS-CoV-2. Importantly, the findings of this project could be applied across numerous Veteran clinical populations experiencing increases in fatigue and fatigability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: Malaria infection in humans, caused by Plasmodium species parasites, is a major global health challenge causing over 400 million deaths worldwide every year, the majority being young children. Despite recent licensure of the first ever malaria vaccine, its low efficacy and recent reports of drug resistance to frontline artemisinin-based therapies in Africa add additional urgency to the pressing need for new druggable targets that that are essential for the parasite lifecycle and with known mechanisms of action and which thus have the potential to stop parasite infection. Our proposal provides a fuller understanding of the function of three essential Plasmodium myosins as druggable targets, defines the effect of small molecule inhibitors on one of these essential myosins, and allows us to discover fundamental insights into malaria parasite cell biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Significant progress in identifying genes that accelerate or slow Alzheimer disease now leads to a critical question, how do these genes act to alter disease progression? We will focus our studies on the impact of these genes on brain vascular pathology which is present in almost all Alzheimer’s disease patients and has been shown to be an early driver of loss of brain function. Because hundreds of genes are potentially involved, we will use large-scale cutting-edge gene editing and screening methods for initial analysis. This will create a prioritized list of genes for focused functional studies in human stem cell models and mouse models. The goal is to identify early events leading to vascular pathology that can be targeted to combat Alzheimer’s disease.

PHR: Despite evidence that the gut microbiome is an important modulator of oxalate metabolism, its role in the pathophysiology of enteric hyperoxaluria (EH) has not been well studied. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is well established that individuals exposed to trauma are at increased risk for both Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD); moreover, there is a high rate of comorbidity of these two disorders. The vast majority of this research has been conducted in adults. In this proposal, we will identify biological predictors of AUD and/or PTSD including genomics, epigenetics, inflammation and psychophysiology in the immediate aftermath of trauma in order to determine which adolescents are at risk to develop these devastating disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This work will enhance the understand the role of tumor niche in B cell lymphomas, while at the same time establish a biomaterials-based modular ex vivo organoid platform with design flexibility for lymphoma subtypes. Mechanisms from the proposed research will increase “predictive power” of pre-clinical small molecule inhibitors for targeted therapies, provide potential biomarkers for correlative studies in clinical trials, and provide clues towards mechanisms that might induce resistance to inhibitors by more faithfully representing patient biological features and creating relevant treatment regimens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: • REASEARCH NARRATIVE • Renal cell carcinoma (RCC), the 8th most common form of adult cancer in the US, is in need of novel therapeutic strategies to overcome resistance to existing treatments. Our preliminary studies have revealed that deregulation of the Hippo-YAP/TAZ pathway represents a major molecular hallmark across most subtypes of RCC, and is a key mechanism used by tumor cells to maintain their transcriptional and metabolic homeostasis. Employing patient-derived RCC tumor models and clinically viable inhibitors, our study will establish the therapeutic potential and mechanisms of actions for YAP/TAZ-based therapies in RCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Chemoenzymatic construction of synthetic human milk oligosaccharide (HMO) glycome Efficient and innovative methods will be developed and related enzymes will be identified for target-oriented chemoenzymatic synthesis of human milk oligosaccharides (HMOs) in a systematic manner. The resulting compounds are important standards for analysis, probes to identify HMO-binding proteins, and reagents to explore the multifaceted applications of HMOs as infant formula additives, potential nutraceuticals and therapeutics. The chemoenzymatic synthetic process is programmable, can be adapted for automation, and readily scalable for large-scale production of HMOs in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - OVERALL Alzheimer's disease (AD) is one of the most urgent health care concerns facing the United States. The Alzheimer’s Disease Research Centers (ADRCs) funded by the NIA provide a national network of resources and researchers aiming to discover the causes and treatments of this disease and related dementias. The Northwestern ADRC is part of this network and serves a leadership role in research on the causes and treatments of AD and related dementias and also on the factors that promote unusually successful brain aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): The Marchigian Sardinian alcohol-preferring (msP) rats represent an unique rat  model in which genetic selection for high alcohol preference has led to co-segregation of elevated  sensitivity to stress and anxiety. The goal of this project is to provide a systematic investigation at the  molecular, neurochemical and behavioral levels of the impact of these heritable factors and biological  mechanisms in the etiology of anxiety and alcohol drinking behavior. These studies may help identify  biological targets for the development of pharmacological treatment for alcoholism and the frequent co-occurrence anxiety related disorders, such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on providing tools and educational material for evaluating and improving the psychometric characteristics of psychophysiological measurements and other trial-wise scores. The project will develop, demonstrate, and disseminate tools to optimize three paradigms for recording event-related potentials (ERPs), time-frequency electroencephalography (EEG), facial electromyography (EMG), and electrodermal activity (EDA) in depression and anxiety, and the developed software, the Psychophysiologist’s Reliability Analysis Toolbox (PsyRAT), will be made openly available to facilitate the application of generalizability theory to novel measures and paradigms. The proposed research is relevant to NIMH’s Research Domain Criteria (RDoC) initiative, which emphasizes dimensional relationships that cut across traditional diagnostic boundaries to foster a better understanding, diagnosis, and treatment of mental illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this cluster-randomized control trial, we will demonstrate the effectiveness of one-stop service pathway to reduce the burden of PrEP visits and cost of PrEP delivery in Kenyan public health settings. We hypothesize that simplified one-stop PrEP service model will significantly shorten client visit time, minimize stigma, and free providers for other work without adversely affecting the quality of PrEP services compared to standard client pathway. This innovative system-focused model will be cost-saving, sustainable, and a model of patient-centered PrEP care for PrEP programs in Kenya and elsewhere in Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infectious diseases pose emerging, ongoing, and evolving threats to society, and physician-scientists dealing with infectious diseases are crucial to meet these challenges. This T32 program will support the research career training of fellows enrolled in the adult and pediatric Infectious Diseases Fellowship Programs at the David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA, who wish to pursue careers as physician-scientists. These trainees will have access to a breadth of infectious diseases-related research ranging from molecular virology to social science across any department at UCLA and its affiliated academic institutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will examine linkages between proximal risk factors, affect regulation, and coping behavior, using survey and ecological momentary assessment (EMA) data from youth experiencing homelessness (YEH). From these data, this project will develop a data-driven app-based just-in-time personal support intervention (JIT-PSI) that delivers responsive messaging to mitigate negative coping in favor of positive coping among YEH. Leveraging growing number of public free WiFi hotspots and shrinking cellphone hardware costs, this project will yield significant public health impacts by developing a sustainable, high-impact JIT behavioral intervention for the prevention of drug use among YEH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Shifts in the composition and function of human-resident microbial communities (microbiomes) are increasingly implicated as determinants of human health. The proposed research program will use in vitro and in vivo model systems to gain mechanistic insight into the ways in bacteriophages (phages) affect the composition and function of gastrointestinal microbiome. This work will provide a foundation for future basic and translational efforts to understand and exploit phage-bacteria-host interactions to mitigate disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The world-wide epidemics of obesity and metabolic syndrome represent a major public health threat that is due in part to increased around-the-clock access to highly-palatable carbohydrate-rich food that leads to impaired glucose tolerance. Our proposed studies build upon our prior work showing an essential role for both brain and peripheral clocks in regulating hunger and whole-body glucose metabolism. Our new project will elucidate (i) the role of the clock in -cell insulin secretion in morning and night and (ii) how brain clocks balance the rival needs to eat and sleep, findings which will elucidate the basis for impaired glucose tolerance in obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Heat exposure is a contributor to dehydration and therefore can affect kidney function. We propose to investigate the relationship between heat (outdoor high temperatures and heat waves) and presentations of acute kidney injury (AKI) at emergency departments in Atlanta, GA. With a focus on improved AKI case ascertainment, heat exposure assessment, and identification of heat-vulnerable populations, this work will fill major gaps in the epidemiology of heat and AKI that will ultimately support public health prevention and clinical case management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with disabilities affecting communication (e.g., hearing, speech, language disabilities) experience significant disparities in the receipt of high-quality, equitable healthcare services. To understand and address disparities in care, healthcare organizations need to systematically document patients’ disability status in the electronic health record and then use that data meaningfully. This project will test implementation strategies to support primary care practices in (a) systematically documenting patients’ communication disabilities and needs in the electronic health record, and (b) providing needed disability accommodations, with the overarching goal of promoting equitable healthcare for individuals with communication disabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The focus of our research proposal is to dissect the neuronal and cellular mechanisms underlying alterations in opioid circuits that lead to opioid misuse in pain conditions and in a sex-dependent manner. Findings generated from the proposed research will provide critical insight on the circuit-based mechanisms underlying pain-induced increase in opioid intake with an insight on sex differences, transforming our understanding of opioid misuse and abuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Autistic children have difficulty understanding texts with more social texts like narrative fiction stories compared to less social texts like expository nonfiction. The goal of this project is to examine how child factors related to children’s language and social communication abilities as well as text factors related to the complexity of linguistic and social information in a text predict autistic children’s comprehension of more and less social stories. This project sets the stage to develop clinical tools and a dynamic intervention approach that adjusts texts to meet child profiles of comprehension and instructional needs for individualized intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL Targeted radionuclide therapies are a type of cancer treatment that can be injected into a patient’s vein and, after circulating through the patient’s body, these will preferentially accumulate in tumors and selectively deliver radiation to these locations. Radiation can damage tumors in a way makes them more susceptible to being killed by a patient’s own immune cells. Here, we will evaluate what effects targeted radionuclide therapies have on immune recognition of tumor cells and we will test whether these agents may enhance response to diverse forms of cancer immunotherapy – all in an effort to develop non-toxic, curative treatment approaches for patients with metastatic cancers of any type.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 1 Our immune system protects us from the majority of invasive diseases but cancer cells are often able to avoid detection by our immune system. It has recently been discovered that combining radiotherapy with immunotherapy is more effective than either treatment alone. Conventional radiation therapy typically cannot treat all tumor sites in patients with metastatic disease because of potential side effects and because of its inability to target small tumors that are not seen on imaging scans. We have overcome these limitations by combining radioactive tumor-seeking molecules with different types of immunotherapy, and our goal is to determine how this type of treatment renders tumors more responsive to immunotherapy and to ultimately use imaging to optimize this treatment approach for cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Major pregnancy complications such as preeclampsia, preterm labor and intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) are leading causes of maternal/fetal morbidity and mortality in the US and worldwide. Immune cell dysregulation in the maternal reproductive tract are thought to be involved in the development of these conditions, but how the immune population in the uterus is regulated is poorly understood. We will develop novel approaches to study the trafficking of immune cells between the blood and the maternal-fetal interface in pregnant rhesus macaques to establish how a healthy immune population is established in the uterus in pregnancy.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To improve patient health and prevent healthcare associated infections (HAIs) due to antibiotic resistant organisms (AROs), it is critical to prevent the transmission and acquisition of AROs from the hospital environment to vulnerable patients. Our work will address these issues by 1) leveraging an established biospecimen repository of AROs isolated from both patients and the intensive care room (ICU) environment to define ARO transmission between the hospital environment and patients, and 2) by implementing and evaluating environmental hygiene strategies to reduce ARO burden in the ICU environment. This project will lead to better, more targeted approaches to preventing ARO transmission and preventing HAIs.

PROJECT_TITLE: Environmental hygiene strategies to decrease the burden of antibiotic-resistant organisms in Intensive Care Unit SINKs (ICU SINK)
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 2 Metastatic cancers are typically incurable, despite advances in cancer treatments including immunotherapies, and to begin changing this we propose to develop and investigate a new treatment approach that combines the most common form of immunotherapy (immune checkpoint inhibitors) with targeted radionuclide therapy. Radiation can damage tumors in a way that renders them more responsive to immunotherapies, however conventional radiation therapy typically cannot treat all tumor sites in patients with metastatic disease because of toxicities and the inability to target small tumors that are not identified on imaging scans. Targeted radionuclide therapies injected into a patient’s vein go throughout the body to preferentially deliver radiation to tumors wherever they are located and here we will (1) determine the effect of this type of treatment on the susceptibility of tumors to immune response; and (2) test the effectiveness of this type of treatment when combined with the most common form of immunotherapy in order to determine which combinations should be most beneficial in patients with metastatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The research aims proposed in this application focus on a better understanding of the role of slow wave sleep in post-stroke recovery, the leading cause of adult disability in the US with annual incidence of 800,000 and with over 7 million stroke survivors. This research has the potential to clarify the basic mechanisms of how slow wave sleep regulates neuronal repair and recovery after stroke. Ultimately, this knowledge may identify novel therapies that could enhance recovery after stroke, which would greatly improve health for patients, reduce disability, and enrich quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 3 We are developing a new approach, representing a dramatic shift in the treatment of high-risk pediatric and adult cancers. Our strategy utilizes immune responses to recognize and destroy cancer (immunotherapy) in combination with low-dose radiation therapy, which substantially improves the anti-tumor potency of the immunotherapy regimens we are creating. In our novel approach, we will administer a low-dose, targeted radionuclide that can be injected into a vein and preferentially deliver molecular radiotherapy to primary, local, and distant tumors throughout the body. We will combine this with immunotherapy approaches in mouse models of different childhood cancers to determine which combinations may lead to the most beneficial strategies to cure high-risk pediatric and adult cancers in humans and advance the National Cancer Institute’s mission to help people live longer, healthier lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The UCSC Graduate Program in Genome Science is designed to train the next generation of scientific leaders in genome sciences, a discipline that is critical to development of new therapies—from cancer to heritable disease. UCSC has been a leader in genomics research since the field was founded and offers a rich interdisciplinary genomics training environment. Our program spans 26 training faculty from 8 departments and combines formal training in statistics, programming, and engineering with more traditional disciplines, such as molecular biology and genetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aspergillus fumigatus is a ubiquitous inhaled mold that causes devastating infections in immunocompromised patients, even with receipt of contemporary antifungal drugs. The goal of this proposal is to integrate two novel regulatory circuits that involve lung endothelial and epithelial cells as well as plasmacytoid dendritic cells in a comprehensive model of anti-Aspergillus innate immunity in the lung. Our findings should give rise to novel strategies for enhancing immune function against this fungal pathogen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 4 We have recently identified that targeted radionuclide therapy (TRT) at doses lower than those that cause direct anti-tumor effects and in combination with anti-tumor vaccination can elicit greater anti-tumor effects than either treatment alone. Given that both of these approaches are in clinical testing as treatments for prostate cancer, an immunologically “cold” tumor, this project focuses on combinations of anti-tumor vaccination with low dose TRT as treatments for prostate cancer. The goals of this project are to understand the impact of these treatments on antigen-specific tumor-infiltrating CD8+ T cells to understand optimal treatment approaches that can be evaluated in future human clinical trials for the treatment of human prostate cancer, which will ultimately advance the National Cancer Institute’s mission to help people live longer, healthier lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Acute kidney injury is a medical condition that complicates ~20% of all hospital admissions and is a strong predictor of mortality. In this study, we aim to develop pharmaceutically acceptable forms of CO for the treatment of acute kidney injury caused by surgery, trauma, crush, or other forms injuries.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Volume-regulated anion channels (VRACs) are plasma membrane proteins that perform essential physiological functions. VRACs and the genes that encode them are implicated in multiple diseases including diabetes, obesity, cancer, and immunity. Our proposed studies utilize a novel chimeric approach to better define VRAC structure-function relationships, which are essential for understanding VRAC associated diseases and developing new drugs that specifically modify VRAC activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The EvolvingSTEM program will use a research-education partnership to educate high school introductory biology students about evolutionary biology, microbiology, and their impact on human health using authentic experimentation and 21st century bioinformatic skills. It has broad potential for increasing understanding of evolution, an important, yet widely misunderstood, life science concept, which will improve public literacy of its role in biomedical advances and public health. The findings from our proposal will improve design and implementation of research experiences that expose high school students (including those from underrepresented groups) to research methods and concepts that are not typically available in conventional classroom activities, and determine whether particular interventions (e.g., near-peer mentorship, student-driven inquiry) lead to sustained engagement in STEM and pursuit of STEM-related careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This application seeks to continue long-standing support for the UCSD Medical Scientist (M.D./Ph.D.) Training Program (MSTP), which combines both M.D. (through an Integrated Scientific Curriculum in the UCSD School of Medicine) and Ph.D. training in areas of the biomedical sciences, including cellular and molecular biology, neuroscience, and bioengineering. Excellent trainees are recruited throughout the United States and graduates typically pursue careers as academic physician scientists. This MSTP has evolved through not only expanding research opportunities and support at UCSD and affiliated institutions (Salk Institute for Biological Sciences and the Scripps Research Institute) but also growing a pool of diverse, high quality applicants and faculty.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - ADVANCED IMAGING AND DOSIMETRY CORE 2 The Advanced Imaging and Dosimetry Core (AIDC) will provide dedicated expertise and cost-efficient support required to facilitate quantitative multiscale imaging and dosimetry calculations for the P01 application, “Molecular Targeted Radionuclide Therapy for Tumor Immunomodulation and Enhancing Immunotherapy Response.” This centralized dosimetry service core is critical for the P01 to achieve its overarching research goals of 1) developing a broad mechanistic understanding of the immunomodulatory capacity of molecular targeted radionuclide therapy (TRT) and 2) evaluating TRT as part of the next generation immunotherapy approaches to improve the treatment of immunologically “hot” and “cold” tumors.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic stress exposure can lead to long-term stress disorders and represents a considerable risk factor for suicide. Stress disorders such as posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) have significant links with suicidality and present an enormous health and financial burden on society. Stress disorders are characterized by plasticity of neural circuits and neurochemical signaling in the amygdala, an emotional center of the brain. We will use genetically engineered mouse models and viral delivery of light- and designer drug-activated channels and receptors to manipulate brain circuits to study inhibitory circuits in the amygdala involved in fear memory formation. We will use a traumatic stress mouse model to determine whether inhibitory circuits in the amygdala undergo long-term changes in response to trauma that lead to stress-associated pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Therapies to treat Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, the types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) characterized by severe chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, have greatly improved over the past three decades; yet, a large proportion of IBD patients fail to achieve sustained remission. Extensive accumulating data suggest that normalization of LRRK2 (leucine-rich repeat kinase 2) activity may be an attractive therapeutic strategy to treat IBD. We are proposing to develop novel, highly potent, gut-restricted LRRK2 inhibitors and test their tolerance, toxicity, and efficacy using in vitro and in vivo studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Observational data, including electronic health records (EHR) and claims data, provide tremendous opportunities for clinical and translational research for Alzheimer's Disease and Alzheimer's Disease Related Dementia (AD/ADRD). A key challenge is observational AD/ADRD research is to better manage and analyze phenotypic data. This project aims at developing novel informatics methods and tools to manage phenotype definitions and correct bias associated with phenotyping errors on local data, thus enhancing the reproducibility and quality of observational studies on AD/ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain is a leading cause of disability in the US and globally, especially among older adults, yet management options are limited and fundamental knowledge regarding causes and consequences of chronic overlapping pain conditions is lacking. We propose an inter-disciplinary study of chronic overlapping pain conditions in older African American adults who have been understudied in this regard, with a focus on neurophysiologic alterations, healthy lifestyle factors and psychosocial factors as underlying risk factors, and the impact of chronic overlapping pain conditions and neurophysiologic alterations in pain processing on physical and psychosocial function, ability to live independently, and mortality risk. The proposed work will bring new insights into chronic pain as a condition itself regardless of anatomic location of pain, with an aim to help the millions suffering from chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sexual and gender minority (SGM) youth are at higher risk for suicidal ideation and attempts than their heterosexual and cisgender counterparts; yet, this community faces many barriers that complicate the implementation of suicide prevention programs. In this project, we aim to adapt, implement and test an empirically-informed, multicomponent youth suicide prevention program, Behavioral-Health Works, in organizations serving this population. We will evaluate primary program outcomes (increased suicide identification and successful referrals), secondary outcomes (program acceptability), and exploratory program mechanisms (training impact, partnership development, software usability, and caregiver involvement).

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Better methods are needed to identify and mitigate any risks of misdiagnosis during telemedicine visits. In this project we will first understand what aspects of telemedicine may involve risks of misdiagnosis, then develop electronic methods to identify telemedicine visits where misdiagnosis may have occurred, and finally use all this knowledge to develop risk assessment guidance tools that health care organizations, providers, and patients can use to reduce any risks of misdiagnosis associated with telemedicine.

PROJECT_TITLE: Developing e-Triggers to Detect Telemedicine Related Diagnostic Safety Events

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use is a common risk factor for both HIV acquisition and poor uptake and use of effective biomedical HIV prevention options, including pre- and post-exposure prophylaxis, in sub-Saharan Africa. This study will test innovative interventions to increase uptake and use of biomedical HIV prevention options by engaging women and men at drinking venues in rural Kenya and Uganda in care and evaluating a brief alcohol counseling intervention among adults with heavy alcohol use at high risk for HIV, while gaining insights into the facilitators, barriers, and cost-effectiveness of these approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is the most prevalent cause of visual disability in developed nations. We identified a protein that is involved in the production of leaky blood vessels and scarring in the space beneath the retina, which characterizes the most severe forms of AMD. We will test whether inhibiting the function of this protein reduces new blood vessel growth, leakiness, and scarring and therefore may be a target for the development of new drugs to treat AMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Some patients’ immune system can be triggered with immunotherapies, leading to their cure. Those patients have a collection of ‘reactive’ immune cells in their tumors, and this proposal will figure out how to support that immune system so that even patients without those cells can be cured.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: There is a critical need for a diverse group of highly trained basic and clinical oral health researchers. If effective preventive therapies and cures for the many diseases associated with the oral, dental and craniofacial complex are to be discovered and applied, a cadre of oral health researchers must be trained to work in interdisciplinary teams and to maintain the highest standards for ethical and responsible conduct of rigorous scientific research. The main objective of this comprehensive training program is to produce oral health researchers who can apply state-of-the-art technologies to generate new knowledge, translate that information to applied therapies, and rigorously evaluate the outcomes of implementation of novel preventive or treatment strategies to improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Interleukin 6 (IL-6) trans-signaling is a non-canonical IL-6 signaling paradigm that is a modifier of inflammatory disease and enhanced by the inheritance of the common mutation IL6R Asp358Ala. We will use our robust, novel C57BL/6 Il6raE357A mouse model of enhanced IL-6 trans-signaling to investigate whether enhanced IL-6 trans-signaling worsens cardiac function and fibrosis in a model of cardiac pressure overload, and whether IL-6R blocking therapeutic interventions may will prevent or attenuate cardiac fibrosis and HF, and we will utilize spatial transcriptomics to identify the type and location of cells in cardiac tissue that are responding to IL-6 trans- signaling. The results of this study will provide insight into how IL-6 trans-signaling modifies disease pathology, cardiac fibrosis, and heart failure, and response to IL-6R blocking therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The aggregation and deposition of Amyloid-beta and tau are crucial pathological hallmarks of Alzheimer’s Disease (AD), but it remains unknown why certain cells and brain regions are vulnerable to their aggregation, and others less. The proposed project from the Switch Laboratory in VIB Flanders Institute for Biotechnology aims to perform a systematic search for potential interacting partners based on the sequence- and structure- specificity of aggregation in a project that starts with a computational search and then proceeds to verify potential interactor proteins in cells, in live animals, and using an extensive array of biophysics assays. This research may lead to a major breakthrough in current treatments of AD by providing a structural model with which the entire set of proteins within brain cells can be screened for potential interactors with the aggregates normally found in AD, providing potential therapeutic value.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Three-quarters of survivors of mechanical ventilation will develop persistent disability. Early mobilization engages patients in physical activity during mechanical ventilation to prevent disability, but has poor adoption into clinical practice. This proposal aims to apply precision medicine to identify patients who are most likely to benefit from early mobilization and elucidate how it can be implemented successfully to extend the benefits of early mobili- zation to patients at risk for long-term disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parkinson's disease (PD) patients treated with deep brain stimulation (DBS) of the subthalamic nucleus (STN) have unpredictable and varied speech outcomes after this treatment. Our research will prospectively document speech performance before, during and 6- and 12-months after STN-DBS in 80 surgically treated patients and compared with 40 non-surgical PD controls. This study will provide unique insights into the role of STN in speech production, document speech outcome in a comprehensive fashion, identify factors that predict functional communication ability 12 months after STN-DBS, and test the feasibility of low frequency DBS in reversing DBS-induced speech declines in order to optimize treatment strategies for those living with PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plasmodium ovale and Plasmodium vivax are resistant to many current malaria control interventions, due to evolutionary advantages affecting transmission and relapse. They are increasingly identified in infections in Africa and, in the case of vivax, potentially evolving to overcome limitations to red blood cell invasion. This proposal seeks to provide the evidence base and to develop tools needed to face challenges associated with control of relapsing malarias by providing fundamental knowledge about the infectious reservoir and vectors involved in transmission, developing tools to understand relapse and defining mechanisms by which vivax malaria may be evolving to expand its range and impact in Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Combing auditory and visual speech information (multisensory integration) is important to an infant’s ability to learn to speak. Non-invasive multimodal brain imaging and infant vocalization analysis is used to investigate 1) the neural correlates of multisensory integration in infants, 2) brain-behavioral associations, and 3) whether multisensory brain measures obtained at 9-12 months can predict speech/language outcome and delays at 2 years old.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Pregnancy and breastfeeding are periods of high HIV acquisition risk for African women. Oral pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) can prevent HIV infection, yet PrEP adherence during pregnancy and postpartum is sub- optimal due to specific issues women face during this period that could be addressed by real-time SMS communication with a health worker. We propose a randomized trial to determine the effect of a bidirectional SMS communication tool (mWACh-PrEP) on PrEP adherence during pregnancy and postpartum and we will collect data on implementation and cost to expedite translation into routine practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Melanoma is the deadliest type of skin cancer because it rapidly and widely metastasizes. While cancer cells require significant metabolic rewiring for metastasis, the metabolic pathways essential for melanoma metastasis are poorly understood. Here, we propose to identify the critical metabolic functions of the metastatic suppressor GAPDHS (glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase, spermatogenic) and determine its role in melanoma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many children in underserved communities face food insecurity, which can adversely impact behavioral disorders. The study will use medical claims data linked to educational outcomes for Arkansas public schoolchildren to test whether school meal delivery options that make it easier to participate in child nutrition programs lead to improvements in discipline and academic performance at school. The study will also determine whether school meal delivery policies can reduce the diagnosis of behavioral disorders and associated healthcare utilization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is an increasingly common cause of neurodegeneration in society today, and the leading environmental cause for Alzheimer's disease (AD)1–5. Mitochondrial fission/fusion activity has been identified as a significant player in neuronal deterioration in several neurodegenerative diseases, including TBI, AD, Huntington's, and Parkinson's diseases, and my preliminary results suggest that this process is also critically involved in both the acute and chronic progression of neurodegeneration after TBI. Here, I propose to fully characterize the role of mitochondrial fission in TBI, and establish its utility as a pharmacologic target for treatment, with the ultimate goal being to expand our understanding of how TBI and AD are connected and facilitate the development of a new neuroprotective treatment for TBI and its resulting acceleration AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed studies aim to reveal new molecular and cellular mechanisms for learning, memory and synaptic plasticity involving the role of a specific biochemical pathway controlling protein synthesis and the process of cholinergic neuromodulation. The knowledge gained may uncover new molecular targets to consider for therapy development for a wide range of human disorders, including aging and memory-related conditions. Mechanisms revealed specifically in the basal ganglia circuitry may further provide insights helpful for a range of conditions that include Parkinson's disease, dystonia, Tourette's syndrome, addiction, Obsessive compulsive disorder and autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Working memory is the ability to think about information that is not present in the environment and to use it guide behavior. Its impairment is characteristic of many psychopathologies and psychiatric syndromes, including attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), major depressive disorder (MDD), and schizophrenia. These experiments will study how the brain controls working memory, and may provide results that could be useful for developing diagnostic tools and treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML), a fatal childhood blood cancer, has limited therapeutic options. Relapse remains the main cause of treatment failure, most likely due to the persistence of leukemic stem cells, a small population of self-renewing precursor cells that is responsible for the long-term maintenance of leukemia growth and is also a major source of drug resistance. The project proposed in this application explores a novel strategy to eradicate these tumor initiating cells in a subset of JMML caused by genetic mutations in Ptpn11.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 100,000 individuals suffer from aphasia each year. The academy of aphasia is an organization of clinicians, scientists and practitioners who study this communication disorder and develop interventions to treat individuals with aphasia. The members comprise a very interdisciplinary group of linguists, psychologists, speech and language clinicians, neurologists and neuroscientists. The annual academy of aphasia meeting is the premier venue to share state of the art methodologies for application in the study of aphasia to improve the research in the development of diagnosis and treatment approaches to alleviate aphasia. This conference is also the ideal venue to educate and train the next generation of aphasia researchers who are well trained from a theoretical, technical and clinical standpoint and are committed to expand the impact of research in aphasia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Schizophrenia is a highly heritable neurodevelopmental disorder, but the mechanisms behind how schizophrenia genetic risk loci function is not clear. Cortical interneurons are substantially affected in schizophrenia and enriched for schizophrenia heritability during development. The proposed study is aimed at identifying schizophrenia risk loci that are active in these neurons during development, which will provide insights on the developmental mechanisms of SCZ risks, and help identify novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Three-dimensional brightfield and bioluminescent microscopy has provided meaningful insights into biology with small animals, parasites, and large bacteria. Existing tools that perform this type of imaging cost between thousands and tens of thousands of US dollars, which limits the research to well-resourced laboratories. We propose to use 3D printed parts, laser cut acrylic, and commercially available components to create tomographic microscope of this type with a smartphone for less than $50, which would provide this type of microscopy to less-resourced laboratories and to remote locations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with locally-advanced cervical cancer with lymph node metastases exhibit poor prognosis despite the current standard of care therapy with chemotherapy and radiation. There is thus a critical need to develop new therapeutic strategies for patients with high-risk cervical cancer and to identify biomarkers that could predict which patients are more likely to benefit. The current proposal will take advantage of tumor and blood samples collected from high-risk cervical cancer patients treated on an NCI-funded clinical trial of immunotherapy combined with chemotherapy and radiation to determine optimal sequencing of immunotherapy and radiation and to identify the patients that do or do not benefit from this approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stuttering profoundly impacts quality of life, mental health, and social, educational, and occupational success for millions of Americans and approximately 55 million worldwide. The proposed research addresses this critical public health need by contributing fundamental knowledge about the role of attention in core emotional features of stuttering. Through a multi-paradigm approach that synthesizes behavioral and eye-tracking indices of attention bias, the project examines associations between threat-related patterns of attention allocation and stuttering, providing a foundation for the development of novel interventions designed to target emotional responses to stuttering by reshaping underlying attention patterns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lupus is a debilitating autoimmune disease that damages vital organs and is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Current therapies can be effective but work on only a subset of patients and suffer from significant side effects, and new therapies are urgently needed. Here we test whether a newly developed inhibitor of the enzyme deoxycytidine kinase can limit disease in a mouse model of lupus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: BENAROYA RESEARCH INST AT VIRGINIA MASON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Systemic lupus erythematosus is a complex autoimmune disease that affects up to 1.5 million Americans; up to half of people with lupus have a serious kidney disease called lupus nephritis. Though how doctors treat lupus nephritis has improved over the years, few drugs to treat lupus nephritis exist and the underlying mechanisms of disease are still being discovered. Here, we propose a cutting-edge method to identify genes that affect one new mechanism of lupus nephritis involving a specialized white blood cell called patrolling monocytes with the goal to not only learn new information about how lupus nephritis develops, but to also identify new proteins that may serve as targets for future therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to improve our understanding of how genetic and non-genetic factors affect drug metabolism and drug response in patients from understudied ethnic backgrounds. This research is important to individualize drug treatment for patients to maximize beneficial drug effects (efficacy) and minimize serious side effects (toxicity). This work will lay the foundation needed to implement precision medicine for ethnically diverse patient populations to achieve the right drug at the right dose for the right patient at the right time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In partnership with Mental Health America (MHA), a non-profit mental health advocacy group offering free, evidence-based screenings and self-guided digital mental health (DMH) resources, the proposed research aims to identify and test tailored strategies to optimize sexual and gender minority (SGM) consumers' engagement with MHA's DMH content. The use of an existing DMH infrastructure, a large, naturalistic sample, and methods such as supervised machine learning, human-centered design approaches, and micro-randomized trial design provide an innovative approach to optimize DMH engagement outcomes among SGM consumers. This study addresses several key objectives outlined within Goal 4 of the NIMH Strategic Plan—to strengthen the public health impact of NIMH-supported research—including improving access, delivery, and quality of mental health care (Objective 4.1) and promoting mental health equity for SGM populations (Objective 4.3).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Our goal is to find new ways to treat CLN1 disease or Infantile Neuronal Ceroid Lipofuscinosis (or Infantile Batten disease), a fatal neurodegenerative disorder of childhood. Based on the therapeutic advances we have made in CLN1 mice, we now propose scaling up our AAV9-mediated gene therapy approach in a CRISPR/Cas9 generated sheep model of this disorder. Defining the affected regions of the CNS, the neurologic consequences, and optimizing vector delivery routes will allow us to test the efficacy, dosing and safety of gene therapy in CLN1 R151X sheep in order to define a strategy that is clinically translatable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Impairments in eating, dysfunctional swallowing, and aerodigestive symptoms in infants are a notable public health concern and contribute to significant socio-economic burdens such as prolonged hospital stays, neuro- developmental delays, or death and parental suffering. This proposal addresses a critical need in neonatal gas- troenterology by examining unique swallowing mechanisms, and defining the basis for preventative and correc- tive therapies by employing new translational research initiatives. Our research aligns closely with NIDDK's mis- sion to conduct and support medical research on digestive diseases and nutritional disorders that will impact the quality of life of infants and parents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of strategies and interventions for preventing or minimizing violent behavior in individuals with psychotic disorders has been limited, in part, by a lack of information about the effects of antipsychotic medications, and in particular clozapine, on violent acts in community settings. In this project, we will determine whether clozapine, when administered in real-world settings, decreases the risk for violent acts in individuals with schizophrenia at high risk for violence when compared to treatment with other antipsychotic medications, and investigate whether previously identified change mechanisms are operative in the effectiveness setting. Examining clozapine in this way will foster a better understanding of the effects of clozapine on violent acts in community settings and allow us to test a scalable intervention and service delivery approaches that can be broadly implemented using typically available resources, and as such has significant public health implications.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescent intimate partner violence (IPV) is widespread, and states are increasingly enacting laws that require school districts to adopt policies for addressing IPV. The proposed research aims to assess the impact of state IPV laws on reducing adolescent IPV, assess if and how high schools in the U.S. implement these laws, and develop and test a toolkit to guide implementation. Findings will provide actionable evidence for schools that carry out the laws, state and local departments of education that provide guidance and hold schools accountable for implementing the laws, and policymakers who may amend or create laws in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure represents one of the most significant burdens to patients of advanced age and often presents with sarcopenia, or muscle wasting, which is independently predictive of poor outcomes. The objective of this project is to develop a novel quantitative magnetic resonance imaging technology and use it to characterize the skeletal muscle and myocardium in heart failure patients with sarcopenia. This project will advance the career development pursued by the investigator as well as provide a novel imaging tool that can help to improve the assessment, and potentially the clinical management, of heart failure patients with sarcopenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The aging population in the United States exacerbates the economic and societal impacts of neurodegenerative disorders, which are among the leading causes of death and disability in the elderly. Novel therapeutic targets need to be investigated to address these illnesses, including improving understanding the molecular mechanisms of their inhibition. This proposal describes the development of first-row transition metal catalyzed transformations to provide laboratory routes to generate structurally diverse complex molecules that are inhibitors of PTP1B, a protein recently implicated in neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Autoimmune diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus, are debilitating and highly prevalent chronic conditions. The strongest genetic associations lie within the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) genes, which play a critical role in activating the immune system, but exactly how HLA variants increase risk for autoimmunity is not fully understood. This project will use paired genomic and single-cell transcriptomic data from inflamed human tissues to explore how genetic variants regulate HLA expression, link these effects to specific disease-driving cell states, and improve our understanding of how autoimmunity is initiated and hopefully lead to new treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Statement of Relevance: Ozone (O3) is a recognized cause of environmental lung injury and contributes to exacerbations of chronic pulmonary diseases and overall mortality. A critical component of addressing this public health concern must focus on understanding how O3 induces inflammation and how this response is exacerbated by prior respiratory viral infections, such as SARS-CoV2. Here we define the roles of distinct macrophage subsets in the severity and persistence of O3-induced inflammation and explore a potential targeted immune intervention to modulate O3-derived effects on respiratory health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Musculoskeletal (MSK) disorders are among the most prevalent chronic conditions, and a leading cause of global disability and pain. Multiple studies have confirmed that medical students lack competency and training opportunities in this domain and therefore have difficulty performing and interpreting the results of MSK physical examinations which can lead to reduced patient outcomes. Inadequate foundational competence in MSK medicine at an early level of training increases the potential for diagnostic and management errors for future physicians.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The emergence of antibiotic-resistant gonorrhea poses an immense threat to public health. Despite successes in identifying the genetic basis of antibiotic resistance, the genes and pathways that modulate the fitness costs incurred by resistance-conferring alleles and thus facilitate the acquisition and maintenance of these resistance determinants remain poorly understood. This proposal will address these gaps by applying a synergistic combination of approaches: identifying new compensatory mutations during competitive co-infections in the mouse model of gonorrhea, application of systematic population genomics-informed methods to identify compensatory mutations in human isolates, and comprehensive experimental analysis to define their mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding novel mechanisms by which a biological pathway finetunes metabolism and controls cellular respiration will unveil a new and alternative strategy to treating patients with defects in metabolism and mitochondria diseases. The research proposed aims at understanding the fundamental aspects of the UFM1 post-translational modification (UFMylation) and its undescribed roles in controlling cellular metabolism and mitochondrial function. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIGMS’ mission that pertains to understanding biological processes and laying the foundation for the treatment of metabolic and mitochondrial diseases broadly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Degenerative disc disease (DDD) is a major source of low back pain that represents a tremendous financial burden to the public health. This project will develop a novel, minimal-invasive approach for the treatment of DDD that relies on enhancing the regenerative and anti-inflammatory capacity of extracellular vesicles (EV) derived from mesenchymal stem cells using state-of-the-art gene editing technology. Successful completion of this study will guide future development of EV-based therapy not only for DDD, but for example also for osteoarthritis in the hands, neck, knees, and hips, which could benefit millions of people in the United States every year.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative When the decrease in insulin sensitivity during pregnancy is excessive, it results in poor pregnancy outcomes such as gestational diabetes. We hypothesized that the placenta expresses and releases small molecules called microRNA that act on the placenta and other maternal tissues such as muscle, liver, and adipose tissues to impact insulin sensitivity. Our studies will help to understand how microRNA from the placenta regulate insulin sensitivity in pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The metabotropic glutamate receptor (mGluR) family are G protein coupled receptors that are activated by the neurotransmitter glutamate and function as dimers. To date, there has been no efficient strategy by which pure populations of mGluR heterodimers can be expressed in isolation so that the effects of pharmacological tools can be tested. The proposed project will utilize a novel composition control method for generating pure populations of mGluR dimers, then utilize this system to generate an mGluR compound vs. dimer activity atlas from which we hope to gain a better understanding of mGluR physiology and more targeted therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance to Public Health Meiosis, a specialized cell division that generates sex cells such as sperm and eggs, is essential for the inheritance of genomes from parent to offspring. Errors in this process lead to the production of cells with an abnormal number of chromosomes or aneuploidy, and this is a major cause of miscarriages and birth defects such as Down syndrome. Our findings from this study will elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying chromosome inheritance during meiosis and will also have general impact in the fields of cell cycle regulation and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: There is a critical need for identifying molecular mechanisms underlying remyelination failure in multiple sclerosis, the most common demyelinating disorder with no therapies directly targeting myelin repair. The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding the function and molecular mechanisms of PARP1 in oligodendrocyte myelin formation provides new insights into devising new strategies for myelin repair. Thus, this proposal is in line with the NIH's mission – uncovering new knowledge of PARP1 in myelin formation and repair which will potentially lead to novel remyelination-promoting therapies for demyelinating disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because the GGGGCC hexanucleotide repeat expansion in the C9orf72 locus is the most common cause of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and the related neurodegenerative disorder, frontotemporal dementia (FTD). We propose to apply our DNA methylation editing tools to study the epigenetic mechanisms contributing to the pathogenesis of C9orf72 ALS/FTD. Precise editing of C9orf72 methylation will establish the functional role of these epigenetic events in the pathogenesis of C9orf72 ALS/FTD and demonstrate the therapeutic potential that editing methylation may have for the most commonly known cause of ALS/FTD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals who have insomnia with short sleep duration (ISS) differ from individuals who have insomnia with normal sleep duration (INS) in terms of health risks and treatment response. This study will examine whether patients with ISS and INS demonstrate a differential response to two common insomnia treatments, cognitive- behavioral treatment of insomnia (CBT-I) and trazodone. Our findings could lead to evidence-based treatment guidelines that help clinicians more effectively match treatments to insomnia patients and reduce associated health problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bleeding into the heart muscles (myocardium), termed myocardial hemorrhage, is a side-effect of standardized interventions to re-establish blood flow to the heart; myocardial hemorrhage occurs in 50% of acute myocardial infarction and contributes to heart failure complications. This bleeding, however, cannot be easily detected in the acute setting by existing imaging technology; in essence, we cannot treat what we are unable to diagnose and monitor. Successful development of a reliable, quantitative cardiac magnetic resonance imaging technique to spatially track acute myocardial bleeding and creation of a patient-adaptive disease model based on structure-function relationships will provide a new path for tailoring therapy and improving heart failure outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it evaluates the potential of human musicality – a universal and highly variable trait in the general population – as a protective factor against the inevitable rapid decline in hearing health as people age. Findings from this study will establish necessary groundwork for eventually identifying individuals’ risk and resilience profiles for age-related hearing loss based on their musicality – including aptitude, engagement, and genetic predispositions. This project is therefore relevant to the NIH’s mission to gain insights into the nature and behavior of living systems and to apply this knowledge to reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative During human development and in adult tissues undergoing repair, stem cells combine, or ‘integrate’, information from a number of extracellular signaling cues to decide what cell types they should become. This proposal seeks to understand how signaling information is integrated within the cell by a set of interconnected genes, called bHLH transcription factors, using experiments in mouse neural stem cells and zebrafish embryos. Insights gained through this work could help improve the generation of desired cell types for tissue engineering and provide new opportunities to remedy errors in signal integration that lead to developmental disorders or cancers.
