IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public health relevance The past decades have seen dramatic increases in the prevalence of allergic diseases, however, our understanding of what drive these aberrant lung inflammatory responses is limited. We have identified a new subset of macrophages that explicitly drive aberrant allergic responses. The long-term goal of this project is the development of novel therapies that directly address the pathogenesis of patients with allergic airway diseases, underserved by current treatment modalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Resilience of blood pressure is the ability of the circulatory system to anticipate, resist, absorb, adapt and recover in response to stressors. Emerging data indicate that our blood pressure fluctuates daily as we go about our daily activities and these blood pressure responses affect our health, including our memory. In this project, we will study blood pressure responses to common daily stressors (mental activity, standing and walking) to clarify if resilience of blood pressure (‘bouncing back’ after stimuli) affects our health, especially heart disease, brain health and cognition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Older sexual minority men (e.g., gay and bisexual men; OSMM) are the only age bracket of SMM experiencing an increase (rather than plateau or decrease) of new HIV diagnoses in the U.S.; yet research addressing factors perpetuating this disparity is lacking.1 This dissertation study integrates three complementary theories - syndemic2, minority stress3,4, and intersectionality5 – and utilizes innovative statistical techniques to explore whether a unique set of age-related psychosocial factors (e.g., age-related discrimination, internalized ageism, aging anxiety, sexual minority specific aging concerns, social isolation, economic marginalization, and perceived cognitive impairment) interact synergistically to exacerbate HIV risk and reduce quality of life, above and beyond traditional syndemic conditions (e.g., substance use) among OSMM living in Florida, a state with one of the highest HIV incidence rates in the nation.6 Findings from this study will not only further NIH and U.S. Ending the HIV Epidemic priorities for HIV/AIDS research7,8, but also catapult an emerging investigator’s programmatic research in behavioral health and health disparities among OSMM, a marginalized, intersectionally invisible population.9,10

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Regulation of spiny excitatory synapses by Rho-GEFs is crucial for brain development and in neurodevelopmental disorders. Here we will investigate the role of the kalirin/Trio->Rac1->Pak axis in basal brain function and in preclinical models of NDDs characterized by excessive synaptic connectivity. We will also test whether inhibition of this pathway can reverse deficits in mouse models relevant for NDDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Asthma is a chronic disease of the lungs, which has been on the rise in recent decades. Our studies strongly suggest that autophagy play a central role in induction of allergic inflammation. Studies in this proposal aim to elucidate the autophagy pathways in the lungs. The identification of autophagy specific inducers may lead to the development of novel, effective therapies for the treatment of this ever-increasing disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sudden cardiac death (SCD) is a leading cause of death in the United States and those patients who do not meet diagnostic syndromic criteria to explain the etiology of their SCD event are labeled as having Idiopathic Ventricular Fibrillation (IVF). IVF patients lack morphologic, genetic, or ECG biomarkers to risk stratify and determine treatment, making clinical management haphazard causing high morbidity and mortality. We propose to integrate a comprehensive functional and multiomic analysis of IVF patient-specific induced pluripotent stem cells with advanced computational modeling to unravel the pathophysiology of IVF and create a pathway for mechanistic-based treatment to make deliverable gains in arrhythmia prevention.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: CLEMENT J. ZABLOCKI VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPDD) is a painful form of arthritis which is common among US veterans. Risk factors for CPDD include advanced age, and prior joint trauma which are common characteristics of the veteran population. Its cause is currently unknown and there are no specific or effective therapies for this painful arthritis. This work explores the role of a protein called osteoprotegerin in CPDD. Genetic abnormalities in this protein were identified as one cause of this disease. In this proposal will explore the mechanisms through which genetic abnormalities in osteoprotegerin cause CPDD, with the ultimate goal of developing new therapies for all patients with CPDD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research will use a national medical record system of over 10 million patients to evaluate the impact of U.S. eviction moratoria policies on use and costs of homeless and acute healthcare services in communities across the country. The project will deploy an innovative method to identify evictions in medical records that can be used for future evaluations and utilize qualitative interviews with dyads of tenants and landlords in urban and rural regions to understand their experiences during eviction moratoria. Together, this work will inform future policies and practices related to evictions, homelessness, and acute care use with the goal of addressing social and health inequities in vulnerable populations.

PHR: The goal of this CBI Training Program is to provide students with the intellectual and technical skills to solve important and complex biological problems with implications for impacting human health and treatment of disease that can be most effectively addressed by studies at the chemistry-biology interface. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Systematic screening for tuberculosis (TB) in high-risk populations, including people living with HIV and all persons living in high TB prevalence settings is recommended by the World Health Organization as an important strategy to improve TB control. While community-wide TB screening in high burden settings is unlikely to be sustainable, community-based systematic TB screening among non-household contacts of newly diagnosed TB patients (contact tracing) using trained peers (recent TB patients) may represent an efficient and effective implementation strategy that compliments existing strategies and is sustainable. The proposed research will develop and pilot a theory-informed, peer-led, multicomponent implementation strategy to improve TB contact tracing among non-household contacts of HIV-positive and HIV-negative adults in Lusaka, Zambia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Managing the impact of thrombosis is central to influenza-induced acute myocardial infarction. This research proposal will investigate the thrombotic and antiviral role of a previously undescribed mechanism in platelets that involves the retinoic acid-inducible gene-I (RIG-I) receptor signaling. Defining the signaling mechanisms that lead to influenza mediated activation of platelets and to their reprograming toward more robust antiviral and thrombotic responses, will enable us to design therapies managing thrombosis without negatively affecting antiviral response during infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our understanding of how the retina neurons works fails to account for responses to natural images—the stimuli for which the system evolved to work. The proposed work will improve our understanding of this issue. This is a requisite step in identifying the role of key circuit mechanisms in normal and aberrant natural vision and in the design of devices such as retinal prostheses to replicate or replace the retina.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative When we learn to sing or speak or play a musical instrument, our motor system has to produce the right sounds under auditory and visual guidance. To understand the neural mechanisms of this sensorimotor integration process, we will train rhesus monkeys in a novel behavioral task that allows them to produce sound sequences, and we will measure the monkey’s brain activity with functional MRI and MRI-guided electrode recordings. Our studies will elucidate the evolution of speech and music and will help to develop a better understanding of higher-level disorders of speech and language, including apraxia of speech and non-fluent aphasia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: NARRATIVE Patients with intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms (IPMNs), due to elevated risk of developing pancreatic cancer (PC), are subjected to active surveillance, and represent an ideally suited cohort for evaluating agents that can prevent progression to PC. Building on our recently completed Phase I studies, the project proposes to undertake a Phase II Clinical trial to determine the effectiveness of δ-tocotrienol (DT3) in preventing IPMN- to-PC progression, and employ cutting edge approaches (radiomics, animal models, organoids, multi-omics) to discern the underlying mechanism(s) of DT3 action. This information will lay the groundwork for a confirmatory study, which will bring a new non-operative option for patients with IPMN to reduce their risk of developing cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The field of alcohol studies lacks racial and ethnic diversity, and few systematic efforts exist to engage undergraduate students in alcohol-related research or coursework. This project will engage undergraduates from underrepresented minority groups in a coordinated program including didactic coursework, intensively mentored research experiences, and professional development activities related to alcohol studies and careers in alcohol-related fields. The goal is to broaden the diversity of the next generation of researchers in the field of alcohol studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The emergence of multidrug resistant Neisseria gonorrhoeae, including strains resistant to the injectable antibiotic ceftriaxone, the only remaining treatment recommended by the CDC, represents a serious and urgent threat to US public health. With more than 600,000 new cases of gonorrhea in the US each year, the spread of an untreatable strain would have devastating consequences, highlighting the need for prompt action to identify and develop new classes of antibiotics to treat this disease. We aim to develop a novel oral antibiotic for the treatment of drug-resistant N. gonorrhoeae to address the urgent threat of untreatable gonorrhea.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Varicella zoster virus (VZV) is the cause of chickenpox and shingles, but it also infects, becomes latent, and reactivates in nerve cells of the bowel to cause a gastrointestinal disorder (“enteric shingles”). We recently found that a persistent active VZV infection, a form of enteric shingles, is associated with achalasia, a severe disease in which the passage of food from esophagus to stomach is impaired. We now propose to eradicate VZV to determine whether its association with achalasia is causal, to identify the genetic basis behind VZV reactivation in the esophagus, and the relationship of mast cells to VZV reactivation in achalasia and its associated pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to public health through its generation of novel population- and individual-level knowledge on the prevalence and health consequences of loneliness and social isolation in the last years of life among older adults with Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementia. The proposal is consistent with the National Institute on Aging’s mission and core research agenda to understand the impact of social interaction on healthy aging (NIA Goal A), develop effective interventions to maintain health and well-being among older adults (NIA Goal B), and to improve our understanding of Alzheimer’s disease and the aging brain (NIA Goal C). The results from this work have the potential to impact the health and well-being of millions of aging adults on an individual and population level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Although outdoor air pollution causes asthma attacks in children, healthcare providers caring for children with asthma lack proper tools to help prevent asthma attacks caused by air pollution. Identifying biomarkers that predict pollution-triggered asthma attacks will allow development of new therapies, thus providing healthcare providers with evidence-based interventions to help children with asthma better control their disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE At least 15.4 million opioid prescriptions in the United States are provided each year during surgical care, and many of these prescriptions are excessive or are written in a manner that increases the risk of opioid-related adverse events, such as overdose. To reduce these harms, policymakers and payers in most states have enacted policies that limit opioid prescribing for acute pain or mandate clinicians to review prescription drug monitoring program databases before prescribing opioids, but the effects of these policies on opioid prescribing, high-risk prescribing, opioid-related adverse events, and patient-reported outcomes among surgical patients are unknown. We will close these knowledge gaps using rigorous quasi-experimental methods, comprehensive medical claims from both privately and publicly insured adults, and data from a statewide Michigan surgical registry, thus revealing whether the policies should be expanded more broadly or whether other approaches are needed to mitigate the harms of perioperative opioid prescribing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: CALHM1 and CALHM3 form a heteromeric voltage-gated CALHM1/3 ion channel that releases neurotransmitter in response to action potentials in taste bud cells that respond to sweet, bitter and umami tastes, relaying taste information to nerve cells to mediate taste perception. Temperature strongly regulates the perception of these tastes, but the effects of temperature on taste bud cell electrical excitability and CALHM1/3 channel gating mechanisms are largely unknown. Because the sense of taste plays an important role in the quality of human life, identification of mechanisms that regulate neurotransmitter release by taste bud cells to modulate perception of taste intensity may provide new targets for pharmacological and nutritional manipulation of taste sensations, which may be important in obesity, diabetes and formulations of food and medicines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Alport syndrome, a hereditary disease leading to kidney failure, has been known for 30 years to be caused by mutations in the glomerular basement membrane type IV collagen COL4A3, COL4A4, and COL4A5 genes. Although many treatments for the disease have been investigated, none have focused on attempting to fix the defective glomerular basement membrane, either by restoring the missing collagen IV chains or removing the Alport GBM’s ectopic noncollagenous components that help drive the disease. Here we will use new drugs, in vivo gene editing approaches, and recombinant collagens to attempt to normalize the glomerular filtration barrier in a mouse model of Alport syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Traumatic stress is a well-documented risk factor for mental illness, including Posttraumatic Stress Disorder, depression, and anxiety, which are prevalent and costly to the person and society. This program integrates the latest findings and concepts in a) epidemiologic risk and resilience and b) treatment development, evaluation and dissemination and implementation science to provide core training in these areas and ensure we have a research workforce that stands ready to make transformative advances in public health for those who have experienced traumatic events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Pharmacological Sciences Training Program (PSTP) at Georgetown University Medical Center is an interdisciplinary training program for a diverse community of doctoral candidates across Ph.D. disciplines who are dedicated to thesis research in pharmacological science; we provide Ph.D. students with advanced training in physiology and pharmacotherapeutics, with a view ranging from cellular signaling networks to organ function to behavior and systems medicine. Faculty mentors in the PSTP share a common research interest in identifying drug targets within cellular signaling pathways to treat human disease. Trainees will prepare for future careers in academia, pharma or biotechnology industry, or drug regulatory agencies through dissertation research and through internship experiences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narative Hair cells in the inner ear mediate our sense of hearing and balance. Hair cells are exposed to continuous mechanical stress, causing damage and cell death over time. Because mammalian auditory hair cells do not regenerate, the repair of hair cell damage is important for continued auditory function throughout life. In this proposal, we plan to study the molecular processes involved in the repair of the stereocilia actin core. Stereocilia damage, and mechanisms that mediate their repair, are expected to be key for understanding and alleviating progressive hearing loss in humans.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Our proposal, involving 3 collaborating academic Neonatal Intensive Care Units, is to determine predictive models of therapeutic hypothermia (TH) efficacy in hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy (HIE). Using a holistic and integrative approach, including deep clinical and community-based data, and molecular biomarkers of multiple biologic pathways, analyzed within a fully connected parsimonious neural network will best describe relationships with longitudinal outcomes and be able to predict response to TH in individual patients. Completion of our aims will identify and then validate the clinical, socioeconomic, and molecular mechanisms driving clinical heterogeneity in HIE and response to TH and allow rapid deployment of a dynamic, precision-based model to optimize patient selection for future HIE adjunctive therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: Chronic itch associated with inflammatory skin diseases such as atopic dermatitis, can become both physiologically and psychologically debilitating and impart serious clinical consequences. We will study how an endogenous ligand that releases in the skin and then sets in motion the following itch circuit by binding to integrin receptor expressed in the dorsal root ganglia neurons, called TRPV1 neurons, as a result, to propagate the sensation of chronic itch by releasing neuropeptide NPPB in the spinal cord. Our proposed research will identify a molecular pathway involved in cutaneous-nerve responses in the dissemination of chronic itch and may provide potentially open new therapeutic targets for prospective treatment for chronic itch associated with atopic dermatitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will help address structural racism and discrimination, and its manifestations and impact on minoritized individuals and groups in the biomedical workforce by developing and utilizing a series of 16 training modules designed specifically for biomedical trainees, supervisors/faculty, and 4 briefer modules for institutional leaders. Using evidence-based methods, the training modules will be iteratively designed to be feasible, engaging, and efficient, as well as self-directed, self-paced, publicly accessible, and user-friendly in the context of one's workday. If successful the modules will provide participants with knowledge of and skills for dismantling the impacts of structural racism and discrimination on minoritized trainees' career development and enhance diversity, equity, and inclusion in the biomedical training environment, which aligns directly with the mission of the NIGMS' Division of Training, Workforce Development, and Diversity and NIH's UNITE initiative.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Stem cells are natural units of tissue repair and homeostasis, and their versatility holds promise for tissueregeneration. This research focuses on deciphering how progenitors within a single layer of developing skinsense local signals, remodel their cellular connections between themselves, their underlying basement membrane, and their surrounding niche cells to form a stratified, differentiating epidermis that maintains a balance between growth and differentiation. Our study is a fundamental prerequisite to understanding how these basic properties go awry in skin cancers, including squamous cell carcinomas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Group B Streptococcus (GBS) is a leading cause of stillbirth and neonatal death and pregnancies complicated by gestational diabetes mellitus are at increased risk for GBS infection and adverse outcomes. This proposal examines how GBS virulence and maternal immunity are altered in gestational diabetic pregnancies compared to healthy pregnancies. These studies seek to reveal novel host and bacterial markers that can be therapeutically targeted to prevent GBS colonization and disease in pregnant women and their newborns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Abnormalities of cardiac structure and impairment of cardiac function precede the development of heart failure (HF) and underlie HF subtypes. To identify specific genomic variants, captured by whole genome sequencing, associated with cardiac structure and function, as well as HF, will provide insights into the biological pathways underlying progressive cardiac dysfunction and HF and highlight targets for drug development. Furthermore, to incorporate cumulative genetic risk of cardiac structure and function alterations will improve HF risk prediction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Thyroid cancer is the most common type of endocrine malignancy with poorly differentiated carcinoma and anaplastic carcinoma representing the most aggressive types of thyroid cancer. We have previously demonstrated that these cancer types can develop as a result of ALK gene fusions and established the mouse models of ALK-driven poorly differentiated and anaplastic carcinomas. In this proposal, will use this and the further improved mouse model to evaluate various therapeutic approaches to these frequently lethal forms of thyroid cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project is relevant to public health because it will determine whether an adapted first-line PTSD intervention effectively treats COVID-related PTSD in frontline healthcare workers, thereby improving the health of these workers and their patients during the current pandemic and in anticipation of future public health emergencies. This innovative approach will leverage the existing resource of the employee assistance program to systematically and efficiently deliver first-line treatment where it is critically needed. It aligns with NIMH’s mission to test interventions for effectiveness in community practice settings and enhance the practical relevance of effectiveness research via deployment-focused, hybrid effectiveness-implementation studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Narrative Standard of care treatments (androgen deprivation therapy-ADT, chemotherapy) are initially effective for the treatment of bone metastatic prostate cancer (mPCa) but the disease evolves to become resistant and incurable due to cancer cell heterogeneity and bone ecosystem effects. To dissect the underlying complex interactions, we will generate a robustly parameterized and validated agent-based mathematical model that will allow us to understand the impact and role of the bone ecosystem and standard of care treatments on mPCa evolution. We will then use the math model to optimize and experimentally test evolutionary-informed standard of care adaptive care treatment strategies that will extend therapeutic efficacy and, ultimately, will translate into improving the overall survival of men suffering with incurable bone mPCa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative The proposed research educational program, Navigating Educational Trajectories in Neuroscience, facilitates the success of neuroscience scholars at two critical training periods within career advancement and progression: mid-stage training for graduate students and late-stage training for postdoctoral scholars. The cohort-based model – a key feature of the program’s design, given the integral nature of community to promote retention, resilience, and success among underrepresented trainees – integrates existing successful activities with new evidence-based practices in mentorship and core skill development to accelerate pre- and postdoctoral trainees’ success as they define and navigate their educational goals. By focusing on specific opportunities to improve training and resources for scholars from backgrounds underrepresented in neuroscience, we will contribute to the diversification of our region and nation’s biomedical workforce and enhance the skills and training of the next generation of neuroscience researchers in culturally-aware mentoring practices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is a small enveloped DNA virus responsible for chronically infecting over 250 million individuals worldwide. Our proposal aims to elucidate the entry steps for HBV in susceptible cells and how these steps are blocked in non-susceptible cells. Our project will provide the basis for identifying how the viral capsid can direct endosomal trafficking post internalization, a novel proposal in the field of HBV and we will further develop an efficient in vitro infection model and identify novel host determinants that play a role in HBV entry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) is a way of non-invasively stimulating specific brain networks and is an established treatment for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD). This proposal will reveal network mechanisms of the therapeutic effects of rTMS by investigating how stimulating each network specifically changes network connectivity and behavior. This will be done in a highly individualized manner in depressed and healthy patients, leading to more effective and more individualized treatments for depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE There is a critical need for a diverse group of highly trained basic and clinical oral health researchers. If effective preventive therapies and cures for the many diseases associated with the oral, dental and craniofacial complex are to be discovered and applied, a cadre of oral health researchers must be trained to work in interdisciplinary teams and to maintain the highest standards for ethical and responsible conduct of rigorous scientific research. The main objective of this comprehensive training program is to produce oral health researchers who can apply state-of-the-art technologies to generate new knowledge, translate that information to applied therapies, and rigorously evaluate the outcomes of implementation of novel preventive or treatment strategies to improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is the most common liver disease globally and it can progress to the more severe form called non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), cirrhosis and liver cancer. Fructose intake promotes NAFLD progression. Our studies suggest nearly half of the patients with NAFLD may have reduced S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) level in the liver. The ultimate goal of this project is to understand how low liver SAMe level affects progression of NAFLD by fructose, and how it promotes the development of fibrosis and liver cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chagas disease (CD) is a major public health burden in Latin America and a serious emerging threat to several countries worldwide, including the United States. Current treatments have limited efficacy and display high toxicity and this project seeks to address this by validating Trypanosoma cruzi dihydroorotate dehydrogenase (TcDHODH) as a drug target against CD. Through the development of selective and potent TcDHODH inhibitors with appropriate ADME/tox properties and in vivo proof-of-concept, our proposal aims to offer a novel route for drug development against CD and a starting point for lead optimization, thus helping the poorest and most vulnerable people in our society and strengthening capacity in the field of drug discovery in Brazil.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer patients taking a class of chemotherapeutic drugs called Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitors (TKIs) often experience taste dysfunction, or dysgeusia, that can severely impact quality of life and lead to poor treatment outcomes. Very little is known about the role of tyrosine kinases in taste homeostasis, and the lack of an identified causative mechanism for how TKIs disrupt taste makes dysgeusia a difficult symptom to treat. This proposal seeks to characterize the role of the receptor tyrosine kinase c-Kit in taste homeostasis and identify the mechanism by which TKIs disrupt taste, which ultimately could inform efforts to lessen the burden of TKI treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: At least one in five children and adolescents in the United States suffer from a serious mental or neurodevelopmental disorder; these disorders not only affect children and their families but lead to far-reaching, negative educational, financial, vocational and societal outcomes. To promote prevention, identification and effective treatment of children with these disorders, we need committed and productive basic, translational and clinical research scientists. This T32 program directly addresses this need by training early career investigators to have the knowledge and skills necessary to conduct innovative, interdisciplinary and precision health-oriented research at the forefront of child psychiatry and neurodevelopment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project tests the hypothesis that, in the rat, exposure to alcohol during adolescence induces long-term changes in sleep and activity rhythms, increases in drinking, that are in part mediated by hypocretin/Orexin system in key sleep circuits. These studies also test new therapeutics for adolescent alcohol-induced sleep/wake pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Mutations in isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) affect patients with gliomas, chondrosarcomas, and acute myeloid leukemia, but the mechanistic consequences of these mutations are still being explored. We propose to leverage our recent discoveries on IDH to elucidate the molecular, trans-organellular, and cellular mechanisms of dysfunction. This work is expected to establish the fundamental features of IDH mutations, ultimately providing tools for predicting patient prognosis and illuminating new disease-driving pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Over 600,000 people in the U.S. have kidney failure that requires dialysis or transplantation to stay alive. The purpose of this project is to determine why kidneys fail. In particular, we plan to study biochemical pathways that prevent kidney cells from dying, which may lead to new therapies to halt the progression of kidney diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Excess lipid accumulation in liver and intestine is linked to diabetes, NASH, and other diseases. We have discovered a family of mammalian proteins called Asters that plays an important role in cholesterol movement. We will determine the roles that Asters play in lipid homeostasis in the enterohepatic axis, test whether Asters are important contributors to the pharmacological effects of LXR and FXR agonists, and assess whether Asters may be potential drug targets themselves.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative One of the earliest symptoms of Alzheimer’s disease to appear is deficits in spatial navigation, or getting lost in space, which involves complex interactions across multiple brain regions. This research project will look at how these interactions may be affected by Alzheimer’s disease, causing losses in spatial navigation, and will utilize a noninvasive approach for clearing amyloid beta and tau and rescuing functional interactions. This research will also expand our understanding of Alzheimer’s effects on spatial navigation, and will aid in understanding what mechanisms underlie these deficits, to improve early identification and treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Each year, problems related to alcohol and drug consumption, abuse, and dependence cause 88,000 deaths and cost over $249 billion in the United States. Scientific research into the causes and prevention of alcohol- and other drug-related problems across the lifespan, as well as treatment advances for individuals diagnosed with alcohol dependence is urgently needed to address these public health concerns. The purpose of this training grant application is to train and equip the next generation of scientific researchers who are committed to understanding and ameliorating the costs, causes, and consequences of alcohol- and drug-related problems.

PROJECT_TITLE: Multidisciplinary Alcoholism Research Training Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) is characterized by increased skeletal and extra-skeletal production of fibroblast growth factor (FGF)-23 that is associated with cardiovascular mortality. Inflammation, iron deficiency (ID) and reduced expression of miR-122 stimulate FGF23 production. This project proposes to test the impact of inflammation and ID on extra-skeletal sources of FGF23, and the role of miR-122 on the post-translational modifications of FGF23 in CKD, thus providing potential therapeutic targets for individuals with CKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The positioning and architecture of a stem cell niche is crucial to the niche's ability to maintain stem cells and thus, to maintain appropriate tissue renewal during injury or aging. The mechanisms by which niches are assembled, however, remain poorly characterized. Using a powerful genetic model, this proposal will investigate the molecular mechanisms required to assemble a stem cell niche, which is required for development and maintenance of functional biological tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: Drug abuse and overdose results in hundreds of thousands of emergency room visits, hospital admissions, and deaths which imposes a large financial cost on the Unites States healthcare system. Guided by molecular modelling, we will synthesize novel water soluble and high affinity macrocyclic arene (prismarenes and pagodaarenes) and measure their binding affinity toward a panel of drugs of abuse (DOA) followed by in vitro and in vivo toxicology and finally in vivo efficacy studies to identify a lead in vivo supramolecular antidote for intoxication with DOAs. The project promises to impact human health by reducing the mortality and health care costs associated with DOA intoxication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative: Tsetse-transmitted trypanosomiasis are a significant socioeconomic and health burden, imapcting millions of people in sub-Saharan Africa. Because a positive correlation exists between the density of tsetse’s facultative endosymbiont Sodalis glossinidius and the prevalence of trypanosome infection in tsetse’s midgut, a more complete understanding of the nature of the Sodalis-tsetse symbiosis will yield information to help control tsetse-borne disease. Furthermore, because Sodalis is one of only a few intracellular insect symbionts to be cultured outside of the host, it can be developed as a model for the study of other intracellular insect symbionts that have an impact on the ability of the insect to transmit disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The adhesion of cells to extracellular matrix is fundamentally important for many physiological processes such as heart development, tissue regeneration, and wound healing. Such adhesion process is controlled by integrin- linked kinase (ILK) and it dysregulation has been linked to the progression of numerous diseases such as heart failure and stroke. Our proposal aims at determining the basic mechanism of the ILK function and its inhibitor development, which will not only help understand cell adhesion at normal and disease states of our body but also transform the diagnosis and treatment of ILK-mediated diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Motivated by the fact that every possible single-’letter’ change in the human genome that is compatible with life already exists in someone alive today, the first phase of our Center for Multiplex Analysis of Phenotype (CMAP) sought to measure the effects of genetic variants on molecular and cellular phenotypes by developing technologies that have been used to measure the effect of ~11 million variants. However, meeting the promise of personalized genomic medicine must account for the fact that variant effects can depend on an individual’s unique life history beginning with development and laden with exposures to diverse environments, and that each individual variant exists in the context of millions of other variants. In the proposed second phase of our Center for Multiplex Analysis of Phenotype (CMAP) – we will develop technologies for mapping variant effects at scale across a wide range of environmental conditions, genetic contexts, and in multicellular model systems; and develop tools for forecasting individual disease risks. 1

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: There is a remarkable increase in the incidence of chronic pain during the transition from early to middle adolescence, a developmental period that is also characterized by the heightened significance and salience of peer relationships and experiences on and offline. Although peer relationship difficulties are commonly observed in youth with chronic pain, whether these difficulties are a cause, correlate, or consequence of pediatric chronic pain is unknown. The long-term goal of this research program is to identify specific peer relationship processes (e.g., traditional and cyber-victimization, social support, and social connectedness) that influence pain persistence, exacerbation, and recovery in a cohort of youth at-risk for chronic pain, such that more developmentally appropriate and effective prevention and intervention programs can be created.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women with metastatic breast cancer (MBC) treated with a CDK4/6 inhibitor exemplify a new and growing population of patients living long-term with metastatic cancer as a chronic and fatal condition (i.e., “metavivors”). In the current study, we will adapt an existing cognitive behavioral therapy intervention for fatigue (CBTF) for fatigued metavivors with MBC treated with a CDK4/6 inhibitor. We will then evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary efficacy of the adapted intervention, called Energize-MBC, in preparation for a full-scale, multisite Phase II trial with high potential impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed project is to develop a novel treatment for osteoarthritis based on slow release of a natural pomegranate derivative from polymeric microparticles that is formed upon injection of a polymer-oil emulsion into the knee joint. The treatment is intended to slow the progression of osteoarthritis by suppressing inflammation and thwarting the enzymes that destroy cartilage by inactivating them and decreasing their production. The project involves characterization of the drug’s anti-arthritic effects on human cells, optimization of the microparticle system formulation to achieve prolonged release of drug, and assessment of the drug delivery system’s safety.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative One mission of the NICHD is to support basic research on typical human development. The proposed research examines a critical problem in early language learning: how children learn words with more than one meaning. These studies will test hypotheses of how children learn to associate multiple meanings with a single word when they are not specifically taught that a word has more than one meaning, which may have important implications for interventions and literacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance This study will develop a smart nanoparticle-based technology capable of unleashing the anti-cancer potential of veratridine, a plant-based molecule, at tumor sites. Understanding the fundamental mechanisms of veratridine will identify the contribution of tumorigenic pathways that selectively support tumor metastasis. This project can lead to the discovery of targeted therapies for primary and metastatic forms of CRC that is safer and more effective than current chemotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb)- the causative agent of tuberculosis (TB)- is able to establish infection in the lungs, persist in humans for years, and kill more people than any other bacteria. The goal of this project is to determine whether Mtb infection alters host oxysterol metabolites, thereby modifying the host inflammatory response and promoting disease pathogenesis. These findings could lead to novel therapies and diagnostics for TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because current antibiotic therapy is poor at preventing chronic, long-term infection by the pathogen Mycoplasma pneumoniae. A deep understanding of M. pneumoniae biofilms, which are masses of bacteria that resist current drugs, is required to more effectively reduce disease caused by this common pathogen, including asthma and autoimmune diseases that result from chronic infection. This project is directly relevant to NIH’s mission in that part of the stated mission of NIH is to “foster fundamental creative discoveries, innovative research strategies, and their applications as a basis for ultimately protecting and improving health.”

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: GeoSentinel is a global surveillance network of travel and tropical medicine clinics, which has been highly productive in enhancing understanding of the epidemiology of imported infections and the detection of sentinel events related to emerging infections and infectious disease outbreaks. We collect data, using a standardized data collection form and uniform diagnostic criteria, on a broad variety of travelers and migrants during and after travel, in near-real time. We propose a wide-ranging series of research projects to further our understanding of travel-related illness and imported infections using our well-established surveillance platform.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CK21-002 - GeoSentinel Database

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR TOXIC SUBSTANCES AND DISEASE REGISTRY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will examine the mechanisms by which the gut bacteria of ALS patients alter the rate of disease through changes in metabolites or immune cells in the blood. The bacteria of the gut are a particularly attractive target for future therapies, as they can be easily and cheaply manipulated using existing interventions such as diet, probiotics, or fecal transplant. The proposed research will therefore have an immediate impact on potential ALS therapeutic strategies.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-TS-22-001: Interactions between the microbiome, metabolome, and immune system as underlying mechanisms of ALS pathogenesis

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Overall Center – Project Narrative Agriculture is the most hazardous sector of the economy, and farmworkers experience the highest rate of severe illness, injury, and death in the U.S. In Illinois, 35-50,000 farmworkers live in extreme poverty and are profoundly disadvantaged, despite their critical importance to the food supply chain. The new Great Lakes Center for Farmworker Health and Wellbeing aims to collaboratively change systems to protect and promote the health and well-being of farmworkers through translation of basic science and survey research, surveillance, networking across NIOSH Centers of Excellence in Agriculture, Total Worker Health, and Education/Research, and outreach to workers, service providers, employers, trade organizations, government agencies and policymakers.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Great Lakes Center for Farmworker Health and Well-being

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: MASSACHUSETTS STATE DEPT OF PUB HEALTH
PHR: The Massachusetts Department of Public Health’s Occupational Health Surveillance Program (OHSP) is proposing to build on its extensive experience and network of partners to continue and enhance its Expanded Program for occupational health surveillance and prevention. The proposal contains focused surveillance and intervention systems for priority occupational health conditions and populations, collaborations with government and community partners to address identified problems, broad-based prevention activities based on surveillance findings, and integration of occupational health into mainstream public health practice. This proposal will contribute to foundational knowledge about the prevention and reduction of work- related injuries and illnesses using state occupational health surveillance programs.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Expanded Occupational Health Surveillance in Massachusetts

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative A subset of leukemia and lymphomas, also called CD4+ T cells neoplasms, are rare and kill patients at a higher rate than other liquid tumors. New drugs, also called living drugs, manufactured from actual patients’ immune system cells, are increasingly being engineered and tested throughout the world. Specifically, so called T cells are taken out from the patients’ blood circulation, and genetically modified using a Chimeric Antigen Receptor, against the CD4+ molecule present in patients’ tumors. These so called CAR-T cells are then re-injected into patients and have the potential to attack and destroy recipients’ cancer cells throughout the body. With this study we propose to test this novel living drug against CD4+ tumors in patients with rare forms of leukemia or lymphoma for the first time, in a Phase I clinical trial aimed at documenting the maximum tolerated dose of such treatment and observe long term response. 1
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CD4 Redirected Chimeric Antigen Receptor T Cell Therapy for CD4 Positive T Cell Neoplasms

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative New Jersey Department of Health (NJDOH) Fundamental Plus and Adult Blood Lead Occupational Health Surveillance Project Since 1985, the New Jersey Department of Health has conducted surveillance, funded by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH), for occupational illnesses and injuries which are reportable under New Jersey regulations that provides the Department with the authority to collect occupational health surveillance data. This proposal details our plans to i) expand on current traditional occupational data collection methods; ii) enhance unique state surveillance systems not traditionally used for occupational health and incorporate the collection of workplace information and iii) develop a framework for future emergent infectious diseases. This improvement of occupational health surveillance will allow for better targeted intervention of at-risk working populations and development of education and outreach materials.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR TOXIC SUBSTANCES AND DISEASE REGISTRY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a rare, fatal neurodegenerative disorder, with 90% sporadic cases do not have genetic causes and their contributing risk factors are largely unknown. The proposed work is exploratory and developmental in nature and will be one of the first pilot studies applying machine-learning-based, hypothesis-generating algorithms on statistically powerful real-world data to generate real-world evidence on ALS risk factors with or without an existing evidence base. The work will not only provide CDC agency of toxic substance and disease registry (ATSDR) with empirical evidence to better prioritize future decisions on expanding the ALS registry risk factor survey but serve to inform better designed proposals for future etiological studies and targeted trials for ALS.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-TS-22-001:Towards Better Understanding of ALS using a Multi-Marker Discovery Approach from a Multi-Modal Database (ALS4M)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Tuberculosis (TB) remains among the most deadly infections worldwide, especially among people living with HIV. Current available tests are not able to accurately detect persons at the highest risk of developing TB, and curing the disease requires at least 6 months of therapy because the TB bacteria can avoid being killed by the immune system and currently available drugs. In the current proposal, physician scientists will receive training in a variety of complementary disciplines, and use several cutting-edge experimental and modeling techniques to analyze samples from patients with TB and TB/HIV, with the ultimate goal of identifying new biomarkers that can predict TB disease and host-directed therapies that can shorten TB treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Asthma is more common in children than adults and persistence of childhood asthma has been conclusively linked to chronic lung function deficits that track into adult life. In a large study we reported for the first time that serum levels and whole blood gene expression of creatine kinase (CK) are decreased in childhood asthma, which suggests that CK may be a potential biomarker for early risk stratification of long-term persistence of childhood asthma. This proposal will investigate 3 areas of interest regarding the CK isoforms and asthma that will lead us down the path of further basic understanding, including: cell-specific expression levels, asthma- related mechanisms of CK regulation and the impact of low CK levels in early life on adult lung function using mouse models of asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research is relevant to public health because children from minority and rural communities have the highest rates of obesity in the country, but they do not have easy access to the type of obesity treatment they need. This study will test whether adapting an obesity intervention for local communities improves the intervention’s reach to underserved communities and effectiveness at reducing obesity. By delivering this intervention in local community centers, we will build an intervention that could be used widely in communities across the country.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Continuous intracranial pressure (ICP) monitoring is considered one of the most important surveillance tools for neurological and neurosurgical patients that can provide critical insights on disease severity to guide medical and surgical management. However, the standard for continuous ICP monitoring, which entails drilling a burr hole into the skull and implanting an intracranial catheter or pressure sensor, is far too often not practiced due to its invasiveness and risks for infection, hemorrhage, and dislodgement. Continuous, non-invasive monitoring of the hemodynamic waveform at the carotid artery using soft, conformal sensors shows promise as an indirect means of continuously and non-invasively monitoring ICP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gametes are the basis for sexual reproduction, and it is thus important to the fitness of future generations that they are “reset” as young when generated, even if they originate from aged cells. The process by which gametes are created ensures that damaged contents from the precursor cell are not inherited by removing and replacing pre-existing components. We propose that by identifying the components that are cleared out during gamete resetting, and the mechanisms by which the cell removes them, we will better understand the cellular components that cause aging and uncover new strategies for combatting age-related cell damage.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAAs) are a life-threatening vascular disease responsible for over 15,000 deaths annually that are characterized by immune cells, namely macrophages, that contribute to pathological vascular remodeling. Our preliminary data demonstrate that epigenetic changes in macrophages, driven by JAK/STAT/SETDB2, regulate the activity of metalloproteinases, which function to break down the aortic wall and promote AAA formation. Using both murine models and human specimens, this proposal will seek to understand how these changes develop in aortic tissue and will test new therapies to restore macrophages to homeostasis and prevent AAA expansion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The overall goal of the Comprehensive NeuroHIV Center (CNHC) is to develop, improve and sustain an infrastructure to provide services to a large number of scientists from the Philadelphia and beyone are who are involved in high impact research towards neuroHIV. CNHC offers unique expertise and services in gene editing strategies and delivery, cellular neurobiology and functional assessments and neuropsychological, virological and immunological data within a well-characterized and longitudinal clinical cohort. CNHC will provide pilot funding for junior investigators to enhance training and research for the next generation HIV scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a progressive, smoking-related lung disease that has a poor prognosis; since current treatments slow future progression but do not reverse disease, there is an important need to identify and characterize the precursors of IPF. This proposal aims to use the radiomics signatures of chest computed tomography scans of smokers to stratify disease severity and to predict progression to early pulmonary fibrosis and advanced disease. Radiomics analyses may help identify patients at greatest risk for adverse events and most likely to benefit from early intervention to prevent the development of advanced IPF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative With this application, we propose to inspire and prepare a diverse set of professional students, including medical students and veterinarians, as well as PhD candidates in relevant biomedical disciplines, to devote their careers to clinical and translational science (CTS). These predoctoral scholars will enter the Tufts CTS Graduate Program to obtain a Certificate (one year), MS degree (two-year) or PhD degree. In addition to a general CTS track, we offer three specialized tracks: Predictive Analytics and Comparative Effectiveness Research (PACER), One Health, and Health Policy and Health Disparities (HPHD).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer is the leading cause of death among Latinos, and among Latinas, breast cancer is the leading cause of cancer death. Latinas are a population at high risk of obesity, diabetes, and other cardiometabolic comorbidities, which are associated with poorer breast cancer outcomes. We will test adaptive interventions to identify the most effective multi-component home-based, online, culturally-tailored weight loss adaptive intervention in Latina breast cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Research in neuroscience is crucial for attacking the causes of neurological and mental health disorders. If the field of neuroscience is to continue its rapid advance, neuroscientists must use, understand, and develop new technologies, acquire and analyze ever larger data sets, and grapple more directly with the complexity of neurobiological systems. The primary goal of this training program will be to help train the next generation of systems neuroscientists with the experimental and computational skills needed to make the discoveries of tomorrow.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Duke University Program in Genetics and Genomics (UPGG) research training program aims to prepare predoctoral students for a variety of career paths in biomedical sciences. UPGG students perform genetics and genomics research contributing to the fundamental understanding of living systems as well as translational research that directly impacts the understanding of human health and disease. After graduation, our trainees will have the professional skills necessary to fill critical niches within the biomedical research field in academic institutions, private industry, and government agencies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This new University of Rochester IDDRC establishes the essential scientific Core infrastructure and administrative architecture to cohere the exceptional talents of 105 IDD investigators around five highly interlinked research cluster thematic foci, and articulates a clear purpose for our coordinated efforts – to serve persons with IDD to the best of our abilities, placing their interests at the heart of our research enterprise. Through a concerted effort across basic, translational and clinical investigators, we have set ourselves the clear goal of providing actionable clinical solutions for our IDD community. We will partner with our IDD community to communicate our work, and our passion, in a manner that is culturally competent, inclusive, and publically oriented.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Neuroscience research is critical for development of strategies to prevent, diagnose and treat diseases of the nervous system. This broadly based training program is designed to provide the next generation of researchers with a solid foundation in the fundamentals of neuroscience and strong, cutting-edge research training in basic and translational neuroscience, emphasizing rigorous experimental design and data analytic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative There is a need in the science and medical health fields associated with brain for expert contributions from engineering, sciences and mathematics in order to make lasting advances. The proposed Cross Disciplinary Neural Engineering (CDNE) training program will train future leaders in the field of neural engineering able to work across the disciplinary boundaries of engineering, sciences, mathematics, and neurosciences and human brain health. CDNE trainees will be able to communicate and understand deeply the needs and science of their collaborators, and thereby able to produce lasting advances in both basic neurosciences and the treatment of human brain health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this Research Project Grant is to develop methods for modeling the spread of tau tangles, which are a hallmark of Alzheimer’s disease, along the structural network of the brain. Novel artificial intelligence tools will be developed that accurately predict the progression of tau. The proposed imaging techniques are expected to facilitate the prognosis and monitoring of Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The cell of origin for Ewing sarcoma and the mechanisms of tumor initiation and progression are a matter of constant debate. My project takes advantages of an innovative zebrafish genetic model of Ewing sarcoma to gain new insights into understanding the developmental origin of that cancer, and to investigate the role of proteoglycan-mediated signaling in cancer and cancer niche cells in tumor initiation and progression. In this work I will test a new strategy targeting the enzymes involved in heparan sulfate proteoglycan metabolism for Ewing sarcoma treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative The aberrant accumulation of tau is linked to neuronal loss and cognitive dysfunction in Alzheimer’s disease and other tauopathies. Based on our exciting preliminary data, I propose DnaJB6 as a potential target for mitigating tau pathology. Understanding more about the interactions between tau and DnaJB6 will provide fundamental knowledge that may be applicable to other DnaJ family members and additional aggregating proteins, which ultimately may aid in the development of novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The NCI-designated Basic Laboratory Cancer Center at the Salk Institute for Biological Studies provides a rich training environment for postdoctoral fellows as they advance their careers in cancer research. In addition to rigorous, hands-on training in experimental research provided by faculty mentors, the proposed T32 Cancer Heterogeneity, Immunity, and Microenvironment (CHIME) Training Program provides workshops in cutting-edge technologies, as well as exposure to local clinicians and the problems they face while treating patients. These training elements, together with an array of career development opportunities, provide a solid foundation on which Salk T32 Fellows can build independent, research-intensive careers to help move the field toward more durable and selective cancer therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Apolipoprotein E (ApoE) represents the most significant genetic risk factor for Late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (LOAD), the most common type of dementia that affects more than 6 million people in the United States. However, even though the same ApoE allele confers risk in all populations, the effect sizes differ significantly by genetic ancestry. The proposed research aims to identify variants and physiological pathways that modify ApoE-associated LOAD risk in non-Hispanic Black, Hispanic/Latino, and non-Hispanic White individuals and evaluate the roles of race/ethnicity and ancestry in LOAD risk modeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The distribution of aggregated hyperphosphorylated tau (p-tau) in the brain correlates well with cognitive impairments observed in different stages of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). AD is currently untreatable, and the mechanisms underlying p-tau aggregation in AD are not fully understood. The proposed research plan will propel small molecule therapeutics that curtail human p-tau aggregation (isoform 1N4R) through lead optimization and proof of concept studies to improve our understanding of the mechanisms underlying AD and tauopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATVIE OVERALL Developmental Biology research is fundamental to progress in determining the molecular basis of many diseases, as well as for the rapidly emerging field of regenerative medicine. Our goals in this Phase III COBRE are to consolidate the progress we have made in Phases I and II by welcoming new Developmental Biologists into our community through the support of Pilot Projects and to expand the services offered by our Imaging and Bioinformatics and Pathways Cores, while at the same time positioning them for sustainability when COBRE funding ends.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy (HDP) are a leading contributor of maternal mortality in the US, and Black compared with White women are three to four times more likely to die from HDP. The proposed study addresses an urgent public health issue by investigating individual, interpersonal and neighborhood factors as contributors to the racial disparity in HDP. Results of this study will support the development of strategic interventions targeted to promote health equity and the improvement of birthing outcomes for Black women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Vascular cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID) is the second most common cause of dementia after Alzheimer’s disease (AD), and development of effective therapies is urgently required. The object of this application is to investigate the key role of the Krüppel-like factor 11 in the regulation of long-term cognitive functions, brain white matter integrity, and neuronal loss in experimental VCID. The successful implementation of this proposal will elucidate the molecular mechanism of Krüppel-like factors-mediated vascular brain injury and may eventually lead us to discover novel Krüppel-like factors-based therapies for the treatment of VCID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Insulin-producing beta cells in pancreatic islets are depleted in type 1 diabetes as a result of autoreactive T cell infiltration. My research will use submicron ultrasound contrast agents as tools to enhance the efficacy of peptide-based preventative therapeutics for type 1 diabetes; first as diagnostic agents to monitor therapeutic efficacy in presymptomatic type 1 diabetes and second as delivery vehicles for these therapeutics. This work will develop a novel diagnostic to monitor if therapeutic intervention is effective during presymptomatic type 1 diabetes and to enhance the repertoire of preventative therapeutic interventions for type 1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lung is the second most common subtype of lung cancer for which there are limited treatment options. This study will employ a novel mouse model of the disease and state-of-the-art technologies to elucidate the role of tumor-associated neutrophils in squamous lung cancer development, progression and therapeutic response. This work is relevant to public health and the NIH mission because it will increase our understanding of how the innate immune system impacts cancer and may ultimately suggest new therapeutic strategies that can improve the quality of life and survival of lung cancer patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Congenital conditions that alter the structure of the skull including craniosynostosis are among the most common of birth defects. Treatment for these disorders largely relies on invasive and, often, multiple surgeries beginning in infancy. By studying the disease mechanisms that disrupt skull development in Bent Bone Dysplasia Syndrome, this proposal will advance our potential to develop novel molecular-based therapeutics for its treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Youth experiencing homelessness (YEH) are disproportionately affected by HIV compared to their stably housed peers. However, little is known about the unique risks faced by YEH who are precariously housed (i.e., “couch-surfing” or temporarily staying with others). The proposed study will examine how the social support networks and living situations of precariously housed YEH impact their HIV risk and prevention behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: We recently identified histone lysine lactylation as a new type of PTM that is derived from and can be stimulated by lactate, the Warburg effect-associated metabolite. The goals of this project are to identify this pathway's regulatory elements and to investigate their epigenetic roles during hair cycle. The results from this study will significantly advance our understanding of epigenetic mechanism, and reveal functions of lactate that are associated with diverse physiological and pathological changes, including but not limited to hair cycle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This new application for five years support is to provide advanced training to predoctoral and postdoctoral fellows in translational research in Alzheimer's disease and related dementias. The aging of the US population means a continued need for new investigators trained in the study of the age-associated brain diseases, especially dementia disorders, with a focus on the latest technologies and scientific approaches. This Training Program uses a multi-disciplinary approach through didactic instructions, courses, seminars, talks, and advisory groups to prepare the trainees for research careers in focused on Alzheimer's disease and related dementias.

PHR: Narrative The mission of the Neuroscience Training Program (NTP) at Johns Hopkins University is to provide students with instruction in the neurosciences at the beginning of their graduate career to enable them to contribute to the advancement of scientific knowledge and improve human health through diverse careers. By serving as focal point for faculty, students and fellows conducting neuroscience research at Johns Hopkins, the program enhances collaborations that lead to a greater understanding of the role of the nervous system in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In recent years, there has been an increase in the prevalence of Type 1 Diabetes (T1D), and yet we still do not understand the mechanisms that lead to β-cell dysfunction and destruction in disease pathogenesis. The goal of this project is to provide comprehensive training and career development opportunities to Ms. Wagner as she works to understand the role of heterogenous β-cell reactive oxygen species (ROS) presence in disease development and determine the molecular signature behind this observed heterogeneity. The aim of this project is to address the gap in our knowledge of intrinsic mechanisms of β-cell dysfunction and has the potential to spark the development of novel therapeutics to treat and prevent T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Overall goal of this project is to create a paradigm shifting diagnosis and patient management strategy (called  HIT-PIRADS) for prostate cancer (PCa) that will significantly increase PPV for clinically significant PCa detection  while minimizing unnecessary prostate biopsies and related morbidities. Due to its interpretable nature and bias correction paradigm, our AI system will generate predictions that physicians can trust. One of the immediate  outcomes of the system will be a reproducible risk scoring system that can be used in community hospitals and  locales without MRI-subspeciality genitourinary trained radiologists to improve the accuracy of prostate imaging  nationwide. In the long term, we expect HIT-PIRADS to be widely adopted in clinics and trigger other treatment  & prevention strategies to be developed based on HIT-PIRADS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 2 diabetes is a growing health concern, with increasing incidence globally, that occurs due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors. RoundUp is the most widely applied herbicide, and glyphosate, the active ingredient, alters the mammalian gut microbiome, which can impact metabolic disease development. This research project will investigate impact of glyphosate on glucose regulation, identifying gut bacteria and signaling pathways that can be targeted to prevent the effects of glyphosate on diabetes development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although anxiety disorders are a major public health burden, existing treatments are only moderately effective, highlighting the need to identify and further investigate malleable risk factors for anxiety. Intolerance of uncertainty (IU) is one risk factor that may be critical to the development of anxiety, however research on IU is limited from both a conceptual and measurement perspective, raising questions about the predictive utility of IU. This study has the potential to provide a better understanding of how IU contributes to risk for anxiety by clarifying the measurement of IU and by exploring how IU affects maladaptive responses in daily life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Chromatin mediated regulation of the genome is critical in human development and health, and dysregulation of chromatin remodeling processes is associated with a large number human pathologies including developmental disorders, cardiovascular disease, cancer, auto-immune disease, and neurological and psychiatric disorders. This proposal seeks to determine mechanisms of chromatin structure regulation by defining the molecular details underlying how regulatory complexes navigate chromatin. Results will provide significant insight into processes of genome regulation, the etiology of human disease, and lay the groundwork for the development of targeted therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE  Aging and diseases associated with age clearly result in dependence and a severe reduction in health-span; however, without a clear understanding of the interactions between aging and disease, effective therapies cannot be developed. Our training program in GeroScience was initiated in 2017 to fill this void and train the next generation of researchers to address the complex causes of aging and their interactions with age-related disease. Based on our outstanding success, current census and plans for continued expansion of our program, we have increased our mentoring faculty to 21 and are requesting one additional position to continue our training program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative This project is aimed at understanding the structure and function of a large number of helical protein and nucleoprotein filaments, ranging from actin in human muscle to helical viruses that infect organisms living in nearly boiling acid. Some of the studies are likely to have a direct and immediate impact on human health, such as those involving the bacteria responsible for meningitis and food poisoning, while others will have longer range impact including new tools for biotechnology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative We have generated recombinant derivatives of the existing TB vaccine, Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG), that express human cytokines targeting B cells to complement chemotherapy and improve suboptimal tuberculosis (TB) control. Our proposal will determine the safety, immunogenicity, prophylactic efficacy and therapeutic efficacy of these recombinant BCG vaccines and their robustness towards host/pathogen genetics, drug resistance and, in principle, their feasibility in TB and TB/HIV patients on therapy. This will establish whether B cells can be harnessed for next generation TB vaccine development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE . High-resolution tools for assessing retinal structure and function are central to advancing our understanding of the limits of human vision in health and disease as well improving our ability to develop and evaluate novel therapeutic strategies for patients with vision loss. Using advanced retinal imaging tools, this proposal aims to evaluate therapeutic potential in blue cone monochromacy, quantify the relationship between disruptions in the photoreceptor mosaic and visual resolution, and examine the impact of premature birth on retinal structure and function. Our proposal addresses many research needs, gaps, and opportunities outlined in the 2021-2025 NEI Strategic Plan, “Vision for the Future”.
