IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will contribute fundamental knowledge about how the primate brain represents dynamic aspects of the three-dimensional (3D) world. In the short term, it will reveal how ecologically relevant representations of the world are created from ambiguous sensory information and in the long term provide insights for treating neurological disorders, brain injury, and cognitive dysfunction. Because 3D vision is a major component of virtual and augmented reality (VR/AR), the public health relevance of this work extends to industry which faces growing demands to develop devices that are safe, persuasive, inclusive, and of therapeutic utility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative  Chagas disease, caused by Trypanosoma cruzi parasites, is an important cause of heart failure with no effective treatment in late-stage disease. This project will build on our findings that L-carnitine treatment improves chronic Trypanosoma cruzi infection severity, to determine the mechanism of action of L-carnitine in chronic Chagas disease treatment. This project is relevant to the NIH’s mission because results will guide L- carnitine pre-clinical and clinical development, identify new avenues for Chagas disease patient treatment, and expand our understanding of Chagas disease pathogenesis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) causes life threatening illness in the immunocompromised and congenital disabilities in newborns. The proposed research is important to public health since defining the mechanisms underlying HCMV remodeling of host metabolism and identifying unique lipid signatures of infection will allow us to better understand virus replication. The research will develop fundamental knowledge of HCMV biology that will identify viral and host factors necessary for virus replication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE N-lysine acetylation is an important regulatory post-translational modification found not only on eukaryotic proteins, but also on hundreds of bacterial proteins involved in a broad array of essential biological processes. We will explore the functional significance of the acetylation of the histone-like protein HBsu, which may reveal the existence of a bacterial histone-like code. A mechanistic understanding of how protein acetylation influences HBsu function in chromosomal organization during various DNA transactions is critical to our understanding of bacterial physiology, and the proposed work with the model bacterium Bacillus subtilis may ultimately provide the foundation for designing novel antimicrobial drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A thorough understanding of longitudinal retinal ganglion cell (RGC) functional and metabolic changes is critical for timely detection and treatment of glaucoma, accurate assessment of its progression, and development and testing of targeted neuroprotective therapies. The proposed experiments will develop advanced, first-of-its-kind two-photon in vivo retinal imaging platform to determine dynamic functional and metabolic features of glaucomatous RGCs at both bulk and single-cell levels using our newly developed inducible and reversible ocular hypertension animal models. The experiments have the potential to discover previously unappreciated glaucoma signatures for detecting, monitoring, and evaluating the disease and its progression.

PHR: Recognition of microbial ad host inflammatory moieties leads to a profound reprograming of the metabolism of phagocytes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transcription factors are proteins that control how and when genes are turned on or expressed. Proper control of gene expression is critical for normal cell function, and transcription factor disruption is frequently associated with human disease. We have taken a new approach to study transcription factors in which these proteins are rapidly degraded by a small molecule, and we will build upon these studies to define the mechanism of transcriptional control by these critical proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE At-home testing is an important part of mitigating the spread of COVID-19, but these tests are not accessible to people with low vision or blindness. Instead of adapting to a technology originally built for sighted people, we propose a no-power version that reports test results through a texture change, which people can feel by touch. This platform could be used not only for COVID, but also for other diagnostics, and will promote the independence and privacy for people with low vision or blindness by removing the need for human assistance or an internet connection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: NARRATIVE Patients with treated HIV infection develop chronic disorders of their fat tissues and liver that lead to diabetes, heart disease and liver failure. These disorders are also associated with malfunctioning of a new hormone called FGF21 and related change of some of the body fat into an energy-wasting form of fat. The goal of this project is to determine what causes these two effects in a mouse model, and how they lead to the metabolic problems in patients with HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding and successfully treating disorders of the brain and nervous system is critically important due to the major impact of neurological and psychiatric disease on public health and the losses in productivity that result. This broadly based training program is designed to provide a solid foundation in neuroscience, from molecules to circuits and systems, in combination with a strong research training using the newest research tools and approaches to understand the complexities of the brain. The purpose of this renewal is to provide outstanding individualized training to talented predoctoral students who will devote their careers to address key challenges in both basic as well as translational neuroscience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The risk and severity of disease associated with environmental and endogenous exposures can vary greatly depending on the unique genetic makeup of an individual. The large number of possible genetic and environment combinations limits our ability to identify these interactions despite their potential to inform strategies for disease prevention and therapeutic intervention. I propose to develop high-throughput methods that overlay genetic and environmental perturbations to systematically identify these gene-by-environment interactions as well as pinpoint the specific cell types responsible for the response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The public health significance of this proposal resides in the fact that each year more than 5.8 million patients are diagnosed with a cancer for which first-line therapy can potentially include platinating agents; however, there are few means of identifying patients at risk for platinum-induced toxicities who might be offered alternative therapy, improved symptom management, or reduced-dose regimens. For patients who must receive platinum, there are no approved preventive measures and few treatments for toxicities. Our proposal is designed to fill these gaps.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Technological advances in single cell RNA sequencing platforms have rapidly advanced our understanding of cellular heterogeneity within complex multicellular organ systems, however validating these data remain a major challenge. Ultrastructural electron microscopy is the gold standard for cell type identification by recognition of definitive physical features, however sample preparation and analysis are arduous and low- throughput. Our laboratory is combining these techniques with deep learning as a novel workflow to predict and confirm epithelial changes in pancreatic metaplasia to understand the processes and mechanisms underlying epithelial injury and regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The work of this application is based on evidence that hippocampal hyperactivity is involved in mediating psychosis and that a clear and understandable pattern of hippocampal tissue pathology exists to support neuronal overactivity in hippocampus. We are reproducing this tissue pathology in a mouse and then will test the animal to determine the characteristic cellular activity in CA3, the region which we have determined is critical to the generation of hippocampal hyperactivity in human psychosis. If successful, this outcome will provide a long-sought strong inference animal preparation important for psychosis understanding.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many genetic variants have been associated with common complex diseases, but the evolutionary and functional architectures that shape genome-wide risk are still unclear. Recent efforts to characterize the extent to which natural selection and functional genomic features determine genetic risk have primarily targeted complex disease in European ancestry populations, which substantially limits the potential to understand disease etiology and stands to further health disparities. Here, we develop and apply novel scalable computational approaches characterize the evolutionary and functional architectures in multiple diverse populations and phenotypes to elucidate the mechanisms mediating risk for complex disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Age associated neoplastic transformation is the result of individual cells escaping tumor suppressive barriers during the lifetime of an organism. Successful efforts towards preventing cancer initiation during aging are dependent on understanding and enhancing the proliferative barriers that govern tumor suppressive barriers. This proposal focuses on the mechanisms that are in place to eliminate precancerous cells during replicative aging, suggesting that crosstalk between telomeres, mitochondria and the inflammation machinery is critical to protect an aging organism from cancer development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Long-acting injectable buprenorphine is an evidence-based treatment for opioid use disorder (OUD) that has the potential to improve patient outcomes, but is underutilized and infrequently available in settings where buprenorphine treatment is offered. We will implement injectable buprenorphine in one primary care clinic and one "low-threshold" clinic (based in a syringe services program) to identify barriers and facilitators to implementation, develop and test successful implementation strategies, and examine gaps in care following implementation of injectable buprenorphine. These data will be used to develop generalizable implementation manuals that can be scaled widely in other primary care and low-threshold settings to increase access to evidence-based OUD treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Parents are clearly an important focus for obesity prevention interventions, yet children who attend childcare spend a large proportion of time outside of parent care and can consume half of their daily dietary intake in this setting. Also, children may receive different messages from these two channels. The proposed research will study the acceptability, feasibility and pilot test the efficacy of a multi- component intervention focusing on supporting and empowering parents through the assistance of family child care providers (including Spanish-speaking parents and providers) to improve the food and PA environments in their homes to improve the dietary, physical activity and sedentary behaviors of the children 18-54 months in their care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will provide a foundation for understanding how cell fate decisions are controlled within an epithelial stem cell lineage. Epithelial stem cells are central to both normal homeostasis and the progression of diseases such as cancer, so understanding how they are regulated their native, in vivo contexts is important for the development of new diagnostics and therapeutics. The proposed project will also contribute to the NIH mission to foster fundamental creative discoveries by investigating new and poorly understood topics such as stem cell niche competition and the role of pH dynamics in cell fate decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative. This project investigates connection between circadian clocks and mTOR signaling rhythms in calorie restriction. The circadian clock, mTOR pathway and calorie restriction are major regulators of metabolism and aging. The obtained data will help to develop a strategy for the treatment and prevention of age-associated diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Surgical treatment for post-hemorrhagic hydrocephalus (PHH) of premature infants is limited by our understanding of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) production and circulation. In this pilot project, we will conduct transcranial, tomographic fluorescence imaging of CSF-indocyanine green (ICG) ventricular dynamics; assess CSF-ICG outflow into the peripheral lymphatics; and measure CSF biomarkers of inflammation in order to understand treatment responses of infants with PHH during standard-of-care treatments of conservative CSF diversion, endoscopic third ventriculostomy and choroid plexus coagulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES

PHR: UPR COBRE Center for Neuroplasticity During Phase 3 the UPR Center for Neuroplasticity will continue to provide a multidisciplinary cadre of investigators with cutting-edge facilities, scientific capability, and multidisciplinary collaborations for the treatment of neurodegeneration-related diseases. Our projects are unified by shared thematic and technical factors toward understanding and treating neurological disorders, including, the origins of neural and mental health disorders, as well as elucidating the molecular basis for alcohol neuroadaptation, addiction, and neuroprotection. Our center will become a world-recognized center for the study of neurodegeneration-related diseases with therapeutic applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Merit and Health Relevance 3'-derived tRNA fragments are highly expressed in stem and cancer cells undergoing epigenetic reprogramming and target endogenous long terminal repeat (LTR)-retroviruses that become active during reprogramming in development and disease. Our overarching goal is to characterize and identify cellular proteins that mediate this novel small RNA silencing mechanism. The proposed research will advance our understanding of endogenous retrovirus control in mammals and the evolutionary role of tRNAs in RNA interference and genome stability, as well as be applicable to LTR-retroviruses that threaten human health such as HIV, RNA tumor viruses, and endogenous LTR-retroelements that drive oncogene expression in cancer.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The structural birth defect of brain dysmyelination causes slowed and asynchronous signal transmission which can lead to seizures, attention deficit, autism and/or age–related cognitive decline. Dysmyelination is a consistent feature of people with an approximately 1.6 megabase deletion of chromosome 18q23. We are creating a team of clinical and basic scientists to evaluate the contribution of genes in this critical region, individually and in combination, to define their effect on myelinogenesis in mouse cells and patient-derived cell models in order to guide potential treatment development.

PHR: Project Narrative: The Neuroimaging and Electrophysiology Facility (NIEF) is a core with state-of-the-art instruments and experienced technical staff to support, guide and advice the scientific community in Puerto Rico. The main goal of this proposal is to maintain the NIEF services in microscopy or electrophysiological strategies and continue the positive impact of our investigators in terms of publications, grants submissions, grants funded, patents obtained and students who have completed their degrees by using the facilities. Excellent services and instruments in the NIEF at the Molecular Science Research Center and the Institute of Neurobiology, maximizes the impact of our cores to help a variety of investigators in the island and support the well-planned sustainability of the cores beyond COBRE-3.

Pre-doctoral trainees in public health and psychology acquire important biological and biomedical foundations in concert with their behavioral science disciplinary training. This program adds scientists to the workforce who are able to more effectively translate research into understanding, preventing, and treating health disorders of major societal import.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As the US population ages, Alzheimer's disease) and its related dementias (ADRD) are responsible for ever- increasing morbidity, mortality, and health care costs. Unfortunately, little research has examined factors relevant to ADRD in non-white individuals. Using data from the Cohorts for Heart and Aging Research in Genomic Epidemiology (CHARGE) consortium, made up of 6 large and long-term NIH-funded cohorts with racially diverse participants, we will build new ethnically diverse machine learning models, derive novel neuroimaging machine learning-based brain signatures of ADRD from them, and evaluate their clinical relevance across diverse ethnoracial groups. iii

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) is a highly aggressive breast cancer subtype that relies almost exclusively on neoadjuvant chemotherapy as the standard of care treatment. Because ~50% of TNBC patients are left with residual disease after chemotherapy, finding alternative treatment options is critical. This proposal aims to address this need by investigating and targeting a potential mechanism of heightened mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation in residual TNBC.

This Core integrates enthusiastic scientists using diverse model systems and strategies in modern world-class facilities to better understand how the brain and the nervous system adapt to challenging changes during health and disease. The scientific activity will also nurture the next generation of neuroscientific leaders.

PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement As one of its 5 strategic goals, the NIH has identified “workforce development” in biomedical data science as important for the coming decades. As such, NIH has called for integrative training in data-science approaches through curricula using a mentored research. The proposed T35 short-term training program is designed to engage eligible predoctoral students with diverse backgrounds particularly those from underrepresented groups, and from the physical and/or quantitative sciences to explore Big Data health science research in HIV, COVID-19, and other infectious diseases in South Carolina (SC) and the United States (US).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Cannabis is consumed by millions of Americans, moreover, changes in public attitudes and regulatory policies are expected to further increase the number of users. Levels of Δ9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) in cannabis are also rising and the use of high potency cannabis (containing high levels of THC) is associated with an increased risk of adverse health consequences. To address the corresponding lack of knowledge regarding targets of high potency cannabis and their role in negative health outcomes, we propose a pharmacogenomic screen in the BXD mouse population to identify genetic variation in effector proteins that regulate cannabinoid receptor signaling and mediate acute physiological responses to high-dose THC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narrative Identifying and targeting the subset of lymphoma cells that maintain and repopulate the disease is a critical unmet need. Building on our strong foundational work and interdisciplinary expertise, we have devised a bold strategy to provide definitive answers on how stem-like populations arise from mature lymphocytes and how are they hijacked by specific mutations to promote disease progression and relapse. Our studies promise to transform the way we understand and treat lymphoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kaposi’s Sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) is a major cause of AIDS-associated cancers and thus represents a significant public health burden. The proposed work seeks to establish how KSHV triggers cellular proliferation in an improved cell culture model of the KSHV-associated cancer Kaposi’s sarcoma. Results will be impactful, because they will improve our understanding of mechanisms underlying Kaposi’s Sarcoma and our ability to develop therapeutic strategies for this cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  In HIV-associated cryptococcal meningitis, altered mental status is a common clinical manifestation and is associated with a significant increase in mortality. There is a considerable lack of understanding as to the exact neurological abnormalities leading to the development of acute altered mental status in cryptococcal meningitis. The objective of this study is to identify the underlying neurological abnormalities that result in the development of altered mental status during cryptococcal meningitis and to identify clinical interventions to reverse these neurological abnormalities and improve survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses invasive E. coli infections, which are common, often antibiotic resistant, and associated with high mortality. Despite this threat, we do not fully understand E. coli pathogenesis and have not developed an antibiotic with novel mechanism to treat E. coli infections in over 50 years. This proposal is relevant to the NIH mission of fostering basic science that leads to novel antibacterial therapeutics as it functionally characterizes a set of genes that appear to be critical in E. coli pathogenesis and that demonstrate homology to a gene that has successfully been developed as a drug target in another organism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Exposure to high doses of ionizing radiation within a relatively short period of time can cause acute radiation syndrome (ARS), a severe form of radiation injury that can occur at events such as a “dirty bomb” terrorist attack or nuclear power plant leakage. ARS survivors may develop delayed effects of radiation exposure (DEARE) and there are no therapeutic agents available to prevent or alleviate DEARE. Our proposal will define the functional immuno-radiobiology of the regenerative immune system after whole body irradiation in mice. Since the tissue targets of radiation injury are well studied, we can also correlate whether T-cell immune senescence and dysfunction of myeloid population contributes to DEARE. These studies will provide a blueprint for developing optimized immuno-conditioning regimens for immunization protocols in radiation survivors that can be extended to immunocompromised and elderly population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preventing infections, vascularization, cell migration, and reintegration with surrounding tissues are vital factors in diabetic wound healing. Here, we propose to develop an extracellular matrix (ECM) mimicking porous nanofibrous microspheres (NMs) integrated with fibrillar hydrogel to co-deliver both antibacterial and angiogenic peptides to the wound site to control infections and enhance vascularization during the diabetic wound healing. The novel open porous architecture of the NMs facilitates rapid cell migration and accelerates the healing process; thus, our goal is to engineer an inexpensive, effective, and minimally invasive combinatorial treatment strategy to treat diabetic wounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Perceptual learning describes a phenomenon where animals can learn to discriminate between highly overlapping sensory stimuli (for example similar tastes, sounds or smells) with practice. The neural mechanisms underlying perceptual learning remain incompletely understood. This proposal will investigate this question by recording neural activity in the gustatory cortex as mice learn to discriminate between overlapping taste mixtures. Knowledge gained from this proposal will provide new information about taste coding, sensory processing and neuroplasticity that could ultimately be used to better understand how the brain works in both health and disease.

PHR: Project narrative: Sepsis is a deadly disease that kills approximately 215,000 Americans each year. This proposed investigation will use preclinical models to determine the mechanisms underlying sepsis-associated cardiomyopathy. Studies are designed to investigate how immune cells localized in the heart tissue regulate cardiac performance, and therefore having a promising potential to develop novel therapies for clinical utility in the near future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The results of the proposed study will have a significant impact on public health by providing critical information regarding the clinical and cost effectiveness of the only empirically-supported treatment to date (Risk Reduction through Family Therapy; RRFT) for adolescents with co- occurring substance use problems and PTSD symptoms. If these problems are left untreated, adolescents with interpersonal violence histories are at high risk for addiction and severe mental health disorders as they enter young adulthood and across the lifespan. Demonstrating the clinical and cost effectiveness of RRFT and more closely examining the qualitative factors that would assist in its implementation broadly, as well as engaging policy makers and brokers to work toward large scale uptake of evidence-based treatment for this population among front-line clinicians, would substantially improve practice for this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE AI/AN populations experience a disproportionate burden of obesity, which contributes to inflammatory mechanisms of carcinogenesis that may add to AI/AN cancer disparities. The purpose of this study is to assess the feasibility of a prehab intervention among AI patients diagnosed with obesity-related cancer and measure inflammatory biomarkers to evaluate the preliminary impact of the trial intervention. The results of this K08 proposal will provide essential data and experience for the candidate’s development into a translational clinical trialist working on behalf of AI/AN cancer patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Mutations in MKRN3 are now recognized to be the most common genetic cause of central precocious puberty. We have made significant progress in understanding how MKRN3 regulates puberty initiation, but the exact mechanisms are yet to be fully determined. The objective of this proposal is to advance our understanding of the molecular, cellular and physiologic mechanisms of action of MKRN3, which in turn can lead to the development of new tools for the management of pubertal and reproductive disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The antibody-drug conjugate enfortumab vedotin (EV), which targets the surface protein NECTIN4, was recently FDA approved for patients with metastatic urothelial carcinoma but the mechanisms controlling sensitivity and resistance to EV are unknown. Using patient derived xenografts (PDX), cell lines and patient biopsy samples, I propose to: 1) investigate the roles of the PPARg and TGFb pathways in regulating NECTIN4; 2) identify novel drug combinations to increase NECTIN4 expression and enhance the efficacy of NECTIN4-targeting therapeutics; and 3) determine mechanisms underlying EV resistance. Completion of this study may lead to new clinical trials to improve the effectiveness and overcome resistance to NECTIN4-targeting therapies and may have implications beyond urothelial carcinoma to inform therapeutic strategies for other NECTIN4-expressing cancers, including breast, lung and pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early identification and monitoring of endolymphatic hydrops (EH) is critical to preventing progression of this, oftentimes, debilitating auditory/vestibular disease (which is episodic in nature). Our approach will be to combine an advanced, objective tool our lab has developed (a Joint-Otoacoustic Emission Profile), which characterizes the generation of two separate intra-cochlear responses, with perceptual measurements of pitch, and computational modeling, to improve the efficacy of EH diagnosis in humans, whose cochlea cannot be accessed or manipulated for direct study. This longitudinal approach to understanding EH is a comprehensive and bold attempt to understand its clinical manifestations as well as its underlying pathophysiology, while enhancing the diagnosis and monitoring of disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Problematic use of alcohol, marijuana and tobacco represent enormous public health costs, and use of substances, particularly alcohol, often begins in adolescence. The big data approach proposed in this application will lead to identification of neural factors linked to risk precursors for early initiation of alcohol and other substance use, including sleep problems, internalizing behaviors, externalizing behaviors, and cognitive impairment in late childhood and early adolescence. The results generated from this project will inform the rationale for designing early detection and intervention before onset of alcohol/substance use in adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Loss of NF1 plays a major role as an oncogenic driver in many cancer types and can be found in up to 33% of all breast cancers (BC); it is a prognostic indicator for increased cancer risk at an earlier age, poorer outcomes, and therapeutic resistance. We have generated novel rat models deficient for Nf1 including a pathogenic patient missense allele (p.R1276Q knockin or KI) as well as a 14 base pair deletion (p.P1220fs*1223 knockout or KO) allele that have a very robust ER+ BC phenotype with apparent lung metastases. Our overall goal is to characterize the phenotype of these rat models in terms of histopathology, Ras signaling, hormone signaling, immune components, and targeted drug response and compare/contrast them with what is known regarding patients with somatic or germline inactivation of NF1 and breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Most of the 1 million Americans suffering a heart attack or related event each year are unable to increase their physical activity to recommended levels, despite the clear benefits of activity on recovery and survival. We propose a randomized controlled trial testing a novel program for this group of patients that combines a traditional physical activity program with positive psychology exercises designed to boost optimism, motivation, gratitude, and confidence. If this new program is more successful than existing clinical management in increasing activity among these high-risk patients, it could ultimately be adopted in clinical practice to improve recovery and reduce rates of death after major cardiovascular events.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Closely related species of nonhuman primates (rhesus and cynomolgus macaques) exhibit different levels of susceptibility to Tuberculosis (TB), yet the underlying mechanism is unknown. This project aims to compare the primate immune genes in response to TB infection to identify species-specific immune genes (or isoforms) that influence susceptibility to TB among primates. Novel identified genes and the proteins they encode can be functionally validated and be used as drug or vaccine targets for TB.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance) Children's naturalistic environments often contain background noise—such as other talkers, televisions and computers, heating and ventilation systems, and outside traffic—that interferes with children's ability to process spoken input. Spoken input is the sole source of word learning for preschool-age children; thus, background noise may interfere with children's ability to learn words, a critical process during early childhood that is related to long-term academic and occupational success. The purpose of the proposed research is to determine how different types and intensity levels of background noise disrupt word learning, which ultimately will advance our understanding of how to maximally support word learning in real-world environments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will contribute to public health efforts to improve treatment and prevention outcomes for people living with or at risk for HIV in U.S., especially those belonging to racial/ethnic minority communities. Findings from this study will have important implications for HIV treatment and prevention approaches for the COVID-19 or related future pandemic. This research has the potential to make important contributions towards addressing some of the key public health problems in the U.S., including attainment of the UNAIDS 95-95-95 targets for HIV; addressing health disparities in the U.S.; and engendering health equity in public health interventions to address racial/ethnic disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have developed methods to evolve proteins continuously in the laboratory toward new biological activities. These methods offer tremendous potential for evolving next-generation gene editing tools and protein therapeutics to treat human diseases; however, they are limited by technical barriers that negatively impact their success rate, efficiency, and broader application. To address these limitations, we propose to develop powerful automation technologies that will dramatically increase the speed, scale, and wider adoption of these methods, and to use the resulting technologies to evolve two classes of proteins with therapeutic potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Postoperative delirium (POD) and postoperative cognitive dysfunction (POCD) are the most common surgical complications experienced by older adults, and they are associated with increased hospital length of stay, early departure from the workforce, increased risk of Alzheimer’s disease, and mortality. Nearly 40% of surgical  patients are older adults, and as the surgical population ages faster than the U.S. population, anesthesiologists are poised to improve the health of older Americans by identifying strategies to prevent POD and POCD. Completing the proposed research will provide evidence that is readily translatable to clinical practice to aid the  choice of general anesthetic strategy to minimize the incidence of POD, POCD, and functional decline in older adults and improve patient-reported outcomes.

PHR: Relevance There are nearly 7 million breast and prostate cancer survivors in the U.S. and most are married. Our type 1 hybrid effectiveness implementation study will conduct a phase II trial to test a partnered exercise approach delivered during radiation treatment on physical and mental health of the dyad and will used a mixed-methods approach to gather information to guide future implementation of the program into routine clinical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of strategies and interventions for preventing or minimizing violent behavior in individuals with psychotic disorders has been limited, in part, by a lack of information about the effects of antipsychotic medications, and in particular clozapine, on violent acts in community settings. In this project, we will determine whether clozapine, when administered in real-world settings, decreases the risk for violent acts in individuals with schizophrenia at high risk for violence when compared to treatment with other antipsychotic medications, and investigate whether previously identified change mechanisms are operative in the effectiveness setting. Examining clozapine in this way will foster a better understanding of the effects of clozapine on violent acts in community settings and allow us to test a scalable intervention and service delivery approaches that can be broadly implemented using typically available resources, and as such has significant public health implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative As highly effective, though non-curative, therapies for metastatic prostate cancer are now being used in earlier stages of disease, there is a critical need for new treatments in castrate resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC). We have identified Trop-2 as a high value target that can be expressed in treatment resistant prostate cancer. We will study biomarkers of Trop-2 in a clinical trial for men with mCRPC with an antibody drug conjugate that targets Trop-2. Integrated blood and tumor biopsies will be analyzed to identify novel predictive biomarkers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of curative approaches for HIV infection is now recognized as both a necessary and attainable goal. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation has been shown to functionally cure HIV infection in two separate patients, but naturally CCR5-deficient donors were required. We propose here to use our non-human primate model of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation to mimic CCR5 deficiency with a CCR5 blocking antibody for HIV cure and to then extend this approach to HIV+ individuals undergoing stem cell transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Chronic disease disease is a major cause of morbidity and mortality; therefore understanding the factors that contribute to kidney disease and ultimately lead to end-organ injury is important. This proposal uses an innovative mouse model and in vitro studies to determine the role of soluble (pro)renin receptor in chronic kidney disease. Findings from this study will establish the functional significance of this receptor, the mechanisms by which the injury effects are mediated and may help in developing a new therapeutic approach for kidney disease in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Engineered cell therapies represent an exciting frontier in medicine, and fully realizing the promise of this approach will require technologies and tools that enable bioengineers to efficiently design, build, and evaluate customized cellular functions that meet specific clinical needs. Towards that goal, this project will develop synthetic biology technologies and computational design tools for engineering cells to sense, evaluate, and respond to their environment in useful ways. Such capabilities will facilitate the development of safer and more effective treatments in areas including cancer, autoimmune disease, and regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Recent studies in mice suggest that specific types of retinal ganglion cells, the neurons that degenerate in glaucoma, are more susceptible to injury. However, translating these findings to the human condition is not straightforward since the mouse and human eye differ in several major ways, including the ocular structures and types of retinal ganglion cells found in the two species. Here we propose a detailed multi-modal assessment of the mechanisms underlying ganglion cell susceptibility in a highly clinically relevant model of glaucoma, which will lead to improved understanding of the disease, novel targets for earlier diagnosis and treatment, and in turn, better options for glaucoma patients to preserve and potentially improve their vision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Elevated energy expenditure and metabolic dysfunction are significant clinical problems facing critically ill patients such as those with severe burns. The goal of this research program is to advance our understanding of the role of the mitochondrion in the metabolic stress response to burn trauma. By leveraging innovative animal models and studying patients, we will generate new knowledge that will aid in the development of strategies that reduce suffering and promote the recovery of burn survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE In type 2 diabetes, accumulation of excess fats in the liver can progress to liver dysfunction or cirrhosis. Studies in this proposal identify a novel mechanism for regulation of fat metabolism in liver tissue that protects against the toxic effects of excess fat. Results of this work could lead to new therapies for one of the most common complications of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most human diseases arise due to disruptions in basic cellular and molecular processes caused by mutations in one's DNA or the presence of a pathogen in one's body. Our program trains students in the core concepts and methods of cell and molecular biology, preparing them to uncover basic insight into the cell and molecular processes that normally control cell growth and development but that when perturbed can lead to diseased states. With better knowledge of these processes and more trained biomedical scientists in the workforce, we can improve our ability to detect, treat, and defeat many crippling human diseases.

Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will enhance human health and reduce the burdens of illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The With No Lysine (WNK) kinases regulate important processes in many different organs of the body, including the kidney, and excess activity of these kinases can lead to high blood pressure, high blood potassium levels, and poor outcomes after stroke. These conditions increase morbidity and mortality. The proposed research will examine new mechanisms for WNK regulation. Ultimately, this could lead to the development of new drugs targeting this pathway, with beneficial effects on human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The analysis of rare and biologically important cell subtypes presents a common challenge in development and disease, where phenotypically variant cell populations can significantly affect the response to therapy and impact patient outcomes. High-throughput single-cell sequencing has proven to be the most successful approach for identifying unique cell subtypes and resolving complex cellular heterogeneity The vision of BioSpyder is to commercially launch a low cost, high-throughput and targeted single-cell multi-omic platform, TempO-LINC, that provides numerous advantages over existing commercial platforms and will enable new studies relying on single-cell sequencing in basic, biopharma, clinical, translational and applied markets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Current diagnosis of spinal cord injury (SCI) mainly relies on X-ray, CT, and MRI, and lacks a quantitative method to evaluate the disease severity and to predict the disease projection. This project is to develop a sensitive, reliable, and quantitative PET imaging method for the diagnosis and prognosis of SCI. It will also allow for the noninvasive longitudinal tracking of SCI recovery and progression and guiding the choice of the therapeutics and the assessment of the effects in clinical trials of disease-modifying interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Expanding access to take home naloxone, a medication used to reverse an opioid overdose death, is a critical step in ensuring equity in available evidence-based practices to address the opioid epidemic. The proposed research will contribute to advancement of implementation strategies focused on equity and sustainability, by addressing the contextual needs of underserved communities through refinement of evidence-based programs. This proposal aligns closely with NIDA’s strategic goal to “increase strategic partnership with the community to improve dissemination and implementation of evidence-based research findings into policy and practice.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research project challenges the current concept of age-related macular degeneration (AMD), the leading cause of severe vision loss in the developed world. Demonstrating that a specific neovascular subtype of AMD actually prevents disease progression in the sense of an intrinsic “rescue mechanism” would not only provide essential information for currently tested treatment approaches but also provide a rationale for new therapeutic strategies in AMD to prevent vision loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because 10% of all infants worldwide are born prematurely, and these infants are especially susceptible to bacterial infection, inflammation and, ultimately, tissue injury that can lead to death. The proposed study opens a new line of investigation focused on the role of maternal inflammation in the high susceptibility of premature infants to intestinal injury. Thus, the proposed experiments are relevant to the NIH mission of developing fundamental knowledge that will help to protect and improve human health by deepening our understanding of the processes of human growth and development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Exercise-based programs for hip osteoarthritis (OA) lack scientific evidence and are ineffective in conservatively treating hip OA. Current experimental protocols are unable to precisely assess the underlying pathomechanism of hip extensor dysfunction that is associated with abnormal hip joint mechanics, hip pain and cartilage breakdown during exercise in hip OA. This study will lead to the development of a novel, multi-modal experimental platform, consisting of magnetic resonance imaging, muscle-function assessment, musculoskeletal simulations and biochemical biomarkers, which will be used to assess the pathomechanism and corresponding effects of hip extensor dysfunction during aerobic exercise in patients with symptomatic hip OA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One of the reasons that explains the high mortality of pancreatic cancer and the lack of responses to most therapies is the fact that the immune system is inactive around this tumor. In this grant we aim to characterize how gut bacteria can trigger immune responses that maintain an immunosuppressive environment which favors tumor growth and resistance to therapies. We plan to study the mechanisms implicated in these events, which include epithelial regulation of immune checkpoint molecules and recruitment of neutrophils, and to target IL-17 to turn pancreatic cancer into a tumor sensitive to immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preserving the integrity of white matter tracts (WMTs) during brain tumor surgery is necessary to maintain function and achieve the best clinical outcomes, but the absence of a clear boundary between WMTs and tumor tissue poses a significant challenge for the neurosurgeon in preserving WMTs. State-of-the-art technologies to image WMTs such as magnetic resonance imaging tractography are limited in helping surgeons preserve the integrity of WMTs, but fluorescence guided surgery (FGS), a surgical tool used to see brain tumors in different colors, provides immediate, direct visualization of tumor tissue during surgery, and has the potential to address the limitations seen with tractography. In the proposed studies, we will develop a FGS strategy by discovering a WMT-specific fluorescent probe to visualize WMTs during surgery, with the long-term goal of dramatically improving surgical outcomes by creating the first in vivo intraoperative WMT imaging technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed study will develop a sustainable, scalable, and patient-centered mobile health combinatorial product, Digital-Chemosensory-Based Olfactory Training for Remote Management of Substance Use Disorders (EDITOR), comprised of (1) a patient-facing culturally-adapted digital-chemosensory platform for treatment of substance use disorders, sensors for acquisition of objective physiological measures of substance intoxication and withdrawal, and an application for running and interpreting these sensory acquisition programs; and (2) a provider-facing web portal, for substance use disorder treatment in socially-disadvantaged minority populations. The proposal will optimize a Digital-Chemosensory-Based Olfactory Training for Remote Management of Substance Use Disorders (EDITOR) platform for socially disadvantaged minority populations and will evaluate the effectiveness for remote treatment of opioid use disorder, cocaine use disorder and alcohol use disorder in medically underserved populations. Accomplishment of the Aims will lead to a commercially ready product that seamlessly links patients and providers, provides effective novel treatment for stimulant use disorder, and improves remote management of SUD in digitally challenged populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Although 24 million Americans suffer from one of the 80 different types of autoimmune disease, the underlying causes are not well understood, and accurate diagnosis can be difficult. Leukocytes are essential immune components that should protect the body against foreign invaders, however dysregulation can instead lead to autoimmune diseases. We aim to uncover the regulation mechanisms and characterize the functions of transmembrane receptors that are highly expressed on the leukocyte surface to provide a blueprint for the rational design of highly-specific therapeutics for autoimmune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Release of neuromodulators, such as serotonin (5-HT), have profound effects on neural circuits and behavior and change following chronic stress. Here, we propose to dissect the selective cellular and circuit effects of a neuromodulator, 5-HT, on specific neuronal subtypes within the lateral habenula (LHb) in vitro and in vivo in mice. Furthermore, following chronic stress we will examine how a common treatment for depression (administration of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs)) modifies the temporal dynamics of 5-HT and effects neuronal activity in the LHb in vivo to understand how activity of specific LHb neuron-types change and effect behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative MRI, and particularly diffusion MRI, is the best imaging method to distinguish healthy prostate from potentially lethal cancer, but because it uses hardware that is built into the MRI scanner, these images have lower signal overall, and not all cancers are visible. We propose a new kind of hardware, a wand placed between the legs during scanning, that will dramatically increase both the signal and contrast in diffusion MRI, improving image quality and making cancers easier to find and monitor. This hardware will improve the imaging of prostate cancers, so that doctors reliably know what they're dealing with, which will reduce both underdiagnosis and overtreatment of this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genomics research is predominantly conducted in homogenous populations of European-descent, limiting the generalizability of genomic findings and hindering the identification of biological pathways underlying disease and the development of equitable tools for the translation of findings to human health for minority populations. Using existing data, this proposal will comprehensively model the interaction of both global and local ancestry with genetic and non-genetic risk factors in admixed populations, who have increased genetic heterogeneity both within and between groups. By drawing upon genetic epidemiology, statistical genetics, and population genetics, the resulting catalog of human ancestry’s role on the genetic underpinnings of disease will better inform methodological development and the application of genomic medicine to bridge existing health inequities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Dry mouth is the frequent side effect of medications, which impairing the cholinergic stimulation of saliva secretion can lead to dry mouth, dental caries, soft tissue damage, and problems with speaking and swallowing. While the saliva secretion is very sensitive to these anticholinergic medications showing a significantly increased usage among adults, information on the oral health side effects is minimal. We propose to assess the salivary secretion and oral health outcomes in dental patients taking anticholinergic medications and explore the role of genetic variations of drug-metabolizing enzymes in the development of dry mouth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because liver cirrhosis affects a large segment of the elderly population with high mortality and high risk for decompensation requiring resource-intensive care, yet little knowledge exists about disease progression and risk prediction. We use a large population based dataset, Chicago Area Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Network (CAPriCORN), which captures the electronic health records (EHR) from nine health systems from 2011-present (incl. academic center, county, VA and private), catching most of the diverse patient population in a large metropolitan area, namely ~160,000 patients with liver cirrhosis. With a strong analytical and clinical team we will use traditional and machine learning techniques to study disease progression and risk prediction in older patients with cirrhosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: NATHAN S. KLINE INSTITUTE FOR PSYCH RES
PHR: Narrative Using data obtained with electrophysiological recordings spanning multiple spatial scales in humans and non- human primates, coupled with advanced data analyses, we are developing a detailed computational model of the brain’s driving and modulatory circuits, and their hallmark neuronal oscillatory dynamics. These “dynamic circuit motifs” support distinct functions, that integrate auditory processing with other critical functions including selective attention, motor operations, and memory recall. We will use the model and experimental data to better understand the brain and the characteristic neuronal deficits underlying a variety of brain diseases. We will utilize model-based neuromodulation in order to causally verify the function of identified circuits and neuronal activity patterns. These precisely targeted neuromodulation methods could be used in the future to restore intricate balances of neuronal oscillatory dynamics that are disrupted in hearing disorders, as well as in neuropsychiatric conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative While the majority of genes in a genome are dispensable, a relatively small number of genes are essential under any circumstance and are generally seen as rigid genetic components, consequently making them excellent antimicrobial targets. Preliminary work has shown that many essential genes can lose their essentiality depending on the genetic background, making them evolvable. Here we determine what makes an essential gene evolvable, we test whether evolvable essentiality is predictable, what the phenotypic and mechanistic consequences are (especially for cell wall synthesis), whether there are fitness costs and/or adaptability changes and, importantly, we apply our newly found knowledge to design a proof-of-principle gene-targeting drug screen.
